1	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">ARMS ACT, 1878 AND ARMS RULES, 1924</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  40 DLR (AD) 170,40 DLR 251, 40 (AD) 170,44 DLR 110,41 DLR 524, 4I DLR 524, 40 DLR 493,44 DLR 159,43 DLR 150</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1878</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  ARMS</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-01-08</p><!DOCTYPE html><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: center;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;">Arms Act, 1878</u></span></div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Sections 16 &amp; 18—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Appellant was neither given any notice of enquiry nor was he given any hearing before cancellation of arms—Enquiry undertaken on a sprawling private complaint made by the local upazila Chairman.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>No emergency or any other compelling situation  preventing  giving of notice of enquiry lo the appellant—Nothing on record to show that any specific case was started against the appellant involving alleged misuse of revolver —Inquisitorial nature of enquiry aggravating the degree of unfairness—Principles of natural justice to be observed in proceedings affecting "the person or property or other right of parties concerned "—court adds a rider to the observance of the principle of natural justice that so far as exercise of power under section 18 of the Arms Act is concerned, the absence of a prior notice or hearing may not always invalidate the order passed thereunder if the security of the public peace is involved.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Sk. Ali Ahmed Vs. Secretary, Home Affairs 40 DLR (AD) 170.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Sections 16(1) and 19(1)—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>The  Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Shariatpur had no jurisdiction whatsoever to cancel the license s of the guns in question under section 18(a) of the Arms Act or under any provision of the Arms Rules of 1924. As the license s of the guns in question were not cancelled by any legally competent authority such as the District Magistrate or by any authorised officer to whom he is subordinate as required under the provisions of Arms Act or the Arms rules, cancellation thereof by the SDO is illegal. Conviction under sections 16(1) and 19(1) of the Arms Act read with section 26 of the Special Powers Act is not sustainable in law.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Anawar  Hossains. Vs State  40 DLR </em></span><em style="font-weight: bold; box-sizing: border-box;">251.</em></div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 18—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Cancellation and suspension of license for arms—The necessity of recording reasons by the appropriate authority in writing for the cancellation of the license to be emphasized as a general rule—If the appropriate authority chooses not to make its order a speaking one and merely relies on the materials on record, its order stands a greater risk of being struck down. <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Sk. Ali Ahmed Vs. Secretary Home Affairs 40 (AD) 170.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 18—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Orders passed by the District Magistrate cancelling license s of guns of the petitioners without giving them any notice and opportunity of being heard and giving no reason for cancellation are illegal being violative of the principal of natural justice.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Rezaul Karim (Md) Vs. Ministry of Home Affairs 44 DLR 110.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 19A—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Uncorroborated testimony of an accomplice cannot be basis of conviction of an accused.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Kazi ibrahim Vs State 41 DLR 524.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 19A—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>A person cannot be convicted on surmises and conjectures and from any analogical deduction.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Kazi Ibrahim VS. State 4I DLR 524.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 19(f)—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Appellants leading the police to place of occurrence and recovery of arms—Appellants cannot be held guilty of the charge of unauthorised possession of arms under section 19(f) of the Arms Act.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Abdul Khaleque Vs. State 40 DLR 493.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 19(f)—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Recovery of arms—culpability—mere knowledge of the accused that the arms were lying at the spot pointed out by him in the absence of evidence that he himself kept the same there or that he had exclusive possession over it, he cannot be made liable under section 19(f).<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Abul Hashem Master Vs. State 44 DLR 159.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> </div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: center;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;">Arms Rules, 1924</u></span></div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Column 2 of the Table Schedule I as amended by notification No 896—Section II dated Dhaka the l9th November l973—The decision in this case having depended on findings of facts as to whether the seized arm were recovered from the possession of the petitioner, whether the same came within the exception provided for and covered by amnesty, if any, declared by the government, the extraordinary power to prevent the abuse of process of the court is not required to be exercised.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Hossain Mohammad Ershad Vs. State 43 DLR 150</em></span></div></div></div>
2	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">ARMS ACT, 1878 AND ARMS RULES, 1924</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  40 DLR (AD) 170,40 DLR 251, 40 (AD) 170,44 DLR 110,41 DLR 524, 4I DLR 524, 40 DLR 493,44 DLR 159,43 DLR 150</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1878</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  ARMS</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-01-08</p><!DOCTYPE html><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: center;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;">Arms Act, 1878</u></span></div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Sections 16 &amp; 18—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Appellant was neither given any notice of enquiry nor was he given any hearing before cancellation of arms—Enquiry undertaken on a sprawling private complaint made by the local upazila Chairman.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>No emergency or any other compelling situation  preventing  giving of notice of enquiry lo the appellant—Nothing on record to show that any specific case was started against the appellant involving alleged misuse of revolver —Inquisitorial nature of enquiry aggravating the degree of unfairness—Principles of natural justice to be observed in proceedings affecting "the person or property or other right of parties concerned "—court adds a rider to the observance of the principle of natural justice that so far as exercise of power under section 18 of the Arms Act is concerned, the absence of a prior notice or hearing may not always invalidate the order passed thereunder if the security of the public peace is involved.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Sk. Ali Ahmed Vs. Secretary, Home Affairs 40 DLR (AD) 170.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Sections 16(1) and 19(1)—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>The  Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Shariatpur had no jurisdiction whatsoever to cancel the license s of the guns in question under section 18(a) of the Arms Act or under any provision of the Arms Rules of 1924. As the license s of the guns in question were not cancelled by any legally competent authority such as the District Magistrate or by any authorised officer to whom he is subordinate as required under the provisions of Arms Act or the Arms rules, cancellation thereof by the SDO is illegal. Conviction under sections 16(1) and 19(1) of the Arms Act read with section 26 of the Special Powers Act is not sustainable in law.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Anawar  Hossains. Vs State  40 DLR </em></span><em style="font-weight: bold; box-sizing: border-box;">251.</em></div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 18—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Cancellation and suspension of license for arms—The necessity of recording reasons by the appropriate authority in writing for the cancellation of the license to be emphasized as a general rule—If the appropriate authority chooses not to make its order a speaking one and merely relies on the materials on record, its order stands a greater risk of being struck down. <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Sk. Ali Ahmed Vs. Secretary Home Affairs 40 (AD) 170.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 18—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Orders passed by the District Magistrate cancelling license s of guns of the petitioners without giving them any notice and opportunity of being heard and giving no reason for cancellation are illegal being violative of the principal of natural justice.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Rezaul Karim (Md) Vs. Ministry of Home Affairs 44 DLR 110.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 19A—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Uncorroborated testimony of an accomplice cannot be basis of conviction of an accused.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Kazi ibrahim Vs State 41 DLR 524.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 19A—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>A person cannot be convicted on surmises and conjectures and from any analogical deduction.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Kazi Ibrahim VS. State 4I DLR 524.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 19(f)—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Appellants leading the police to place of occurrence and recovery of arms—Appellants cannot be held guilty of the charge of unauthorised possession of arms under section 19(f) of the Arms Act.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Abdul Khaleque Vs. State 40 DLR 493.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 19(f)—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Recovery of arms—culpability—mere knowledge of the accused that the arms were lying at the spot pointed out by him in the absence of evidence that he himself kept the same there or that he had exclusive possession over it, he cannot be made liable under section 19(f).<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Abul Hashem Master Vs. State 44 DLR 159.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> </div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: center;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;">Arms Rules, 1924</u></span></div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Column 2 of the Table Schedule I as amended by notification No 896—Section II dated Dhaka the l9th November l973—The decision in this case having depended on findings of facts as to whether the seized arm were recovered from the possession of the petitioner, whether the same came within the exception provided for and covered by amnesty, if any, declared by the government, the extraordinary power to prevent the abuse of process of the court is not required to be exercised.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Hossain Mohammad Ershad Vs. State 43 DLR 150</em></span></div></div></div>
3	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">ARMS ACT, 1878 AND ARMS RULES, 1924</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  40 DLR (AD) 170,40 DLR 251, 40 (AD) 170,44 DLR 110,41 DLR 524, 4I DLR 524, 40 DLR 493,44 DLR 159,43 DLR 150</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1878</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  ARMS</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-01-08</p><!DOCTYPE html><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: center;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;">Arms Act, 1878</u></span></div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Sections 16 &amp; 18—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Appellant was neither given any notice of enquiry nor was he given any hearing before cancellation of arms—Enquiry undertaken on a sprawling private complaint made by the local upazila Chairman.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>No emergency or any other compelling situation  preventing  giving of notice of enquiry lo the appellant—Nothing on record to show that any specific case was started against the appellant involving alleged misuse of revolver —Inquisitorial nature of enquiry aggravating the degree of unfairness—Principles of natural justice to be observed in proceedings affecting "the person or property or other right of parties concerned "—court adds a rider to the observance of the principle of natural justice that so far as exercise of power under section 18 of the Arms Act is concerned, the absence of a prior notice or hearing may not always invalidate the order passed thereunder if the security of the public peace is involved.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Sk. Ali Ahmed Vs. Secretary, Home Affairs 40 DLR (AD) 170.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Sections 16(1) and 19(1)—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>The  Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Shariatpur had no jurisdiction whatsoever to cancel the license s of the guns in question under section 18(a) of the Arms Act or under any provision of the Arms Rules of 1924. As the license s of the guns in question were not cancelled by any legally competent authority such as the District Magistrate or by any authorised officer to whom he is subordinate as required under the provisions of Arms Act or the Arms rules, cancellation thereof by the SDO is illegal. Conviction under sections 16(1) and 19(1) of the Arms Act read with section 26 of the Special Powers Act is not sustainable in law.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Anawar  Hossains. Vs State  40 DLR </em></span><em style="font-weight: bold; box-sizing: border-box;">251.</em></div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 18—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Cancellation and suspension of license for arms—The necessity of recording reasons by the appropriate authority in writing for the cancellation of the license to be emphasized as a general rule—If the appropriate authority chooses not to make its order a speaking one and merely relies on the materials on record, its order stands a greater risk of being struck down. <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Sk. Ali Ahmed Vs. Secretary Home Affairs 40 (AD) 170.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 18—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Orders passed by the District Magistrate cancelling license s of guns of the petitioners without giving them any notice and opportunity of being heard and giving no reason for cancellation are illegal being violative of the principal of natural justice.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Rezaul Karim (Md) Vs. Ministry of Home Affairs 44 DLR 110.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 19A—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Uncorroborated testimony of an accomplice cannot be basis of conviction of an accused.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Kazi ibrahim Vs State 41 DLR 524.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 19A—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>A person cannot be convicted on surmises and conjectures and from any analogical deduction.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Kazi Ibrahim VS. State 4I DLR 524.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 19(f)—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Appellants leading the police to place of occurrence and recovery of arms—Appellants cannot be held guilty of the charge of unauthorised possession of arms under section 19(f) of the Arms Act.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Abdul Khaleque Vs. State 40 DLR 493.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 19(f)—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Recovery of arms—culpability—mere knowledge of the accused that the arms were lying at the spot pointed out by him in the absence of evidence that he himself kept the same there or that he had exclusive possession over it, he cannot be made liable under section 19(f).<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Abul Hashem Master Vs. State 44 DLR 159.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> </div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: center;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;">Arms Rules, 1924</u></span></div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Column 2 of the Table Schedule I as amended by notification No 896—Section II dated Dhaka the l9th November l973—The decision in this case having depended on findings of facts as to whether the seized arm were recovered from the possession of the petitioner, whether the same came within the exception provided for and covered by amnesty, if any, declared by the government, the extraordinary power to prevent the abuse of process of the court is not required to be exercised.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Hossain Mohammad Ershad Vs. State 43 DLR 150</em></span></div></div></div>
4	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">ARMS ACT, 1878 AND ARMS RULES, 1924</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  40 DLR (AD) 170,40 DLR 251, 40 (AD) 170,44 DLR 110,41 DLR 524, 4I DLR 524, 40 DLR 493,44 DLR 159,43 DLR 150</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1878</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  ARMS</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-01-08</p><!DOCTYPE html><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: center;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;">Arms Act, 1878</u></span></div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Sections 16 &amp; 18—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Appellant was neither given any notice of enquiry nor was he given any hearing before cancellation of arms—Enquiry undertaken on a sprawling private complaint made by the local upazila Chairman.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>No emergency or any other compelling situation  preventing  giving of notice of enquiry lo the appellant—Nothing on record to show that any specific case was started against the appellant involving alleged misuse of revolver —Inquisitorial nature of enquiry aggravating the degree of unfairness—Principles of natural justice to be observed in proceedings affecting "the person or property or other right of parties concerned "—court adds a rider to the observance of the principle of natural justice that so far as exercise of power under section 18 of the Arms Act is concerned, the absence of a prior notice or hearing may not always invalidate the order passed thereunder if the security of the public peace is involved.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Sk. Ali Ahmed Vs. Secretary, Home Affairs 40 DLR (AD) 170.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Sections 16(1) and 19(1)—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>The  Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Shariatpur had no jurisdiction whatsoever to cancel the license s of the guns in question under section 18(a) of the Arms Act or under any provision of the Arms Rules of 1924. As the license s of the guns in question were not cancelled by any legally competent authority such as the District Magistrate or by any authorised officer to whom he is subordinate as required under the provisions of Arms Act or the Arms rules, cancellation thereof by the SDO is illegal. Conviction under sections 16(1) and 19(1) of the Arms Act read with section 26 of the Special Powers Act is not sustainable in law.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Anawar  Hossains. Vs State  40 DLR </em></span><em style="font-weight: bold; box-sizing: border-box;">251.</em></div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 18—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Cancellation and suspension of license for arms—The necessity of recording reasons by the appropriate authority in writing for the cancellation of the license to be emphasized as a general rule—If the appropriate authority chooses not to make its order a speaking one and merely relies on the materials on record, its order stands a greater risk of being struck down. <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Sk. Ali Ahmed Vs. Secretary Home Affairs 40 (AD) 170.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 18—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Orders passed by the District Magistrate cancelling license s of guns of the petitioners without giving them any notice and opportunity of being heard and giving no reason for cancellation are illegal being violative of the principal of natural justice.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Rezaul Karim (Md) Vs. Ministry of Home Affairs 44 DLR 110.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 19A—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Uncorroborated testimony of an accomplice cannot be basis of conviction of an accused.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Kazi ibrahim Vs State 41 DLR 524.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 19A—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>A person cannot be convicted on surmises and conjectures and from any analogical deduction.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Kazi Ibrahim VS. State 4I DLR 524.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 19(f)—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Appellants leading the police to place of occurrence and recovery of arms—Appellants cannot be held guilty of the charge of unauthorised possession of arms under section 19(f) of the Arms Act.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Abdul Khaleque Vs. State 40 DLR 493.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 19(f)—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Recovery of arms—culpability—mere knowledge of the accused that the arms were lying at the spot pointed out by him in the absence of evidence that he himself kept the same there or that he had exclusive possession over it, he cannot be made liable under section 19(f).<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Abul Hashem Master Vs. State 44 DLR 159.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> </div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: center;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;">Arms Rules, 1924</u></span></div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Column 2 of the Table Schedule I as amended by notification No 896—Section II dated Dhaka the l9th November l973—The decision in this case having depended on findings of facts as to whether the seized arm were recovered from the possession of the petitioner, whether the same came within the exception provided for and covered by amnesty, if any, declared by the government, the extraordinary power to prevent the abuse of process of the court is not required to be exercised.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Hossain Mohammad Ershad Vs. State 43 DLR 150</em></span></div></div></div>
5	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">ARMS ACT, 1878 AND ARMS RULES, 1924</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  40 DLR (AD) 170,40 DLR 251, 40 (AD) 170,44 DLR 110,41 DLR 524, 4I DLR 524, 40 DLR 493,44 DLR 159,43 DLR 150</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1878</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  ARMS</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-01-08</p><!DOCTYPE html><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: center;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;">Arms Act, 1878</u></span></div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Sections 16 &amp; 18—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Appellant was neither given any notice of enquiry nor was he given any hearing before cancellation of arms—Enquiry undertaken on a sprawling private complaint made by the local upazila Chairman.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>No emergency or any other compelling situation  preventing  giving of notice of enquiry lo the appellant—Nothing on record to show that any specific case was started against the appellant involving alleged misuse of revolver —Inquisitorial nature of enquiry aggravating the degree of unfairness—Principles of natural justice to be observed in proceedings affecting "the person or property or other right of parties concerned "—court adds a rider to the observance of the principle of natural justice that so far as exercise of power under section 18 of the Arms Act is concerned, the absence of a prior notice or hearing may not always invalidate the order passed thereunder if the security of the public peace is involved.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Sk. Ali Ahmed Vs. Secretary, Home Affairs 40 DLR (AD) 170.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Sections 16(1) and 19(1)—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>The  Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Shariatpur had no jurisdiction whatsoever to cancel the license s of the guns in question under section 18(a) of the Arms Act or under any provision of the Arms Rules of 1924. As the license s of the guns in question were not cancelled by any legally competent authority such as the District Magistrate or by any authorised officer to whom he is subordinate as required under the provisions of Arms Act or the Arms rules, cancellation thereof by the SDO is illegal. Conviction under sections 16(1) and 19(1) of the Arms Act read with section 26 of the Special Powers Act is not sustainable in law.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Anawar  Hossains. Vs State  40 DLR </em></span><em style="font-weight: bold; box-sizing: border-box;">251.</em></div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 18—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Cancellation and suspension of license for arms—The necessity of recording reasons by the appropriate authority in writing for the cancellation of the license to be emphasized as a general rule—If the appropriate authority chooses not to make its order a speaking one and merely relies on the materials on record, its order stands a greater risk of being struck down. <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Sk. Ali Ahmed Vs. Secretary Home Affairs 40 (AD) 170.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 18—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Orders passed by the District Magistrate cancelling license s of guns of the petitioners without giving them any notice and opportunity of being heard and giving no reason for cancellation are illegal being violative of the principal of natural justice.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Rezaul Karim (Md) Vs. Ministry of Home Affairs 44 DLR 110.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 19A—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Uncorroborated testimony of an accomplice cannot be basis of conviction of an accused.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Kazi ibrahim Vs State 41 DLR 524.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 19A—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>A person cannot be convicted on surmises and conjectures and from any analogical deduction.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Kazi Ibrahim VS. State 4I DLR 524.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 19(f)—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Appellants leading the police to place of occurrence and recovery of arms—Appellants cannot be held guilty of the charge of unauthorised possession of arms under section 19(f) of the Arms Act.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Abdul Khaleque Vs. State 40 DLR 493.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 19(f)—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Recovery of arms—culpability—mere knowledge of the accused that the arms were lying at the spot pointed out by him in the absence of evidence that he himself kept the same there or that he had exclusive possession over it, he cannot be made liable under section 19(f).<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Abul Hashem Master Vs. State 44 DLR 159.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> </div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: center;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;">Arms Rules, 1924</u></span></div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Column 2 of the Table Schedule I as amended by notification No 896—Section II dated Dhaka the l9th November l973—The decision in this case having depended on findings of facts as to whether the seized arm were recovered from the possession of the petitioner, whether the same came within the exception provided for and covered by amnesty, if any, declared by the government, the extraordinary power to prevent the abuse of process of the court is not required to be exercised.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Hossain Mohammad Ershad Vs. State 43 DLR 150</em></span></div></div></div>
6	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">ARMS ACT, 1878 AND ARMS RULES, 1924</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  40 DLR (AD) 170,40 DLR 251, 40 (AD) 170,44 DLR 110,41 DLR 524, 4I DLR 524, 40 DLR 493,44 DLR 159,43 DLR 150</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1878</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  ARMS</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-01-08</p><!DOCTYPE html><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: center;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;">Arms Act, 1878</u></span></div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Sections 16 &amp; 18—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Appellant was neither given any notice of enquiry nor was he given any hearing before cancellation of arms—Enquiry undertaken on a sprawling private complaint made by the local upazila Chairman.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>No emergency or any other compelling situation  preventing  giving of notice of enquiry lo the appellant—Nothing on record to show that any specific case was started against the appellant involving alleged misuse of revolver —Inquisitorial nature of enquiry aggravating the degree of unfairness—Principles of natural justice to be observed in proceedings affecting "the person or property or other right of parties concerned "—court adds a rider to the observance of the principle of natural justice that so far as exercise of power under section 18 of the Arms Act is concerned, the absence of a prior notice or hearing may not always invalidate the order passed thereunder if the security of the public peace is involved.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Sk. Ali Ahmed Vs. Secretary, Home Affairs 40 DLR (AD) 170.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Sections 16(1) and 19(1)—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>The  Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Shariatpur had no jurisdiction whatsoever to cancel the license s of the guns in question under section 18(a) of the Arms Act or under any provision of the Arms Rules of 1924. Vs State  40 DLR </em></span><em style="font-weight: bold; box-sizing: border-box;">251.</em></div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 18—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Cancellation and suspension of license for arms—The necessity of recording reasons by the appropriate authority in writing for the cancellation of the license to be emphasized as a general rule—If the appropriate authority chooses not to make its order a speaking one and merely relies on the materials on record, its order stands a greater risk of being struck down. <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Sk. Ali Ahmed Vs. Secretary Home Affairs 40 (AD) 170.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 18—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Orders passed by the District Magistrate cancelling license s of guns of the petitioners without giving them any notice and opportunity of being heard and giving no reason for cancellation are illegal being violative of the principal of natural justice.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Rezaul Karim (Md) Vs. Ministry of Home Affairs 44 DLR 110.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 19A—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Uncorroborated testimony of an accomplice cannot be basis of conviction of an accused.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Kazi ibrahim Vs State 41 DLR 524.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 19A—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>A person cannot be convicted on surmises and conjectures and from any analogical deduction.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Kazi Ibrahim VS. State 4I DLR 524.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 19(f)—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Appellants leading the police to place of occurrence and recovery of arms—Appellants cannot be held guilty of the charge of unauthorised possession of arms under section 19(f) of the Arms Act.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Abdul Khaleque Vs. State 40 DLR 493.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 19(f)—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Recovery of arms—culpability—mere knowledge of the accused that the arms were lying at the spot pointed out by him in the absence of evidence that he himself kept the same there or that he had exclusive possession over it, he cannot be made liable under section 19(f).<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Abul Hashem Master Vs. State 44 DLR 159.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> </div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: center;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;">Arms Rules, 1924</u></span></div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Column 2 of the Table Schedule I as amended by notification No 896—Section II dated Dhaka the l9th November l973—The decision in this case having depended on findings of facts as to whether the seized arm were recovered from the possession of the petitioner, whether the same came within the exception provided for and covered by amnesty, if any, declared by the government, the extraordinary power to prevent the abuse of process of the court is not required to be exercised.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Hossain Mohammad Ershad Vs. State 43 DLR 150</em></span></div></div></div>
7	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">ARMS ACT, 1878 AND ARMS RULES, 1924</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  40 DLR (AD) 170,40 DLR 251, 40 (AD) 170,44 DLR 110,41 DLR 524, 4I DLR 524, 40 DLR 493,44 DLR 159,43 DLR 150</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1878</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  ARMS</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-01-08</p><!DOCTYPE html><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: center;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;">Arms Act, 1878</u></span></div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Sections 16 &amp; 18—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Appellant was neither given any notice of enquiry nor was he given any hearing before cancellation of arms—Enquiry undertaken on a sprawling private complaint made by the local upazila Chairman.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>No emergency or any other compelling situation  preventing  giving of notice of enquiry lo the appellant—Nothing on record to show that any specific case was started against the appellant involving alleged misuse of revolver —Inquisitorial nature of enquiry aggravating the degree of unfairness—Principles of natural justice to be observed in proceedings affecting "the person or property or other right of parties concerned "—court adds a rider to the observance of the principle of natural justice that so far as exercise of power under section 18 of the Arms Act is concerned, the absence of a prior notice or hearing may not always invalidate the order passed thereunder if the security of the public peace is involved.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Sk. Ali Ahmed Vs. Secretary, Home Affairs 40 DLR (AD) 170.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Sections 16(1) and 19(1)—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>The  Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Shariatpur had no jurisdiction whatsoever to cancel the license s of the guns in question under section 18(a) of the Arms Act or under any provision of the Arms Rules of 1924. Vs State  40 DLR </em></span><em style="font-weight: bold; box-sizing: border-box;">251.</em></div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 18—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Cancellation and suspension of license for arms—The necessity of recording reasons by the appropriate authority in writing for the cancellation of the license to be emphasized as a general rule—If the appropriate authority chooses not to make its order a speaking one and merely relies on the materials on record, its order stands a greater risk of being struck down. <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Sk. Ali Ahmed Vs. Secretary Home Affairs 40 (AD) 170.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 18—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Orders passed by the District Magistrate cancelling license s of guns of the petitioners without giving them any notice and opportunity of being heard and giving no reason for cancellation are illegal being violative of the principal of natural justice.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Rezaul Karim (Md) Vs. Ministry of Home Affairs 44 DLR 110.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 19A—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Uncorroborated testimony of an accomplice cannot be basis of conviction of an accused.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Kazi ibrahim Vs State 41 DLR 524.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 19A—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>A person cannot be convicted on surmises and conjectures and from any analogical deduction.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Kazi Ibrahim VS. State 4I DLR 524.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 19(f)—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Appellants leading the police to place of occurrence and recovery of arms—Appellants cannot be held guilty of the charge of unauthorised possession of arms under section 19(f) of the Arms Act.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Abdul Khaleque Vs. State 40 DLR 493.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 19(f)—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Recovery of arms—culpability—mere knowledge of the accused that the arms were lying at the spot pointed out by him in the absence of evidence that he himself kept the same there or that he had exclusive possession over it, he cannot be made liable under section 19(f).<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Abul Hashem Master Vs. State 44 DLR 159.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> </div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: center;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;">Arms Rules, 1924</u></span></div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Column 2 of the Table Schedule I as amended by notification No 896—Section II dated Dhaka the l9th November l973—The decision in this case having depended on findings of facts as to whether the seized arm were recovered from the possession of the petitioner, whether the same came within the exception provided for and covered by amnesty, if any, declared by the government, the extraordinary power to prevent the abuse of process of the court is not required to be exercised.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Hossain Mohammad Ershad Vs. State 43 DLR 150</em></span></div></div></div>
8	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">ARMS ACT, 1878 AND ARMS RULES, 1924</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  40 DLR (AD) 170,40 DLR 251, 40 (AD) 170,44 DLR 110,41 DLR 524, 4I DLR 524, 40 DLR 493,44 DLR 159,43 DLR 150</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1878</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  ARMS</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-01-08</p><!DOCTYPE html><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: center;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;">Arms Act, 1878</u></span></div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Sections 16 &amp; 18—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Appellant was neither given any notice of enquiry nor was he given any hearing before cancellation of arms—Enquiry undertaken on a sprawling private complaint made by the local upazila Chairman.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>No emergency or any other compelling situation  preventing  giving of notice of enquiry lo the appellant—Nothing on record to show that any specific case was started against the appellant involving alleged misuse of revolver —Inquisitorial nature of enquiry aggravating the degree of unfairness—Principles of natural justice to be observed in proceedings affecting "the person or property or other right of parties concerned "—court adds a rider to the observance of the principle of natural justice that so far as exercise of power under section 18 of the Arms Act is concerned, the absence of a prior notice or hearing may not always invalidate the order passed thereunder if the security of the public peace is involved.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Sk. Ali Ahmed Vs. Secretary, Home Affairs 40 DLR (AD) 170.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Sections 16(1) and 19(1)—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>The  Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Shariatpur had no jurisdiction whatsoever to cancel the license s of the guns in question under section 18(a) of the Arms Act or under any provision of the Arms Rules of 1924. As the license s of the guns in question were not cancelled by any legally competent authority such as the District Magistrate or by any authorised officer to whom he is subordinate as required under the provisions of Arms Act or the Arms rules, cancellation thereof by the SDO is illegal. Conviction under sections 16(1) and 19(1) of the Arms Act read with section 26 of the Special Powers Act is not sustainable in law.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Anawar  Hossains. Vs State  40 DLR </em></span><em style="font-weight: bold; box-sizing: border-box;">251.</em></div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 18—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Cancellation and suspension of license for arms—The necessity of recording reasons by the appropriate authority in writing for the cancellation of the license to be emphasized as a general rule—If the appropriate authority chooses not to make its order a speaking one and merely relies on the materials on record, its order stands a greater risk of being struck down. <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Sk. Ali Ahmed Vs. Secretary Home Affairs 40 (AD) 170.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 18—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Orders passed by the District Magistrate cancelling license s of guns of the petitioners without giving them any notice and opportunity of being heard and giving no reason for cancellation are illegal being violative of the principal of natural justice.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Rezaul Karim (Md) Vs. Ministry of Home Affairs 44 DLR 110.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 19A—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Uncorroborated testimony of an accomplice cannot be basis of conviction of an accused.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Kazi ibrahim Vs State 41 DLR 524.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 19A—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>A person cannot be convicted on surmises and conjectures and from any analogical deduction.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Kazi Ibrahim VS. State 4I DLR 524.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 19(f)—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Appellants leading the police to place of occurrence and recovery of arms—Appellants cannot be held guilty of the charge of unauthorised possession of arms under section 19(f) of the Arms Act.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Abdul Khaleque Vs. State 40 DLR 493.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 19(f)—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Recovery of arms—culpability—mere knowledge of the accused that the arms were lying at the spot pointed out by him in the absence of evidence that he himself kept the same there or that he had exclusive possession over it, he cannot be made liable under section 19(f).<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Abul Hashem Master Vs. State 44 DLR 159.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> </div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: center;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;">Arms Rules, 1924</u></span></div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Column 2 of the Table Schedule I as amended by notification No 896—Section II dated Dhaka the l9th November l973—The decision in this case having depended on findings of facts as to whether the seized arm were recovered from the possession of the petitioner, whether the same came within the exception provided for and covered by amnesty, if any, declared by the government, the extraordinary power to prevent the abuse of process of the court is not required to be exercised.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Hossain Mohammad Ershad Vs. State 43 DLR 150</em></span></div></div></div>
9	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">The Companies Act, 1994</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  9 ADC 979, 10 ADC 500, 9 ADC 779, 6 ADC 565, 8 ADC 193, 8 ADC 567, 9 ADC 472, 9 ADC 901.</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Companies</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-10-31</p><!DOCTYPE html><p><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> <o:OfficeDocumentSettings>  <o:RelyOnVML/>  <o:AllowPNG/>
