Heading"/> </w:LatentStyles></xml><![endif]--><!-- [if gte mso 10]><style> /* Style Definitions */ table.MsoNormalTable	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;	mso-style-noshow:yes;	mso-style-priority:99;	mso-style-qformat:yes;	mso-style-parent:"";	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;	mso-para-margin:0in;	mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;	font-size:11.0pt;	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";	mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;	mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast;	mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;	mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;}</style><![endif]--></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -4.3pt; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 4.55pt 0in .0001pt 23.05pt;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">The Emergency Requisition of Property Act, 1948, Section 3</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">Subsequently Joydebpur Cantonment i was shifted too Rajendrapur and conse­quently the possession of the remaining land was handed over to the Deputy Commissioner by the order of the au­thority dated 20.06.1979. No notice ei­ther under section 5(1 )(a) or section 5(3) of the said Act was served nor no­tice under section 5(7) of the said Act was published in the official Gazettee and compensation in respect of the said land was paid. <em>A.S.M.AnayetuJlah vs. Bangladesh represented by the Secre­tary (Md. Joynul Abedin J) (Civil)6 ADC 309.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-indent: -44.65pt; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 4.55pt 0in .0001pt 44.65pt;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Emergency Requisition of Property Act, 1948, Section 5</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">The appellate court affirmed the judg­ment and decree of the trial court hold­ing the same view that since the plaintiff purchased the suit land from the original owner before acquisition of the same by the Government the plaintiff acquired right and title in the suit land and he had also been possessing the same. Against this judgment of the appellate court the appellant filed the above mentioned Civil Revision No. 1606 of 2001 and ob­tained the Rule. A Single Bench of the High Court Division, on hearing the learned Advocate for the appellant-pe­titioner and considering the facts and circumstances and relevant laws, made the Rule absolute making observations to the effect that the suit land was ad­mittedly acquired by the Government by gazette notification and holding that "once a property is acquired and Gazette Notification is published under Section 5(7) of the Emergency Requisi­tion of Property Act, the right, title and interest, if any, of the owners are extin­guished". <em>Md. BandeAli Miah vs. Chief Engineer, Housing and Settlement (Naz-mun Ara Sultana J)(Civil) 8 ADC 604.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt;">Section 5(7)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">Section 5(7) of the said Act provide that "on and from the beginning of the day on which the notice is so published the requisitioned property shall vest ab­solutely in the government free from all encumbrances". Section 14A imposes an express bar on the entertainment of any suit against any order passed or any action taken under the said Act. On con­sideration of these provisions of law, the judgment and order of the High Court Division and the judgment of this Divi­sion, we find merit in the contention of the learned Attorney General. Leave is., therefore, granted to consider on addi­tional grounds as under. <em>Government of Bangladesh vs. Mohammad Alamgir Hossain (S.K. Sinha Jj(Civil) 8 ADC 702</em></span></p></div></div>
13	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">DRUGS (CONTROL) ORDINANCE, 1982</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  42 DLR 493, 45 DLR 640.</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1982</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  DRUGS</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-01-13</p><!DOCTYPE html><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: center;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 16px;"> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;">Drugs (Control) Ordinance, 1982</u></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;">[VIII of 1982]</u></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> </span></div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Sections 8 and 16—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Interpretation of Statutes—The order of the appellants’ conviction by the Judge of Drug Court is based on his finding of “keeping in stock and exhibiting the medicine (banned one) in the shop”. Neither section 8 nor section 16 contains the quoted expression. Penal statute must be strictly construed and a court in order to punish an accused must not introduce any expression which has not been used by the makers of the law. The impugned order must therefore be struck down.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Dr. Golam Rahman Vs. State 42 DLR 493.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 23—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Instead of holding the trial before the Drug Court it was held before the wrong forum of Special Tribunal which is no trial in the eye of law. The order of conviction and sentence is therefore set aside and the case is sent back to the Drug Court for fresh cognizance and trial.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Shahidullah , 2. Jane Alam Vs. State 45 DLR 640.</em></span></div></div></div>
14	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">DRUGS (CONTROL) ORDINANCE, 1982</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  42 DLR 493, 45 DLR 640.</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1982</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  DRUGS</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-01-13</p><!DOCTYPE html><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: center;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 16px;"> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;">Drugs (Control) Ordinance, 1982</u></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;">[VIII of 1982]</u></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> </span></div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Sections 8 and 16—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Interpretation of Statutes—The order of the appellants’ conviction by the Judge of Drug Court is based on his finding of “keeping in stock and exhibiting the medicine (banned one) in the shop”. Neither section 8 nor section 16 contains the quoted expression. Penal statute must be strictly construed and a court in order to punish an accused must not introduce any expression which has not been used by the makers of the law. The impugned order must therefore be struck down.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Dr. Golam Rahman Vs. State 42 DLR 493.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 23—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Instead of holding the trial before the Drug Court it was held before the wrong forum of Special Tribunal which is no trial in the eye of law. The order of conviction and sentence is therefore set aside and the case is sent back to the Drug Court for fresh cognizance and trial.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Shahidullah , 2. Jane Alam Vs. State 45 DLR 640.</em></span></div></div></div>
15	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">DRUGS (CONTROL) ORDINANCE, 1982</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  42 DLR 493, 45 DLR 640.</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1982</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  DRUGS</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-01-13</p><!DOCTYPE html><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: center;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 16px;"> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;">Drugs (Control) Ordinance, 1982</u></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;">[VIII of 1982]</u></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> </span></div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Sections 8 and 16—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Interpretation of Statutes—The order of the appellants’ conviction by the Judge of Drug Court is based on his finding of “keeping in stock and exhibiting the medicine (banned one) in the shop”. Neither section 8 nor section 16 contains the quoted expression. Penal statute must be strictly construed and a court in order to punish an accused must not introduce any expression which has not been used by the makers of the law. The impugned order must therefore be struck down.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Dr. Golam Rahman Vs. State 42 DLR 493.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 23—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Instead of holding the trial before the Drug Court it was held before the wrong forum of Special Tribunal which is no trial in the eye of law. The order of conviction and sentence is therefore set aside and the case is sent back to the Drug Court for fresh cognizance and trial.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Shahidullah , 2. Jane Alam Vs. State 45 DLR 640.</em></span></div></div></div>
16	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">DRUGS (CONTROL) ORDINANCE, 1982</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  42 DLR 493, 45 DLR 640.</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1982</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  DRUGS</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-01-13</p><!DOCTYPE html><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: center;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 16px;"> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;">Drugs (Control) Ordinance, 1982</u></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;">[VIII of 1982]</u></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> </span></div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Sections 8 and 16—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Interpretation of Statutes—The order of the appellants’ conviction by the Judge of Drug Court is based on his finding of “keeping in stock and exhibiting the medicine (banned one) in the shop”. Neither section 8 nor section 16 contains the quoted expression. Penal statute must be strictly construed and a court in order to punish an accused must not introduce any expression which has not been used by the makers of the law. The impugned order must therefore be struck down.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Dr. Golam Rahman Vs. State 42 DLR 493.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 23—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Instead of holding the trial before the Drug Court it was held before the wrong forum of Special Tribunal which is no trial in the eye of law. The order of conviction and sentence is therefore set aside and the case is sent back to the Drug Court for fresh cognizance and trial.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Shahidullah , 2. Jane Alam Vs. State 45 DLR 640.</em></span></div></div></div>
17	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">DRUGS (CONTROL) ORDINANCE, 1982</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  42 DLR 493, 45 DLR 640.</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1982</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  DRUGS</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-01-13</p><!DOCTYPE html><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: center;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 16px;"> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;">Drugs (Control) Ordinance, 1982</u></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;">[VIII of 1982]</u></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> </span></div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Sections 8 and 16—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Interpretation of Statutes—The order of the appellants’ conviction by the Judge of Drug Court is based on his finding of “keeping in stock and exhibiting the medicine (banned one) in the shop”. Neither section 8 nor section 16 contains the quoted expression. Penal statute must be strictly construed and a court in order to punish an accused must not introduce any expression which has not been used by the makers of the law. The impugned order must therefore be struck down.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Dr. Golam Rahman Vs. State 42 DLR 493.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 23—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Instead of holding the trial before the Drug Court it was held before the wrong forum of Special Tribunal which is no trial in the eye of law. The order of conviction and sentence is therefore set aside and the case is sent back to the Drug Court for fresh cognizance and trial.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Shahidullah , 2. Jane Alam Vs. State 45 DLR 640.</em></span></div></div></div>

<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  42 DLR 493, 45 DLR 640.</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1982</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  DRUGS</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-01-13</p><!DOCTYPE html><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: center;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 16px;"> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;">Drugs (Control) Ordinance, 1982</u></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;">[VIII of 1982]</u></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> </span></div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Sections 8 and 16—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Interpretation of Statutes—The order of the appellants’ conviction by the Judge of Drug Court is based on his finding of “keeping in stock and exhibiting the medicine (banned one) in the shop”. Neither section 8 nor section 16 contains the quoted expression. Penal statute must be strictly construed and a court in order to punish an accused must not introduce any expression which has not been used by the makers of the law. The impugned order must therefore be struck down.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Dr. Golam Rahman Vs. State 42 DLR 493.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 23—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Instead of holding the trial before the Drug Court it was held before the wrong forum of Special Tribunal which is no trial in the eye of law. The order of conviction and sentence is therefore set aside and the case is sent back to the Drug Court for fresh cognizance and trial.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Shahidullah , 2. Jane Alam Vs. State 45 DLR 640.</em></span></div></div></div>

Name="Colorful Grid Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="60" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light Shading Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="61" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light List Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="62" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light Grid Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="63" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Shading 1 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="64" SemiHidden="false" Name="Medium Grid 1 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="68" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 2 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="69" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 3 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="70" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Dark List Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="71" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Colorful Shading Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="72" SemiHidden="false" UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Intense Emphasis"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="31" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Subtle Reference"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="32" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Intense Reference"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="33" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Book Title"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="37" Name="Bibliography"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="39" QFormat="true" Name="TOC Heading"/> </w:LatentStyles></xml><![endif]--><!-- [if gte mso 10]><style> /* Style Definitions */ table.MsoNormalTable	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;	mso-style-noshow:yes;	mso-style-priority:99;	mso-style-qformat:yes;	mso-style-parent:"";	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;	mso-para-margin:0in;	mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;	font-size:11.0pt;	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";	mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;	mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast;	mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;	mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;}</style><![endif]--></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 4.3pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">The Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, Suit for partition</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">The appellate court though affirmed the sahams allotted by the trial court to the plaintiffs and the defendant No.30 but disapproved the saham allotted to the defendant No.31 and allotted a separate saham of 1.44 acres of land to the de­fendant Nos.l0,14 to 20 and another separate saham of .701/2 acre of land to the defendant No.21 out of Plot No.605 accepting the case of the defendant Nos. 10,14-20 and 21. </span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Abdul Halim vs.</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.9pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">­</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Section 115</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Since both the trial court as well as the appellate court below on consideration of the deposition of the P.Ws. and D.Ws. found that the plaintiff was able to prove his exclusive possession in the suit land the plaintiff was entitled to get the decree as prayed for and that since there was no allegation in the revisional application regarding any misreading or non-consideration of the materials or evidence on record there was no reason for interference by the revisional court. <em>Assistant Horticulturist Agriculture Ex­tension vs. M. A. Sattar Bhuiyan (Naz­mun Ara Sultana J)(Civil) 9 ADC 644.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Order VI, rule 17</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">On 16.05.2006, the petitioners filed an application under Order VI Rule 17 of the Code of Civil Procedure before the learned Senior Assistant Judge, First Court, Bogra for amendment of the plaint. They stated, inter alia, that owing to inadvertence some important facts have not been incorporated in the plaint. Not only correction of the description of the names of some of the plaintiffs is necessary but- striking out the name of plaintiff No.61 is also essential. <em>Md. Akram AH Pk. vs. Md. Yasin Ali (Syed Mahmud Hossain J) (Civil) 9 ADC 703</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Section 107</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Section 151</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">On 23.4.2005 in Title Appeal No. 180 of 2002 the plaintiff-appellants filed an application under Order XXIII Rule 1 (2) along with Section 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure for withdrawing the appeal and instituting a fresh suit; that after hearing both the parties and perus­ing the application the learned Addi­tional District Judge, 1st Court, Kushtia rejected the same by his order dated 26.4.2005 vide Order No.41 upon find­ing that the application does not dis­close what the formal defects were. <em>Md. Mokbul Hossain vs. Md. Molier Rah­man (Muhammad Imman Ali J)(Civil) <span style="letter-spacing: 1.5pt;">9ADC</span> 413</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">The trial Court after consideration of the evidence on record and upon comparing the signatures of Abdul Wazed appear­ing in the deed of agreement with other admitted signatures came to the conclu­sion that the signatures appearing in the deed with his admitted signatures tally with each other and that he executed the agreement upon receipt of the advance money. <em>Dream Land Properties vs. Hazi Abdul Wazed (S.K. Sinha <span style="letter-spacing: 1.5pt;">J)</span> (Civil) 9 ADC <span style="letter-spacing: 1.5pt;">667</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: 1.5pt;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Section 151</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">For declaration of title to the suit land and confirmation of possession therein alleging, inter alia, that the plaintiffs ac­quired title to the suit land on the basis of settlement from the landlord. <em>The People's Republic vs. Abdul Matin Sarder (S.K. Sin ha J) (Civil) 8 ADC 479</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 7.45pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Rules 30, 31</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-right: 1.45pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.65pt 1.45pt .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">This Division, after hearing, dismissed the petition for condonation of delay on 14.07.2008, by the following order : "The leave petition is hopelessly in or­dinate delay of 5991 days. Explanation offered seeking condonation of delay is far from satisfactory. Accordingly, the petition for leave to appeal is dismissed being barred by limitation." </span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Advocate Alauddin Khan vs. Government of the People's (A.B.M. Khairul Haque <span style="letter-spacing: 1.5pt;">J) </span>(Civil) 8 ADC 114</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 4.8pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Section 115</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.9pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">We have considered the submissions of the learned Advocate for the petitioners, the impugned judgment and the materi­als on record. Having considered the materials on record the High Court Divi­sion found that the Advocate Commis­sioner specified saham allotted to the plaintiffs pursuant to the preliminary de­cree passed in the suit and also on con-sideration of the existing possession of the parties. The High Court Division no­ticed the defendants failed to disclose any facts about any conflict in allotment of saham to the plaintiffs. </span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Safiur Rah­man vs. Nazir Ahmed (Sved Mahmud Hossain J) (Civil) 10 ADC 238</span></em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> The learned Advocate for the peti­tioner submits that the courts below failed to consider that the predecessors of the plaintiff petitioners and the de­fendant respondents are step brothers and they have been enjoying the prop­erty according to ' Wasiatnama' and by amicable partition. But the defendant respondents attempted to dispossess the plaintiff petitioners from the prop­erty which they were enjoying since life time of their father and a result the petitioners were constrained to file the suit for permanent injunction, with a prayer for temporary injunction which the courts below rejected on miscon­ception and the High Court Division without considering this aspect dis­charged the rule occasioning failure of justice. </span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Md. Mizanur Rahman vs. <span style="letter-spacing: 1.5pt;">Al-</span>haj Md. Riazul Islam (Md. Shamsul ITuda J) (Civil) 10 ADC 999</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: .1in; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Section 115</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.9pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Short facts necessary for disposal of this</span><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">petition for leave to appeal are that the<br/>petitioner as plaintiff filed Artha Rin Case No. 18 of 2004 in the Court of<br/>Joint District Judge, Second Court, Ra-jbari against the predecessors of the<br/>present respondents for realization of asum of TK. 15,03,77.00 as on<br/>22.04.2004 on the averments, inter-alia, that the predecessors of the respondents,<br/>namely, Kalipada Saha, and Brojendra Nath Saha, had a business house under<br/>the name and style M/S. Kalipada Saha and Brothers and they had transactions<br/>with the plaintiff-bank from the year 1983. <em>Agrani Bank Limited vs. M/S.<br/>Kalipada Saha (Md. Abdul WahhabMiah J)(CiviI) 8 ADC.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.9pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.9pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">The Code of Civil Procedure for ad­dition of party , Order I rule 10(2)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">It appears from the record that in the in­stant case though the petitioners have not enclosed the application under Order I rule 10(2) of Code of Civil Pro­cedure in course of hearing of the Rule the learned Advocate for the petitioners have frankly conceded that the 3rd party applicants are claiming title on the basis of registered deeds from the defendant No 12-14 and that their deeds are prior to the date of execution of plaintiffs. <em>Noor Jahan Begum vs. Golam Mostafa (Mohammad Fazlul Karim J) (Civil) 6 ADC 558</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Order VII, Rule 11</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA;">The plaintiff-respondent Nos. 1 -6 Hied a written objection against the application<br/>for rejection of plaint stating, intcralia, that the title of the petitioner was still<br style="mso-special-character: line-break;"/><br style="mso-special-character: line-break;"/></span></p></div></div>
24	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">CONSTITUTION OF PAKISTAN, 1962</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  40 DLR (AD) 178,40 DLR (AD) 178</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1962</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  CONSTITUTION OF PAKISTAN</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-01-09</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: center;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 16px;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;">Constitution of Pakistan, 1962</u></span></span></div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Article 98 read with Constitution of Bangladesh, Article 102—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>since 1962 prerogative writs were omitted and the constitutional jurisdiction to issue necessary orders on an application was conferred on the High Court (Division) in its own terms.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Radical difference in language between Article 170 of 1956 Pakistan Constitution and Article 98 of 1962 Pakistan Constitution in respect of the jurisdiction conferred on the High Courts.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Sajeda Parvin Vs. Government of Bangladesh 40 DLR (AD) 178.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Article 98(2)(b) read with Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972 Article 102(2)(b)(i)—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>The language of Article 98 of 1962 Pakistan Constitution which has been imported into Article 102 of Bangladesh Constitution of 1972 has been couched in such a manner which is untrammeled by the formalities or technicalities of either section 491 of the Code of Criminal Procedure or the old prerogative writ of Habeas Corpus. Ref. 21 DLR (SC) 1(11).<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Sajeda Parvin Vs. Government of Bangladesh 40 DLR (AD) 178.</em></span></div></div></div>
25	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">CONSTITUTION OF PAKISTAN, 1962</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  40 DLR (AD) 178,40 DLR (AD) 178</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1962</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  CONSTITUTION OF PAKISTAN</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-01-09</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: center;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 16px;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;">Constitution of Pakistan, 1962</u></span></span></div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Article 98 read with Constitution of Bangladesh, Article 102—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>since 1962 prerogative writs were omitted and the constitutional jurisdiction to issue necessary orders on an application was conferred on the High Court (Division) in its own terms.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Radical difference in language between Article 170 of 1956 Pakistan Constitution and Article 98 of 1962 Pakistan Constitution in respect of the jurisdiction conferred on the High Courts.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Sajeda Parvin Vs. Government of Bangladesh 40 DLR (AD) 178.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Article 98(2)(b) read with Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972 Article 102(2)(b)(i)—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>The language of Article 98 of 1962 Pakistan Constitution which has been imported into Article 102 of Bangladesh Constitution of 1972 has been couched in such a manner which is untrammeled by the formalities or technicalities of either section 491 of the Code of Criminal Procedure or the old prerogative writ of Habeas Corpus. Ref. 21 DLR (SC) 1(11).<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Sajeda Parvin Vs. Government of Bangladesh 40 DLR (AD) 178.</em></span></div></div></div>

29	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">The Code of Civil Procedure, 1908</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  9 ADC 656, 9 ADC 185, 9 ADC 1009, 8 ADC 457, 9 ADC 363, 9 ADC 271, 8 ADC 454, 8 ADC 869, 9 ADC 242, 9 ADC 400, 8 ADC 993, 8 ADC 739, 9 ADC 294, 9 ADC 377, 10 ADC 112, 10 ADC 961, 10 ADC 967, 10 ADC 991, 10 ADC 993, 8 ADC 421, 8 ADC 502, 8 ADC 596, 8 ADC </p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Civil Procedure</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b> <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="39" QFormat="true" Name="TOC Heading"/> </w:LatentStyles></xml><![endif]--><!-- [if gte mso 10]><style> /* Style Definitions */ table.MsoNormalTable	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;	mso-style-noshow:yes;	mso-style-priority:99;	mso-style-qformat:yes;	mso-style-parent:"";	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;	mso-para-margin:0in;	mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;	font-size:11.0pt;	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";	mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;	mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast;	mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;	mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;}</style><![endif]--></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 5.3pt 1.2pt .0001pt 0in;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">The Code of Civil Procedure, 1908</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">During the pendency of the suit, the plaintiffs-respondents filed an applica­tion under Order-XL Rule 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure for appointment of receiver in respect of the suit land alleg-</span> <span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">ing that the plaintiffs-respondents are entitled to 91 bighas of land and, on the other hand, the defendants-petitioners and others are entitled to 182 bighas of land. <em>Most. Umme Shaheda Akhter Rina vs. Ayub AH (Sved Mahmud Hossain J) (Civil) 9 ADC 656</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 8.15pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Order XXI, rule 90</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-right: 1.45pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.4pt 1.45pt .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">The respondent No.l Arab Bangladesh Bank Limited, as plaintiff, instituted Title Suit No. 134 of 1995 before the Artha Rin Adalat No.2, Dhaka against the defendant Nos. 1 to 5 for realization of outstanding loan. That suit was sub­sequently renumbered as Title Suit No. 143 of 1998. The suit was ultimately decreed ex-parte vide judgment and de­cree dated 25.11.1998. Since the judg­ment debtor failed to pay the decretal amount within the prescribed time the decree holder bank put that decree into execution in Title Execution Case No.99 of 2000. </span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Mrs. Jahanara Ahmed vs. Arab Bangladesh Bank Ltd (Nazmun <span style="letter-spacing: -1.0pt;">Ara</span> Sultana J)(Civil) 9 ADC 185.</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.4pt 1.45pt .0001pt 0in;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Section 115</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="Style3" style="margin-top: 2.9pt;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">As it appears the High Court Division discharged the Rule holding that the contents of Annexures A, C, C-l of the revisional application, the applications filed by the defendant No.l / petitioner as well as the contents of impugned order show that the petitioner filed the above applications on the grounds that Mr. Md.</span><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> Abdul Noor Bhuiyan Bablu. the learned Advocate Commissioner, while recording the deposition of the re- • spondent No. 1 in cross-examination did not wear the formal dress and rather he had been wearing a T shirt and due to such wearing of T shirt by the learned Advocate Commissioner, the decorum of the Court or the person involved with the activities of the Court, had not been maintained properly and as such the said learned Advocate Commissioner is not competent to perform the duty as an Advocate Commissioner and the learned Advocate of the petitioner also filed an application before the Advocate Commissioner by mentioning his dress but the copy of the said application has not been annexed with the revisional ap­plication but however the learned advo­cate of the respondent No. 1 handed over the same to the Court and the contents of the same, Annexure A, C and C-1 and the impugned order does not disclose any cause of grievance and since there is no Code of dress for any Advocate Commissioner, at the time of perform­ing his duty as commissioner, an Advo­cate Commissioner is not bound to wear the dress which he wears in the Court room and the records also show that the learned Advocate of the petitioner mis­behaved with the learned Advocate Commissioner in a manner which is not in accordance with the professional eti­quette of the learned members of the Bar and further the impugned order has</span> <span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">not occasioned any failure of justice for which the petitioner can move this Divi­sion under section 115(1) of the Code of Civil procedure and moreover the dif­ferent steps taken by the petitioner in the trial courts as well as this revisional application show that he adopted a pol­icy for dragging the suit for long time and that the instant suit was filed in the year 1978 and now it is 2008 and even after expiry of 30 years the recording of the depositions of the parties could not be completed for such dilatory tactics and further the Rule was obtained by the petitioner in the year 2003 but he never took any initiative to get the Rule heard, rather the respondent No.l took initia­tive for hearing of the Rule. <em>Shainsud-din Mollah vs. Jamila Khatoon (Md. Tafazzul Islam J) (Civil) 9 ADC 1009</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 4.8pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Section 115 and order XVII, rule 14</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-right: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.4pt 2.4pt .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">It appears that the opposite party insti­tuted a suit showing valuation of TK.71,000.00 and subsequently, by amendment raised the valuation to the tune of TK.60(sixty) lacs. It appears that the trial Court allowed other prayer of amendment. It appears that the defen­dants filed an application under Order XVII rule 14 of the Code of Civil Pro­cedure before the trial Court and the trial Court while allowing the amend­ment rejected the said application by the said impugned order. </span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">M. A. Razzaque. vs. Syed Mainul Hag (Mohammad Fa-zlulKarim CJ)(Civil) 8 ADC 457</span></em></p><p class="Style3" style="margin-top: 2.9pt; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-pagination: widow-orphan;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Order 37, rule 2</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">We have heard the petitioner Ms. Yas-min Banu appearing in person. The pe­titioner has made submission to the effect that her claim of legal fees made in the plaint of summary suit was based on an impliedly fixed amount and there­fore the summary suit under Order 37 Rule 2 of the Code of Civil Procedure was maintainable. Referring to Section 128(2)(f)(i) of the Code of Civil Proce­dure the learned Advocate has argued also that this provision of law tells that where the claim of the plaintiff payable by the defendant is fixed summary suit is maintainable. <em>Yasmin Banu vs. M. A. Mannan Chairman (Nazmun Ara Sul­tana J) (Civil) 9 ADC 363</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 5.05pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Order 47, Rule 1</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-right: .95pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">From the order-sheet of the execution case, we noticed that the petitioner did not raise the jurisdiction or the authority of the presiding officer of the Artha Rin Adalat to sell the mortgaged property in accordance with section 33 of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain at any point of time rather he had surrendered to the juris­diction of the Adalat and prayed for staying further proceedings of the exe­cution case on different grounds. There­fore, we find no substance as regards the question of jurisdiction raised by the learned counsel. </span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Md. Saidur Rahman vs</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Order 7, rule 11</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; tab-stops: dotted 151.9pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">However, from the above discussions it is evident that the High Court Division<br/>committed no wrong in allowing the de-fendants' application under Order 7<br/>Rule 11 of the Code of Civil Procedure for rejection of the plaint of Title Suit<br/>No.42 of 1999 of the 5th Court of Sub-ordinate Judge, Dhaka. The parties of<br/>this subsequent Title Suit No.42 of 1999 and the parties of earlier Title Suit<br/>No. 177 of 1994, are same, the subject matter of both these suits being-the en-<br/>tire land of C.S. Plot No.371 of C.S. Khatian 4300 'Ja' of Mouza-Shahar<br/>Dhaka, are same and also the issues raised and settled in the earlier suit and<br/>the issues for determination in the sub-sequent suit are same</span><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"><span style="mso-tab-count: 1;">           </span><span style="letter-spacing: .5pt;">(12) </span><em>Abdul Jalil vs. Islami Bank Bangladesh Ltd. (Nazmun Ara Sultana J) (Civil) 9 ADC 271</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 6.0pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Order I rule 10</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Whether the High Court Division was in error in nullifying the proceeding conducted by the Additional District Judge, inasmuch as the law does not say that trial by an Additional District Judge who was entrusted with the trial of Artha Rin Suit would be invalid be­cause of this lacuna. </span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">One Bank Limited</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: .25pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Order IX, Rule 13</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Filed for restoration of Title Suit No. 103 of 1989 after setting aside the cx-parte judgment and decree dated 7.5.1997. <em>Ijarder Mansur Ahmed vs. Sheikh Musaraf Hossain (Shah Abu Nayeem Mominur Rahman J)(Civil) 8 ADC 454.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Order VII, rule 11</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="Style3" style="margin-top: .25pt; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-pagination: widow-orphan;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">The instant suit was filed on 14.08.1996 and the defendants who filed the appli­cation for dismissal of the suit, filed written statement to contest the suit. Thereafter, issues were framed by the learned Joint District Judge and the suit being ready was fixed for peremptory hearing. At that stage on 26.06.2005 i.e. after about 9(nine) years from the date of filing of the suit the defendants filed the application for dismissal of the suit on the ground of its maintainability. In the application it was contended, inter-alia, that in the plaint the plaintiffs claimed that plaintiff No. 1 is a private limited company and its Managing Di­rector, Mr. Sirajul Islam Khan died leav­ing behind a son, 2(two) wives and one daughter, i.e. plaintiff Nos.2 and 3 and defendant Nos.5 and 6 respectively and plaintiff No.2 claimed himself to be the director of plaintiff No. 1 company. In<span style="letter-spacing: .5pt;"> order to become a director one must be the owner of minimum 5000 shares in the company and on the death of Sirajul Islam Khan none of his heirs became the owner of 5000 shares, so none of them is fit to be the director and in fact none became the director. As per article 14 of the Articles of Association an heir of a deceased share-holder can become a share-holder only when the Company approves the same but the heirs of de­ceased Sirajul Islam Khan were never approved by the Company. Plaintiff Nos.2 and 3 are not competent to be the director of the company and they had no interest in the property of the Company; the persons who got kabala from plain­tiff Nos.2 and 3 were not entitled to be impleaded in the suit. Although the suit was filed on behalf of the company for redemption of the mortgaged property, the plaint was not signed by any one on behalf of the company duly authorized in that respect. Although plaintiff No.3, Syeda Sultana signed the plaint as Di­rector of the company, she was never Director of the company as per the Ar­ticles of Association of the Company. So, the suit filed by the company was not maintainable. <em>Salahuddin Khan vs. Md. Abdul Hai Bahar (Md. Abdul Wah-hab Mi ah </em></span><em><span style="letter-spacing: 2.0pt;">J)</span><span style="letter-spacing: .5pt;"> (Civil) 8 ADC 869.</span></em></span></p><p class="Style3" style="margin-top: .25pt; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-pagination: widow-orphan;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 8.15pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: 1.0pt;">Order XLI, rule 31</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="Style3" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; mso-pagination: widow-orphan;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">The plaintiffs' claim is that the land de­scribed in the first schedule land along with other lands measuring .69 acre originally belonged to Abdur Rahim. By a registered deed dated 22.03.1972, the defendant No.l Sayedullah and his" brother Saif Ullah purchased the said land which was jointly possessed by them. On 09.11.1985 the land was par­titioned and as a result each brother got .3412 acre of land. On 10.11.1985 Saif Ullah executed a bainapatra in favour of the plaintiffs in respect of. 1534 acre of land and by four registered deeds dated 14.11.1985, 16.11.1985 and 07.01.1986 transferred the land and delivered pos­session thereof. <em>Md. Masuk Miah vs. Md. Fovzur Rahman (Muhammad human AH J) (Civil) 9 ADC 242</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 8.4pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: 1.0pt;">Order XXXIX, Rule 1 and 2</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">The facts of the case, in short, are that in pursuance of an agreement dated 18.7.2001, the plaintiff -respondent en­tered into the suit-shop owned by the defendant-respondent as a monthly ten­ant*. But inspite of receipt of advance from the plaintiff, the defendant was trying to let out the suit-shop premises to a third party, as such, the plaintiff filed a suit being Title Suit No. 14 of 2005 in the Court of Senior Assistant Judge, Barisal, praying for inter alia, for a decree that the defendant be restrained by an order of permanent injunction not to let out the shop premises in favour of anybody else during the period of the agreement between them. <em>Sk. Md. Del-</em></span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> ware Hossain vs. Md. Shahajan Miah(A.B.M. Khairul Hague J)(Civil) 8 ADC 938</span></em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> and so the same should be rejected. </span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Hozizur Rahman vs. Abu Bakar Choxvcl-hury (Nazmun Ara Sultana J) (Civil) 9 ADC 400</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Order XXXIX, rule 1 and 2</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">The facts leading to the filing of this pe­tition, in short, are that the petitioners filed a suit for partition being Partition Suit No.45 of 2008 in the Court of the Joint District Judge, First Court, Bogra, and also filed a petition under Order XXXIX Rules 1 and 2 of the Code of Civil Procedure, praying for injunction against the defendant No.7, the respon­dent No. 1 herein, restraining him from proceeding with the construction work in the suit plot. The learned Joint Dis­trict Judge after hearing the petition passed an order to maintain status-quo in respect of possession of the suit prop­erty till disposal of the suit. On appeal, the said order was affirmed. </span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Mst. Setara Beugm vs. Md. Rafiqul Alam Tipu (A.B.M. Khairul Haque J) (Civil) 8 ADC 993</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Section 10</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">The plaintiffs contested the said appli­cation for rejection of the plaint by fil­ing written objection contending that the subject matter, parties and the relief sought for in the said Title Suit No. 156 of 1966 and those of the present suit were not same; that the application for rejection of plaint was misconceived</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Section 107</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">On conclusion of hearing of the suit the trial Court by its judgment and decree dated 29.08.2007 decreed the suit. Against the judgment and decree of the trial Court, the </span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">contesting defendants </span></em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">filed Title Appeal No.5 of 2002 before the District Judge, Patuakhali.
