The learned Joint District, 2nd Court, Patu­akhali who heard the appeal by his judg­ment and decree dated 10.04.2003 allowed the appeal and dismissed the suit. Being aggrieved by the judgment and decree of the appellate Court the plaintiff filed Civil Revision No.3306 of 2003 before the High Court Division. </span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Noni Gopal Das vs. Dinesh Chandra Das (Md. Abdul Wahhab Miah J)(Civil) 8 ADC 739.</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Section 107</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="Style2" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-pagination: widow-orphan;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">Mr. Abdul Motin Khashru has argued that the High Court Division has com­mitted wrong in setting aside the judg­ment of the lower appellate court and thereby restoring the judgment of the trial court without taking into consider­ation at all the fact that in this suit for partition the plaintiffs did not at all give any account as to how the recorded ten­<span style="letter-spacing: .5pt;"> ants got the suit property and how they acquired the specific quantum of land as stated in the plaint; that though in the plaint it has been stated that each of the five recorded tenants has .28 acre of land in the divisible property but no where in the plaint or in the deposition it has been stated as to how all the recorded tenants acquired this particular quantum of land. </span><em>Md. Muhibur Rah­man Muyeeb vs. Md. Meher AH (Naz-mun Ara Sultana J)(Civil) 9 ADC 294</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 4.8pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Section 115</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">It has already been stated above that the original partition suit was decreed on contest by the trial court by the judg­ment and order dated 31.10.1996 allot­ting a separate saham for 2.37 acres of land out of total 18.86 acres of divisible land to the plaintiffs. </span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Sona Miah vs. Abed Ali (Nazmun Ara Sultana J)(Civil) 9 ADC 377</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Section 115</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">The learned advocate appearing for the petitioners did not press the rules on merit and concede that the amount of compensation re-assessed by the arbi­trator was adequate and pray for a direc­tion to pay the balance consideration amount assessed by the arbitrator expe­ditiously. <em>Abu Taker vs. Government of Bangladesh (S.K. Sinha J)(Civil) 9 ADC</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 4.8pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Section 115</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">It appears that the High Court Division rightly found that exparte decree passed in favour of the defendant-respondent No.l in Title Suit No.291 of 1985 was maintained up to the Appellate Division in Civil Appeal No.361 of 2002. So he should not be deprived of enjoying the benefit of the said decree. The High Court Divi sion are of the view that if the proceedings of the execution case in question is somehow blocked either in the form of injunction or stay the decree which the defendant-respondent No. 1 ob­tained on 26.04.1989 shall be made nu­gatory and that will definitely shake the faith and confidence of the litigant people injudicial system of the country. </span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Most. Shahida Khanam vs. K.M. Zahurul Hoque (Md. Muzammel Hossain J)(Civil) 10 ADC 112.</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Section 115</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">When the matter was taken up for hear-ing we noted that the order impugned in this appeal is an interim order dated 01.08.2000. The petitioner had chal­lenged art order dated 14.11.99 passed in Miscellaneous Appeal No. 141 of 1999 claiming that the order was tanta­mount to rejection of the prayer for con­stituting a neutral committee for performing the regular administration and function of the Ershad Ali Waqf Es­tate, Chttagong. While issuing the Rule the High Court Division directed the op­posite party No.8, the Waqf Administra­tor to constitute an official mutwalli to perform the regular administration of the Waqf Estate. <em>Anwarul Islam Khan vs. Ali Mahbub Khan (Muhammad Imman Ali J)(Civil) 10 ADC 961</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 5.3pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Section 115</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.9pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">From the pleadings of the contesting parties, the prayer for saham of the de­fendants as stated hereinbefore and from the judgment and decree of two Courts below, it appears that the main controversy in the suit was as to the claim of defendant Nos. 1 -5 in respect of .66 acre and .62 acre of land which were allegedly purchased by defendant No. 1 by two kabalas being No.5362 dated 10.04.1967 and No.2143 dated 08.02.1965 marked as exhibits-'Ka' and 'Kha'. From the judgment and decree of the trial Court, it appears that it did not accept the said case of defendant Nos. 1-5 as to their claim to 1 28 acres of land on the specific finding that the ka­balas by which they, claimed to have purchased those area of land were cre­ated, fictitious and ineffective (in Ben­gali it has been written as</span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> Monsur Rahman Mondal vs. Hasanuzzaman Mandal (Md. Abdul WahhabMiahJ) (Civil) 10 ADC 967.</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.9pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 5.3pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Section 115</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">It appears from the judgment and order that on consideration of the ma­terials on record the High Court Divi­sion found the plaintiff's title in the suit land but held that the plaintiff pur­chased the suit land from a plot hav­ing 1.43 acres of land and she did not give description of the land giving sketch map in the schedule of the plaint, so it is difficult to find out the exact position of the suit land. Since the plaintiff and contesting defendant purchased the land from the succes­sive heirs of Ismail Hossain and the suit land is a portion of a big plot hav­ing 1.43 acres of land, we are of the view that the High Court Division rightly held that the proper remedy of the petitioner is lying in a suit for par­tition. It is relevant here to observe that the High Court Division found the title of the plaintiff in the suit land and the contesting defendant did not raise any objection against such find­ing in the higher forum. </span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Mosammat Shahida Alam vs. Mosammat Hasina Akhter (Hasan Foez Siddique <span style="letter-spacing: 2.0pt;">J)</span> (Civil) 10 ADC 991</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: .1in; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Section 115</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="Style1" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-pagination: widow-orphan;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: .5pt;">In view of the submissions of the learned Counsel of the respectiveparty and the nature of the impugned order, the only question to be decided </span><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">in this leave petition is as to whether </span></strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: .5pt;">the, High Court Division was correct in its approach in disposing of the re­vision application filed under section 115(1) of the Code summarily without issuing any Rule and thus giving no chance of hearing to the other side, namely, the defendant-petitioners herein and the other defendants who were made opposite parties in the re­vision application to place their ver­sion of the case on the question of the order of stay passed by the learned District Judge. The question is not a new one and was raised earlier many a times before this Division and each time, this Division disapproved the disposal of revision application sum­marily by the High Court Division giving full relief to the petitioner with­out issuing any Rule upon the other side(s). This Division in unequivocal language held that though section 115 of the Code does not speak about service of notice on the opposite party, the revisional Court cannot interfere with the decision of the Court below without giving to the other side(s) an opportunity of being heard. It has also been held by this Division that Rule must be issued against all parties who would be affected in case of interfer­ence. This is so even when the High Court Division acts suo motu. The cases are Danish" Abu v. Sakina, 4 BLC(AD) 68; Moslema Khatun v. Ishaque, 42 DLR(AD) 72; Ali Ahmed v. M.A. Haque, 1983 BLD(AD)193; Faruk v. Nurul Azim, 1983 BLD(AD) </span><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">196; A</span></strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: .5pt;">.H. <strong><em>Chowdhury v. </em></strong></span><strong><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: 2.5pt;">M.</span></em></strong> <span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Hossain, 1984 BCR(AD) 532; Abdul Wahab v. Ali Ahmed, 1992 BLD(AD) 64; Fa-zlur Rahman v. Rajab Ali, 30 DLR(AD) 30; Dijendra Lai v. Abu Zafar30 DLR(AD)74; Shamsul Are-fin v. Kazal Mia, 49 DLR(AD) 175; Jabbar Jute Mills v. Abul Kashme, 10 MILR(AD) 301; Sukumar Sen v. Gouranga, 1989 BLD(AD) 162; Kar-naphuli Cotton Mills v. UCBL, 49 DLR(AD) 130 and Md. Hossain v. Dildar Begum, 9MLR(AD)361. But unfortunately, we are coming across number of cases including the instant one where the 'learned Judges of the High Court Division have been dis­posing of revision applications sum­marily giving full relief to the petitioner without issuing any Rule completely ignoring the said princi­ples of law declared by this Division. It' seems that the' concerned learned Judges are not aware of article 111 of the Constitution of the People's Re­public of Bangladesh which has man­dated that the law declared by this Division shall be binding on the High</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; tab-stops: dotted 118.55pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Court Division</span><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"><span style="mso-tab-count: 1 dotted;">............ </span><span style="letter-spacing: .5pt;">(9)</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; tab-stops: dotted 118.55pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p><p class="Style3" style="line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-pagination: widow-orphan;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">In view of the above, the order passed by the High Court Division complained of in this petition cannot be sustained and must be set aside But since we have heard the learned Counsel of both par­ties and, the question involved in this leave petition is, well settled by this Di­vision, we do not consider it necessary to grant leave, because that would cause delay' of the disposal of the mis­cellaneous appeal pending before the District Judge. However, we reiterate the statement of law that summary dis­posal of a revision application filed under section 115 of the Code giving full relief to the petitioner without issu­ing Rule and thus giving no opportunity to the other side(s) of being heard is not permissible. We strongly disapprove and deprecate such kind of disposal by the High Court Division. </span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Gulf Air Company GSC vs. Travel Trade Lid. (Mcl. Abdul Wahhab Miah <span style="letter-spacing: 1.5pt;">J)</span> (Civil) 10 ADC 993</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 5.75pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Section 115</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">The High Court Division found that the Trial Court's finding that the plaintiff" could not prove his possession and dis­possession in the suit land appeared to be inconsistent with the material evi­dence on record. </span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Md. Daliluddin vs. Md. Mokarram Hossain (Syed Mahmud HossainJ) (Civil) 8 ADC 421.</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Section 115</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Filed the above pre-emption case under section 24 of the Non Agricultural Ten­ancy Act on the averments that the case land originally belonged to Mojibor and Motizar and in the year 1985 the re­spondent Nos.2-4 purchased the suit land from them and then the respondent</span></p><p class="Style3" style="margin-top: .25pt; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-pagination: widow-orphan;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Nos.3 and 4 while possessing the case land by a registered kabala of the year 1992 sold the 3 decimals of land to him and thus he is</span><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> <span class="FontStyle14"><span style="mso-ansi-font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">a co-sharer by purchaser and the respondent No.2, on 15.4.1998, without any notice to him. </span></span><span class="FontStyle12"><span style="mso-ansi-font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 11.0pt;">Most. Rojika Begum vs. Mohammad AlPSheikh (Md. Tafazzul Islam J) (Civil) 8 ADC 502</span></span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 6.0pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Section 115</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-right: .25pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.4pt .25pt .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">In this case, the only question for deter­mination is whether the kabala deed in question was executed by the defendant No. 1 or not. Admittedly the signatures of the executant appearing in this kabala in question are of the defendant. The de­fendant has admitted in his very plead­ing that the signatures appearing in this kabala in question are his own signa­tures. The defendant, however, has pleaded a case to the effect that the plaintiff obtained these signatures on some blank stamp papers and cartridge papers during execution and registration of two other documents namely a ka­bala deed and a deed of exchange by him in favour of the plaintiff on 13.10.2008 and for filing written objec­tion in a per-emption case and those blank stamp papers and cartridge papers containing his signatures might have been used in creating the kabala in ques­tion. But it appears that the defendant has hopelessly failed to prove this story of taking his signatures on blank stamp papers and cartridge papers by the de­fendant by adducing any iota of evi- dence. <em>Md. Moktad Hossen Majumdar vs. Md. Golam Mostafa Majumdar (Naz-mun Ara Sultana J) (Civil) 8 ADC 596</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.4pt .25pt .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 4.8pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Section 115</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.9pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">The case of the plaintiffs and all the contesting defendants have been nar­rated elaborately in the judgments of courts of fact and as such we do not re­quire to narrate the same in details again in this judgment. Plaintiffs short case is that the land in suit originally belonged to Golam Ali. Golam Ali died leaving his 2nd wife Shukhi Bibi and 3 daugh­ters. Golam Ali's son Baksha prede­ceased his father leaving 2 daughters. </span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Rahima Khatun vs. Md. Habibur Rah­man (Nazmun Ara Sultana <span style="letter-spacing: 1.5pt;">J)</span> (Civil) 8 ADC 777</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 4.8pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Section 115</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.9pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Admittedly the suit land appertained to taluk No.6344 which belonged to Maimuna Khatun. It is also admitted that Maimuna Khatun was in khas pos­session of the suit land. The plaintiffs case is that the suit land was put in auc­tion for arrears of rent and one Md. Ishaque purchased the same in the year 1935 and got possession of the same and subsequently Md. Ishaque sold the suit land to Abdur Rashid by registered deed in the year 1943. The plaintiffs are the heirs of this Abdur Rashid and have inherited the suit land from Abdur</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Rashid. <em>Abdul Mannan Chowdhury vs. Manikkya Lai Dey (Nazmun Ara Sul­tana J) '(Civil) 8 ADC 793.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 4.8pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Section 115</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.9pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Facts relevant for disposal of the appeal are that the appellants (plaintiffs) insti­tuted Title Suit No.45 of 1999 in the Court of Subordinate Judge, Satkhira for specific performance of contract in respect of 3.49 acres of land of Plot No.9879 of S.A. Khatian Nos.2257 and 2292 out of 8.66 acres of land. Plain­tiffs case in short is that the respondent No.l (defendant) entered to a contract for sale of the suit land with the plaintiff on 14th September, 1989 at a consider­ation of Tk. 1,05,000/- and on receipt of advance amount of Tk.60,000/- deliv­ered possession of the same on condi­tion that he would execute and register a sale deed within 13th Jaistha, 1397 B.S. upon receipt of the balance amount of Tk.45,000/-. The plaintiffs offered the balance consideration amount and requested the defendant to execute the sale deed but the latter refused to per­form his part of obligation. </span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Khokan Chandra Mondal vs. Nanda Lai Mridha (S.K. Sin ha J) (Civil) 8 ADC 926</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 5.05pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Section 115</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-right: 1.2pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.65pt 1.2pt .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">The facts in short are that the appellant instituted a suit being Title Suit No. 261 of 1963 in the Third Court of Assistant</span> <span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">dge. Dhaka, on 5.9.1968, praying for "cree for eviction of the defendant as ensee. The suit was decreed ex-parte on 27.2.1975 and thereafter Execution Case No. 14 of 1975 was filed. The de­fendant on 4.3.1975. instituted a miscel-eous case being Miscellaneous Case 54 of 1975 under Order IX rule 13 <sup>:</sup>the Code of Civil Procedure, praying setting aside the aforesaid ex-parte lecree and by an order dated 27.3.1975 e operation of the ex-parte decree was tayed but the appellant inspite of the foresaid order of stay, evicted the de-ndant from the suit property. There-fter, on the application of the fendant, the Court by its order dated .8.1980, directed the appellant to nd over possession of the suit prop-y to the defendant within 24 hours. <em>lilttllah vs. Hasina Begum (A.B.M. airul Hague J)(Civil) 8 ADC<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">    </span>94 7</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.65pt 1.2pt .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p><p class="Style3" style="mso-pagination: widow-orphan; margin: 2.9pt 0in .0001pt 14.15pt;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">trial court decreed the suit allotting parate saham for 4.96 acres of land e plaintiffs. Against that judgment decree of the trial court the contest-defendant Nos. 1 to 3 preferred ap-being Title Appeal No. 109 of 1986 re the District Judge, Jhalakati. The Hate court, after hearing, dismissed appeal affirming the judgment and e of the trial court. Against that ent of the appellate court the con-; defendants preferred Civil Revi-No.3330 of 1991 and obtained Rule. </span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Abdul Aziz vs. Most. Kutisona Bibi (Nazmun Ara Sultana J)(Civil) 9 ADC 190</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 5.75pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Section 115</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">The facts, leading to the filing of this petition, in brief, are that the predeces-sor-in-interest of respondent Nos. 1-6 and respondent No.7 instituted Title Suit No.85 of 2002 for partition on dec­laration of title claiming a saham for 1.45 acres of land described in the schedule to the plaint. The plaintiffs case, in short, is that the suit land origi­nally belonged to Abdul Kader Sarder and Kasiruddin Sarder alias Basir Sarder. The owners died just before the R.S. operation. </span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Abdul Hakim Sarder vs. Ahidul Sarder (Syed Mahmud Hos-sain J) (Civil) 9 ADC 250</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: .05in; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Rules 1 and </span></strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">2, <strong>Section 151</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-right: .25pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.4pt .25pt .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Granting mandatory injunction direct­ing the added defendant Nos.3 and 4-petitioners to deliver possession of Suit Shop No. 19 of Younusco City Center in favour of the proforma respondent Nos.2 and 3. </span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Md. Khorshed Alam vs. Mohammad Ali (Md. Muzammel Hos-sain J) (Civil) 7 ADC 223</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 6.25pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Order 1 Rule 8</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.65pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">The decision taken by No. 4 Digholbak Union Parishad for constructing perma-</span> <span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">nent office of the said union parishad at Nandipur village being legal, valid, bonafide and within jurisdiction is bind­ing on the defendants and the decision taken by defendant Nos.2 and 4 in re­spect of construction of permanent of­fice of the said union parishad at Kamargaon village is illegal. <em>Md. Rus-tom Ullah vs. Md. Zomifuddin (Md. Tafazzul Islam J) (Civil) 7 ADC<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">    </span>541</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.65pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: .1in; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Order 21 Rule 97, 98 and 99</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">The High Court Division rejecting an application for vacating the order of stay passed on 25.08.2005 and the order staying the proceeding of the execution case on 08.04.2006 which was extended lastly on 08.05.2006 by recalled and va­cated and directed the executing Court to proceed with the execution case in accordance with law. </span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Jahanara Begum vs. Badura Begum (Mohammad Fazlul Karim J)(Civil)6 ADC 197</span></em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> clared without lawful authority on the following<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>averments</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p></div></div>
30	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">VILLAGE COURTS ORDINANCE, 1976</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  44 DLR 77.</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1976</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  VILLAGE COURTS</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-01-18</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: center;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 16px;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;">Village Courts Ordinance, 1976<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>(LXI of 1976)</u></span></span></div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 3—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Jurisdiction—When trial by Magistrate and hearing of appeal by the Sessions Judge coram non judice—All cases relating to offences’ specified in Part I of the Schedule to the Ordinance shall be exclusively triable by a village Court and no criminal Court shall have jurisdiction to try any such case. Trial of the accused for offences falling under the schedule by the Magistrate and hearing of the appeal as done by the Sessions Judge are absolutely without jurisdiction. If a court has no jurisdiction to try a case, the question of either submitting to the jurisdiction or raising objection to its jurisdiction would not arise. Parties by their mutual consent can neither confer a jurisdiction which does not exist in law nor can take away a jurisdiction which so exists. Jurisdiction is a question of statute and not of consent.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Dr. Joynal Abedin Vs. State 44 DLR 77.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> </div></div></div>
31	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">VILLAGE COURTS ORDINANCE, 1976</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  44 DLR 77.</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1976</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  VILLAGE COURTS</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-01-18</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: center;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 16px;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;">Village Courts Ordinance, 1976<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>(LXI of 1976)</u></span></span></div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"> <br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Section 3—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Jurisdiction—When trial by Magistrate and hearing of appeal by the Sessions Judge coram non judice—All cases relating to offences’ specified in Part I of the Schedule to the Ordinance shall be exclusively triable by a village Court and no criminal Court shall have jurisdiction to try any such case. Trial of the accused for offences falling under the schedule by the Magistrate and hearing of the appeal as done by the Sessions Judge are absolutely without jurisdiction. If a court has no jurisdiction to try a case, the question of either submitting to the jurisdiction or raising objection to its jurisdiction would not arise. Parties by their mutual consent can neither confer a jurisdiction which does not exist in law nor can take away a jurisdiction which so exists. Jurisdiction is a question of statute and not of consent.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Dr. Joynal Abedin Vs. State 44 DLR 77.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> </div></div></div>
32	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">BANGLADESH SERVICE RULES</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  48 DLR (AD) 40, 49 DLR 298, 51 DLR (AD) 112, 53 DLR (AD) 41, 54 DLR 566.</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1983</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  BANGLADESH SERVICE </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-01-28</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1.5em; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: center;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #000000;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;">Bangladesh Service Rule</u></span></span></p><p style="box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1.5em; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Rule 5(57)-</span></p><p style="box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1.5em; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;">"Traveling allowance"-It varies upon the circumstances of each journey undertaken by an employee.</p><p style="box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1.5em; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Government of People's Republic of Bangladesh represented by the Secretary Ministry of Labour and Manpower. </em></p><p style="box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1.5em; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"><em><strong>Bangladesh Secretariat Dhaka vs Hasan Movies Ltd and others 48 DLR (AD) 40.</strong></em></p><p style="box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1.5em; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Rule 21-</span></p><p style="box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1.5em; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;">A vested right was created in favour of the petitioner to the post of Director General of Bangladesh Shilpakala Academy and such a right cannot be taken away by cancelling his contractual service as Principal of Music College as he joined the College keeping his lien to his service as the Director General. Since his lien was kept intact and it was never cancelled, he ought to have been allowed to join his former post as Director General of Bangladesh Shilpakala Academy.</p><p style="box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1.5em; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Azad Rahman vs Government of the People's Republic of Bangladesh and others 49 DLR 298.</em></span></p><p style="box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1.5em; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Rule 24(1)-</span></p><p style="box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1.5em; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;">lf Class III and Class IV employees have been exempted from operation of rule 24(1) then it is an improvement in their general condition of service. If any authority violates this improved condition of service then it is a clear violation of the general conditions of service of that employee.</p><p style="box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1.5em; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Government of Bangladesh and Ors vs Mohammad Faruque 51 DLR (AD) 112.</em></span></p><p style="box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1.5em; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Rule 72(b)-</span></p><p style="box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1.5em; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;">The review forum having found the respondent honourably acquitted the Tribunals below rightly held that the respondent is entitled to the arrear pay and allowances.</p><p style="box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1.5em; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Secretary, Ministry bf Establishment vs AM Nurunnabi 53 DLR (AD) 41.</em></span></p><p style="box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1.5em; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: center;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #000000;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;">Bangladesh Service Rules, 1983</u></span></span></p><p style="box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1.5em; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Rule 342(2)-</span></p><p style="box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1.5em; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;">Duty to pay pensions to a person who has worked for the stipulated period of time remains an undischaged contractual obligation-Where the employee retires or is terminated there must exist provision for payment of pension, describing the mode and timing of payment of pension to terminated employees, else courts will imply terms to that effect.</p><p style="box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1.5em; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"><em><strong>MA Jalil vs Rupali Bank Ltd and others 54 DLR 566.</strong></em></p></div></div>
33	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">CHILDREN ACT, 1974</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  42 DLR (AD) 89,45 DLR 643,43 DLR 163,44 DLR 500,42 DLR 491</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1974</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  CHILDREN </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-01-08</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: center;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 16px;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;">Children Act, 1974</u></span></span></div><p><span style="color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"> </span><br style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;">Section 2(f) —</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"/><span style="color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;">In view of the definition of child as appearing in section 2(f) appellant Nasir ought to have been tried by Juvenile Court. Trial of child along with adult is forbidden by law. The trial of the appellant being held not by Juvenile Court is hit by want of jurisdiction.</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Md. Nasir Ahmed Vs. Stare 42 DLR (AD) 89.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"/><span style="color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"> </span><br style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;">Section 2(f), 6 and 8—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"/><span style="color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;">No Child is to be charged with or tried for any offence together with an adult. The child must be tried in the Juvenile Court and not in the ordinary court .Only the adult can be committed to the Court of Sessions and the Juvenile Court will take cognizance of juvenile offenders.</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">State Vs. Deputy Commissioner 45 DLR 643.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"/><span style="color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"> </span><br style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;">Sections 2(f) &amp; 6(1)—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"/><span style="color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;">Joint trail of applicant Sunil, a child, along with the appellants being adults was illegal.</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Kadu VS State 43 DLR 163.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"/><span style="color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"> </span><br style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;">Sections 2(f),55—58 and 61— </span><br style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"/><span style="color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;">offence against child—question of custody—if an offence is committed against a child before its attaining the age of 16, the court has the power to keep it in custody till the child attains the age of 18 or till the proceeding in respect of the crime is terminated.</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Sumati Begum Vs. Rafiqullah 44 DLR 500.</em></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"/><span style="color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"> </span><br style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;">Sections 2(b), 3 &amp; 6—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"/><span style="color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;">The word "cinematograph" is comprehensive enough to include a video—cassette player. It means a composite equipment used for production, projection and exhibition of motion picture film. There is nothing to show that the timber 'Aroth' from where the incriminating materials were seized was a place licensed under the Act and therefore the contention raised against the conviction has no substance.</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Md. Aktarul Vs. State 42 DLR 491.</em></span></p></div></div>
34	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">FAMILY COURTS ORDINANCE, 1985</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  42 DLR 450.</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1985</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  FAMILY COURTS</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-01-13</p><!DOCTYPE html><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: center;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 16px;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Family Courts Ordinance, 1985</span></u><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><u style="box-sizing: border-box;">[XVIII of 1985]</u></span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/> </span></div><div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;">Sections 3, 5 &amp; 27—</span><br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/>Order for maintenance of wife and son—purpose of the Family Courts Ordinance is to provide for speedy disposal of family matters by the same forum. There will be anomaly and multiplicity of proceedings if, in spite of the establishment of Family Courts, the Magistrate continues to entertain cases for maintenance. Provisions made in the Family Courts Ordinance have oust4ed the jurisdiction of the Magistrates to entertain application for maintenance which is a family court matter.<br style="box-sizing: border-box;"/><span style="box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold;"><em style="box-sizing: border-box;">Md. Abdul Khaleque Vs. Selina Be gum 42 DLR 450.</em></span></div></div></div>

SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light Shading Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="61" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light List Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="62" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light Grid Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="63" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Shading 1 Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="64" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Shading 2 Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Ordinance, 1985, Section 5(1)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">Having been enlisted in the 'Ka' list of Abandoned Buildings published in Bangladesh Gazette dated 23.09.1986 under serial No.Sutrapur-9 at page No.9762(9) under the provisions of Abandoned Buildings (Supplementary Provisions) Ordinance, 1985 (Ordi­nance No.LIV of 1985). Mohammad Abdul Alim vs. Government of Bangladesh (Mohammad Fazlul Karim W(Civil) 8 ADC 233 claimant. Government of Bangladesh vs. A. T. M.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">Section 5, 6,12</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">[It has been now well settled by different [pronouncements of this Division that the onus is on the claimant of the build­ing to prove that the building is not an abandoned property and that the Gov­ernment has no obligation either to deny lie facts alleged by the claimant or to as close the basis of treating the property as abandoned property merely be-Hause the same is disputed by the Mannan (Sved Mahmud Hossain J) (Civil) 10 ADC 211</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">The above Act, 1948, Section 4A(2)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">Praying for a direction upon the respon dents to release from requisition the properties mentioned in paragraph 3 of the writ petition. <em>Capi. Mohammad hut-far Rahman vs. Government of Bangladesh (Md. Tafazzul Islam J)</em></span><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> Abdul Jalil Vs. Khorshed Ali, 27 DLR(AD) 143</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">Civil Revision No.2305 of 1997 making the rule absolute and thus decreeing the suit by setting aside the judgment and decree passed by the appellate court below and affirming the judgment and decree passed by the trial court. Probir Kumar Rakshit vs. Abdus Sabur (Md. Joynul Abedin J) (Civil) 6 ADC 74 Rahman vs. Government of Bangladesh (Md. Tafazzul Islam J) (Civil)6 ADC 406</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;"> </span></p></div></div>
36	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Acid Aparadh Ain, 2002 </h2>

Sadek Hossain (Mohammad Fazlul Karim J) (Criminal) 6 ADC 345</em></p></div></div>
37	<h2 class="blog_entry-title"> Acquisition and Requisition of Immovable Property </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  8 ADC 652, 6 ADC 493</p><p><b>Subject:</b>   Acquisition and Requisition of Immovable Property</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b> <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="39" QFormat="true" Name="TOC Heading"/> </w:LatentStyles></xml><![endif]--><!-- [if gte mso 10]><style> /* Style Definitions */ table.MsoNormalTable	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;	mso-style-noshow:yes;	mso-style-priority:99;	mso-style-qformat:yes;	mso-style-parent:"";	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;	mso-para-margin:0in;	mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;	font-size:11.0pt;	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";	mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;	mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast;	mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;	mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;}</style><![endif]--></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">The Acquisition and Requisition of Immovable Property Ordinance 1982, Section: 5,12,15</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">So, the decision of the High Court Divi­sion is based on the fact that the award for compensation was made on 8th April, 1991 and as the compensation money having been deposited by Rabi-tat on 12th December, 1991 within one year from the date of award for compen­sation, the deposit was made in time, the proceedings not abated. This finding is based on misconception of law, inas­much as, the High Court Division made the above observation on the basis of the substituted section 12 of the Ordi­nance, which provision would not be applicable in the said writ petitions. The Deputy Commissioner after hearing ob­jection approved the proposal of the Land Acquisition Officer under section 5 of the Ordinance by order dated 17th July, 1990. The earlier writ petitions were filed in 1992. In the premises, it is the unamended provisions of Section 12 would hold the field but the High Court Division wrongly considered the amended provision . Dr. Malik Mehdi Kabir vs. Rabitat-Al-Alam-Al-Islami (S.K. Sinha J) (Civil) 8 ADC 652</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 5.05pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">Section 3, 15</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 3.1pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">lands had earlier been acquired by the Government for the purpose of con­struction of Dhaka-Chittagong High­way and thereafter only the case plots are left to them and they rent to develop the same for the purpose of setting up industry on these lands. M/S. Mollah In­dustrial Estate vs. Khawja Mohammad Arifullah (M.M. RUHUL AM IN C.J ) (Civil)  6 ADC 493</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;"> </span></p></div></div>
38	<h2 class="blog_entry-title"> Acquisition and Requisition of Immovable Property 2</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  6 ADC 649, 8 ADC 558, 6 ADC 493</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Acquisition and Requisition of Immovable Property </p><p><b>Delivery <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="39" QFormat="true" Name="TOC Heading"/> </w:LatentStyles></xml><![endif]--><!-- [if gte mso 10]><style> /* Style Definitions */ table.MsoNormalTable	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;	mso-style-noshow:yes;	mso-style-priority:99;	mso-style-qformat:yes;	mso-style-parent:"";	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;	mso-para-margin:0in;	mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;	font-size:11.0pt;	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";	mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;	mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">The Acquisition and Requisition of Immovable Property Ordinance, 1982</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-right: 1.9pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 5.5pt 1.9pt .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">The writ petitions as mentioned in the second bunch were filed impugning the notice issued by the Magistrate of the RAJUK, Dhaka, asking the persons to vacate the land in unauthorized occupa­tion and to remove the structures thereon by the 24th August, 1996. Ra-jdhani Unnayan Kartipakkya vs. Jahan Ara Begum (Mohammad Fazlul Karim J) (Civil) 6 ADC 649</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 5.75pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">Section 3,6,15</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 1.7pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">Acquisition has been vitiated for not specifying the lands sought to be ac­quired, these lands have not been ac­quired in public interest or for any public purpose and that no agreement deed was executed between the. requir­ing body and the Government as per Section 15 of the Acquisition and Req­uisition of the Immovable Property Or­dinance, 1982 before acquiring these lands. Power Grid Company vs. Row-shon Ara Begum (Nazmun Ara Sultana J)(Civil) 8 ADC 558.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 1.7pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 4.8pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Section 3, 15</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-right: 6.7pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.4pt 6.7pt .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">lands had earlier been acquired by the Government for the purpose of con­struction of Dhaka-Chittagong High­way and thereafter only the case plots are left to them and they rent to develop the same for the purpose of setting up industry on these lands. <em>M/S. Mollah In­dustrial Estate vs. Khawja Mohammad Arifullah (MM. RUHUL AMIN C.J )(Civil)  6 ADC 493</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: 13.2pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: 13.2pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p></div></div>

Arbitrator in­stead of allowing the prayer for appoint­ment of a Private Engineering Finn for assessment of the costs of the construc­tions made in the acquired land ought to have directed the Public Works Depart- I ment to do the duty relating to the as- \ sessment of compensation<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>of the ! constructions made in the acquired land I as per requirement of the law. The lamed Arbitrator having had not done j so, his action in allowing the prayer for j appointment of a Private Engineering Firm on the prayer of the petitioners in | the Arbitration Miscellaneous case for ! assessment of the compensation as re- j ard the constructions made in the ac- <strong>j</strong>uired land was<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>not<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>legal, <em>Land Acquisition Officer vs. Al-haj Md. Abdul Latif Biswas (Md RuhulAmin CJ)(Civil)<br/>6 ADC<span style="mso-tab-count: 1;">  </span>811 .</em></span></p></div></div>
40	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Adequacy of compensation</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  9 ADC 648</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Adequacy of compensation</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-10-25</p><!DOCTYPE html><p><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> <o:OfficeDocumentSettings>  <o:RelyOnVML/>  <o:AllowPNG/> </o:OfficeDocumentSettings></xml><![endif]--><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> <w:WordDocument>  <w:View>Normal</w:View> 115</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-right: 9.35pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace:
