arbitration court .the contesting respondent i.e. Government represented by the Deputy Commissioner, Dhaka did not raise specifically any such plea that the peti­tioners did not raise any objection as to adequacy of the compensation or that they accepted the compensation money without any objection. <em>Bangladesh Water Development Board vs. Anowar Ali (Nazmun Ara Sultana <span style="letter-spacing: 1.5pt;">J)</span> (Civil) 9 ADC 648</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: 27.35pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; 41	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Administrative Appellate Tribunal, Dhaka</h2>

42	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Administrative Tribunal Act, 1980</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  9 ADC 418, 9 ADC 691,  10 ADC 60, 9ADC' 968, 9 ADC 851, 9 ADC 201, 9 9 ADC 410,  8 ADC 271, A 8 ADC 434,  9 ADC 846, 10 ADC 60, DC 237,  6 ADC828, 10 ADC 407, 6 ADC 879, 7 ADC67</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Administrative </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-10-27</p><!DOCTYPE html><p><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light Shading Accent 4"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="61" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light List Accent 4"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="62" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light Grid Accent 4"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="63" SemiHidden="false" Name="Medium List 2 Accent 4"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="67" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 1 Accent 4"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="68" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 2 Accent 4"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="69" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 3 Accent 4"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="70" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Dark List Accent 4"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="71" SemiHidden="false" Name="Light Shading Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="61" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light List Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="62" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light Grid Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="63" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Shading 1 Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="64" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Shading 2 Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="65" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium List 1 Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="66" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium List 2 Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Name="Medium Grid 2 Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="69" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 3 Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="70" <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="72" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Colorful List Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="73" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Colorful Grid Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="60" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light Shading Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="61" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light List Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="62" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light Grid Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="63" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Shading 1 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="64" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Shading 2 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="65" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium List 1 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="66" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium List 2 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="67" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 1 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="68" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 2 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="69" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 3 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="70" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Dark List Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="71" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Colorful Shading Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="72" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Colorful List Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="73" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Colorful Grid Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="19" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Subtle Emphasis"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="21" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Intense Emphasis"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="31" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Subtle Reference"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="32" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Intense Reference"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="33" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Book Title"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="37" Name="Bibliography"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="39" QFormat="true" Name="TOC Heading"/> </w:LatentStyles></xml><![endif]--><!-- [if gte mso 10]><style> /* Style Definitions */ table.MsoNormalTable	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;	mso-style-noshow:yes;	mso-style-priority:99;	mso-style-qformat:yes;	mso-style-parent:"";	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;	mso-para-margin:0in;	mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;	font-size:11.0pt;	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";	mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;	mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast;	mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;	mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;}</style><![endif]--></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Administrative Tribunal Act, 1980, Dismissal from Service</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">In the departmental proceeding the main allegation brought against the petitioner was that he kidnapped a school teacher who was wife of another man and mother of two children and forcibly compelled her to divorce her husband and thereafter married her forcibly against her will. <em>Md. Kabir I fossa in vs. Government of the People's (Nazmun Ara Sultana J)(Civil) 9 ADC 418</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="Style4" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-pagination: widow-orphan;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="Style4" style="margin-top: 5.3pt; text-align: justify; mso-pagination: widow-orphan;"><span class="FontStyle13"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">Section 4</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">The learned member of the Administra­tive Tribunal allowed the case of the pe­titioner with the observation that the S.P., Bogra was not a proper authority to draw up the departmental proceeding against the petitioner as, during that pe­riod, the petitioner was not working under him. <em>The Government vs. Bemal Kumar Chaki (Nazmun Ara Sultana J)(Civil) 9 ADC 691</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Section 4(1)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Mr. Mahbubey Alam, learned Attorney General appearing for the petitioners, has taken us to the judgments and ar­gued that since the appeals had arisen out of the same judgment, it was incum­bent upon the Administrative Appellate Tribunal to hear and dispose of both the appeals analogously in order to avoid conflicting decisions, and as a matter of fact, it had delivered two conflicting judgments, which escaped the notice of this Division while disposing of the leave petitions and the same is an error of law apparent on the face of the record. It is further contended that the Administrative Tribunal while main­taining the punishment of the respon­dent came to a definite finding that some of the charges brought against the respondent had been satisfactorily proved but the Administrative Appellate Tribunal without reversing those find­ings allowed the appeal preferred by the respondent mechanically. In view of the above, it is contended that the judg­ments of this Division deserve reconsid­eration for ends of justice. <em>Government vs. Md Masud Miah (S.K. Sin ha J) (Civil) 10 ADC 60</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Section 4(2)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Petitioner was appointed as the Postal Operator in Letter Packet Section in Chittagong Foreign Post Office. He worked there till his forced retirement under the order dated 15.07.1998. The petitioner was suspended on 01.08.1995 and a departmental proceeding was started against him. <em>Kamol Krishna Das vs. Government (Sved Mahmud Hossain J) (Civil) 9ADC' 968</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Section4 and 6</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">It is argued on behalf of the petitioner that the petitioner was appointed as electrician in 1991 and thereafter, he was transferred to the post of mechanic in 1998, and the scale of pay of electri­cian being equal to the post of me­chanic. <em>Md. AshrafUddin Khan vs. Md. Rafiqul Islam (S.K. Sinha J)(Civil) 9 ADC 851</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Section 4 and 6</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">That the respondent was appointed as MLSS in the Bangladesh Civil Service, Administration Academy in 1987. Sub­sequently he was promoted to the post of library assistant-cum-typist on 19th February, 1989. In May, 1992 an objec­tion was raised in his pay bill on the ground that his promotion was made not in accordance with law. Thereafter, he was reverted to the post of MLSS after taking opinion from the Ministry of Law. He unsuccessfully preferred a de­partmental appeal and then a petition before the Administrative Tribunal for redress. <em>Government of Bangladesh vs. Md. Ismail (S.K. Sinha J) (Civil) 9 ADC</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 4.8pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Section 4(2)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-right: 1.45pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.9pt 1.45pt .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">A departmental proceeding was initiated against the respondent for misappropri­ation of 339 mds 12 seers of rice and 668 mds 29 seers of wheat in or around mid 1971. The respondent thereupon without defending the charges tendered resignation from his service on 18th Oc­tober, 1971. <em>Government of Bangladesh vs. A.B.M. Siddique Mia (S.K. Sinha J) (Civil) 9 ADC 201</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 4.8pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Section 4</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">We would like to give more explicit reply to the questions raised by the learned Advocate-on-Record for the pe­titioner. It is important to note that amended proviso 2 was added beforethe original 2nd proviso and as a result, the 2nd proviso was relegated to the 3rd proviso. The 1st proviso, in essence, provides that where there is a higher ad­ministrative authority having the power to set aside, vary or modify an order, de­cision or action to be challenged before the Administrative Tribunal, the Admin­istrative Tribunal shall not entertain a case until such higher authority takes a decision on the matter. Md. Shahjahan Atmasder vs. Government of Bangladesh (Sved Mahmud Hossain J)(Civil) 9 ADC 237</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> <o:OfficeDocumentSettings> Roman";	mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;}</style><![endif]--></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">The Administrative Tribunal Act, 1980, Dismissal from service</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">The learned Advocate for the petitioner has argued before us to the effect that the contesting respondent did not raise any question of defect of party in the original Administrative Tribunal Case and as such the Administrative Appel­late Tribunal was not justified and cor­rect at all to dismiss the case on the ground of defect of party. Z. M. Mostafa Kamal vs. Secretary, Ministry of Fi­nance Bangladesh (Nazmun Ara Sul­tana J) (Civil) 9 ADC 410</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Section 4(2)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">As a Deputy Magistrate and Deputy Collector and was granted Senior Scale on 15.07.1981; that on 04.02.1982 he joined on promotion as Additional Deputy Commissioner. By an order dated 22.05.1983, however, he was compulsorily retired from service under Martial Law Order No.9; that in view of the representation made by him from time to time against the said order of punishment, the Review Forum consti­tuted under Article 1A of the Martial Law Order No. 9 for consideration of the representations, made a recommenda­tion on 12.10.1992 "for setting aside the order of retirement dated. 22.05.1982 and for his reinstatement in service maintaining his seniority and continuity of service and treating the period of ab­sence from duty as on leave without pay"; that thereupon the Government by the impugned order dated 23.01.1994 reinstated him in service although ille­gally directing in paragraph No.3 thereof that the period of his absence would be treated as on leave without pay; that on receipt of the said order dated 23.01.1994 i.e. on that very day he submitted his joining report and has been serving as such. But on 20.07.1994 submitted a representation to the Hon'ble President for payment of his ar-rear salary and allowance; that the rep­resentation was rejected bv an order dated 08.10.1995. The Government of Bangladesh vs. A bit I Hashem Khan (Mohammad Fazlul Karim J) (Civil) 8 ADC 271</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Administrative Tribunal Act, 1980 Section 4(2)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 1.7pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Section 4(2) of the Administrative Tri­bunal Act before the Administrative Tri­bunal, Dhaka being Administrative Tribunal Case No. 145 of 2006 claiming pension benefits. According to him after completion of 57 years in service, he went on LPR with effect from 19th Jan­uary, 2005 and thereafter, he retired from the service. After expiry of one year, the authority did not pay his serv­ice benefits on some baseless allega­tions. Government of Bangladesh vs. Ansarul Huq (S.K. Sin ha J) (Civil) 8 ADC 434</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: 10.1pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: 10.1pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 4.8pt 0in .0001pt 10.1pt;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">The Administrative Tribunal Act, 1980 Section 6(2A)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-right: .95pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.65pt .95pt .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">The present petitioners filed the above mentioned Administrative Appellate Tribunal Appeal against the judgment and order dated 12.08.2008 passed by the Administrative Tribunal No.l, Dhaka in Administrative Tribunal Case No.l31 of 2005 with an application under section 6(2A) of the Administra­tive Tribunal Act, 1980 praying for con­donation of delay of 2 (two) months and 6 (six) days in filing the appeal. Gov­ernment of the People's vs. Mcl. Mizaniii-Rahman (Nazmun Ara Sultana J) (Civil) 9 ADC 846</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 5.75pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Section 4(1)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 4.55pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Mr. Mahbubcy Alam, learned Attorney General appearing for the petitioners, has taken us to the judgments and ar­gued that since the appeals had arisen out of the same judgment, it was incum­bent upon the Administrative Appellate Tribunal to hear and dispose of both the appeals analogously in order to avoid conflicting decisions, and as a matter of fact, it had delivered two conflicting judgments, which escaped the notice of this Division while disposing of the leave petitions and the same is an error of law apparent on the face of the record. It is further contended that the Administrative Tribunal while main­taining the punishment of the respon­dent came to a definite finding that some of the charges brought against the respondent had been satisfactorily proved but the Administrative Appellate Tribunal without reversing those find­ings allowed the appeal preferred by the respondent mechanically. In view of the above, it is contended that the judg­ments of this Division deserve reconsid­eration for ends of justice. Government vs. Md Masud Miah (S.K. Sin ha J) (Civil) 10 ADC 60</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 6.25pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Article 4(2)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="Style3" style="mso-pagination: widow-orphan; margin: .7pt 2.4pt .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Administrative Appellate Tribunal Case The petitioner hereof as Teacher, Exper­imental School, filed Administrative Tribunal Case No.293 of 1999 praying for a direction upon the opposite party to upgrade the position of the petitioner to Class-I Gazetted (non-cadre) post like Instructors of Primary Training In­stitute. Md. Jahangir Kabir vs. Bangladesh, represented by the Secre-</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">arv (Shah Abu Nayeem Mominur Rah-</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: .25pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">nan J) (Civil) 6 ADC828</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 4.55pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Administrative Tribunals Act, 1980</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">It is, however, true that the petitioner was suspended from service by an order dated 02.08.2000 and that he was dis­missed from service by an order dated 06.06.2001 giving retrospective from 02.08.2000. Final order of dismissal dated 06.06.2001 could not have any retrospective effect and it was to be ef­fective from the date of final order of dismissal, that is, 06.06.2001. There­fore, the petitioner shall be deemed to have been dismissed from service on and from 06.06.2001 and not from 02.02.2000. Mir Abdul Qaium vs. Gov­ernment of Bangladesh (Syed Mahmud Hossain J)(Civil) 10 ADC 407</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 5.3pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Section 4(2)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Praying for an order setting aside the order of demotion of the petitioner ...(2) It appears that the Administrative Ap­pellate Tribunal considered the provi­sion of Section 4(2) of the Administrative Tribunals Act, 1980 and held that the application before the tri­bunal was barred by limitation and set aside the judgment of the Administra­tive Tribunal. S. M. Mosharaf Hossain vs. Sonali Bank (Md. Abdul Matin JHCivil) 6 ADC 879</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.9pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">The Administrative Appellate Tribunal held that the Divisional Electrical Engi­neer Office issued a letter on 29.01.2001 requesting 11 subordinate, offices to inform about the demands of the petitioner and out of 11 offices only Sub Assistant Engineer (Electrical) gave clearance and the office of the Financial Adviser, Raj shah i gave no objections and no clearance certificate was pro­duced by other offices. The Administra­tive Appellate Tribunal accordingly held that, therefore, it cannot be claimed that "No Demand certificate" was submitted as required by the authority for finaliz­ing the pension and gratuity of the peti­tioner before the tribunal and the Administrative Appellate Tribunal al­lowed the appeal in part with modifica­tions. <em>Government of Bangladesh vs. Md. Jillur Rahman (M. M. Ruhul Amin CJ) (Civil) 7 ADC67</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.9pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p></div></div>
43	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">  Anti-Corruption Commission Act, 2004</h2>

<w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="60" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light Shading Accent 4"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="61" SemiHidden="false" Accent 4"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="68" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 2 Accent 4"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="69" SemiHidden="false" read with Section 109 of the</span></span> <strong><span style="font-size: 7.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">Penal code alleging that the respondent and his wife concealed . <em>Anti Corrup­tion Abdul Matin J) (Criminal) 7 ADC 349</em></span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal"> </p><p class="MsoNormal"><strong>Sections 26(2) and 27(1)</strong></p><p class="MsoNormal"> </p><p class="MsoNormal">Alleged found by disproportionate to his known source of income and thereby he alleged to have committed the offence publishable under Sections 26(2)/27(l) of the Anti-Corruption Ain, 2004 read with Section 15 Gha(5) of Emergency Powers Rules, 2007. <em>Habibur Rahman Mollah vs. The State (Mohammad Fazlul Karim J)(Crimi­nal) 8 ADC 62</em></p></div></div>

petitioners passed their depart­mental examination and also completed foundation training successfully and thus became regularised and confirmed in their service and were eligible for promotion to the senior scale. </span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Md. Ataur Rahman vs. B.M. Muhibur Rahman (Md. Jovnul Abedin <span style="letter-spacing: 1.5pt;">J)</span> (Civil) 6 ADC 278</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: 20.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p></div></div>
46	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Bangladesh Jute Corporation Ordi­nance</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  6 ADC 287</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Bangladesh Jute Corporation </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-10-28</p><!DOCTYPE .5pt;">Bangladesh Jute Corporation Ordi­nance, Section 19</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-pagination: widow-orphan;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">The plaintiff cannot claim for Specific Performance of Contract; that the plain­tiff has accepted the cancellation of let­ters of intent and encashed the cheque for the value of schedule Gha' property</span><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> deposited by it and therefore, it is estopped from instituting the suit for Specific Performance of Contract; that as per terms of the tender notice. </span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">M/S. Nur Mohammad vs. Government of Bangladesh (Mohammad Fazlul Karim J) (Civil)6 ADC 287</span></em></p></div></div>
47	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Bangladesh Penal Code</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  6 ADC 254,  9 ADC 520</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Bangladesh Penal Code</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-11-13</p><!DOCTYPE <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="39" QFormat="true" Name="TOC Heading"/> </w:LatentStyles></xml><![endif]--><!-- [if gte mso 10]><style> /* Style Definitions */ table.MsoNormalTable	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;	mso-style-noshow:yes;	mso-style-priority:99;	mso-style-qformat:yes;	mso-style-parent:"";	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;	mso-para-margin-top:0in;	mso-para-margin-right:0in;	mso-para-margin-bottom:10.0pt;	mso-para-margin-left:0in;	line-height:115%;	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;	font-size:11.0pt;	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";	mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;	mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast;	mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;	mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;}</style><![endif]--></p><p class="MsoNormal">Bangladesh Penal Code Sections 302/34</p><p class="MsoNormal">The High Court Division without dis­cussing the evidence on record as re­quired under law in a very slip shod manner set aside the order of convic­tion and sentence on certain untenable and flimsy grounds. <em>The State vs. Nantu Biswas and others (Md. Abdul Matin J) (Criminal) 6 ADC 254</em></p><p class="MsoNormal"> </p><p class="MsoNormal"> </p><p class="MsoNormal">Circumstantial Evidence</p><p class="MsoNormal"> </p><p class="MsoNormal">If the circumstantial evidence are far from satisfactory and suffered from a number of infirmity, the court is left with no option other than to acquit the accused. Circumstantial evidence must be consistent with the guilt of the ac­cused and if the evidence is inconsis­tent with any other rational explanation, than there is an element of doubt of which the accused must be given the benefit of doubt. The prose­cution must have to prove several cir­cumstances relied by the prosecution beyond doubt that the incriminating facts are such as to be incompatible with the innocence of the accused and incapable of explanation on any rea­sonable hypothesis other than that of the accused's guilt. The chain of evi­dence furnished by those circumstance must be complete and leave no reason­able ground for a conclusion consistent with accused's innocence. <em>Sree Ra-</em><em> bindra Nath Roy vs. The State (S.K. Sinha J)(Criminal) 9 ADC 520</em></p></div></div>
48	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Bangladesh Sugar and Food Indus­tries Corporation Service Regula­tions, 1989</h2>

affi-davit-in-opposition stating inter alia, that the service of the writ petitioner was terminated on 31.03.2004 pursuant to clause 53(2) of the Bangladesh Sugar and Food Industries Corporation Serv­ice Regulations, 1989, by which the au­thority is empqwered to terminate any of its officials by 3(three) months' no­tice or upon payment of 3 (three) months' salary without assigning any reason whatsoever. </span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Bangladesh Sugar and Food Industries vs. Md. Shamsud-din Sheikh (Muhammad Imman Ali J)(Civil) 9 ADC 368</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: 12.25pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p></div></div>
49	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Bengal Tenancy Act</h2>

style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Bengal Tenancy Act, Section 173</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">It appears from record that the suit being for declaration of title to unspec­ified portion of an undivided plot of land is not maintainable without a prayer for partition; that the plaintiff is found to be out of possession; that the trial Court's finding on possession is supported by the evidence on record. </span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Ji-lendra Math B a char vs. Badhakanta Sardar being (Mohammad Fazlid Karim J) (Civil) 6 ADC 127</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: 26.9pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: -26.9pt; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p></div></div>
50	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898</h2>

table.MsoNormalTable	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;	mso-style-noshow:yes;	mso-style-priority:99;	mso-style-qformat:yes;	mso-style-parent:"";	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;	mso-para-margin-top:0in;	mso-para-margin-right:0in;	mso-para-margin-bottom:10.0pt;	mso-para-margin-left:0in;	line-height:115%;	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;	font-size:11.0pt;	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";	mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;	mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;	mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;}</style><![endif]--></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: center; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 14.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;">Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;">Section 195(l)(c) and 476</span></strong><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;">— Power of appellate<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>court<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>to<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>lodge<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">   </span>complaint </span></strong><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;">against forgery of documents used in connection with judicial proceedings</span></strong><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;">—</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;">As provided under section 107 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 the court of appeal has all the powers of the trial court. It is competent to do what the trial court failed to do. It can make complaint under section 195(l)(c) read with section 476 of the Code of Criminal Procedure in respect of forgery of document used in the judicial proceedings before it. <em>Messers N.F.M Universal Estate Ltd. represented by its Managing Director Abdul Awal Minto Vs. A.N.M Obaidul Islam being dead his heirs Gidshan Begum and others 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 52.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 403(1)</span></strong></span><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;">— Provides that a person tried and convicted by a court of competent jurisdiction shall not be tried and punished again for the same offence—</span></strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> <strong><span style="color: black;">Constitution of Bangladesh</span></strong></span><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;">—</span></strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> <strong><span style="color: black;">Article </span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">35(2)</span></strong></span><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;"><strong>—</strong> <strong>Prohibits trial and conviction of a person twice for the same offence—</strong></span><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> <strong><span style="color: black;">General Clauses Act, 1897</span></strong></span><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;">—</span></strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> <strong><span style="color: black;">Section 26</span></strong></span><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;">— Contains similar provision against trial and conviction of a person more than once for the same offence—</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;">From the above provisions it is abundantly clear that a person once tried and convicted by a court of competent jurisdiction for a particular offence shall</span><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> <span style="color: black;">not be tried and punished for the second time for the same offence. The appellant upon conviction by a Special Martial Law court though having no jurisdiction, had already served out the most part of the sentence and was then released on amnesty. The apex court held it inappropriate and against the interest of justice to reopen and restart the case afresh after lapse of long period and in that view set aside the order of the Sessions Judge.</span> <em><span style="color: black;">Mohammad Ullah Vs. Sessions ]udge, Noakhali and others 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 351.</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 561A</span></strong></span><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;">— Quashment of proceedings—</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;">Unless there is a situation as contemplated under section 12 a Chairman can not be placed under suspension. Where in a proceedings under section 561A Cr.P.C for quashment of conviction and sentence a rule has been issued and the convict-petitioner is released on bail the criminal proceedings against him is held still pending and in that view of the matter the apex court declared the impugned suspension order illegal and of no legal effect.</span><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> <em><span style="color: black;">Government of Bangladesh represented by the Secretary Ministry of Local Government and others Vs. Md. Fariduddin Talnkder 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 17.</span></em></span></p></div></div>
51	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Fisheries Nitimala 2009</h2>

Heading"/> </w:LatentStyles></xml><![endif]--><!-- [if gte mso 10]><style> /* Style Definitions */ table.MsoNormalTable	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;	mso-style-noshow:yes;	mso-style-priority:99;	mso-style-qformat:yes;	mso-style-parent:"";	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;	mso-para-margin:0in;	mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;	font-size:11.0pt;	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";	mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;	mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast;	mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;	mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;}</style><![endif]--></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt;">Fisheries Nitimala 2009</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">In view of the submissions from the Bar and the evidence pointed out to us, we are of the opinion that the High Court Division rightly ordered recission of the lease granted in favour of the writ re­spondent No.6. But the direction to gra nt lease in favour of one of the two remaining societies does not appear to be in conformity with the requirement of the Nitimala 2009 as some of the members of those two societies appear to be described as businessman /farmer. <em>Md. Monirul Islam vs. Bijoy Haider (Muhammad Imman Ali J) (Civil) 10 ADC 671</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p></div></div>
52	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Foreign Private Investment (Promo­tion and Protection) Act, 1980</h2>

table.MsoNormalTable	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;	mso-style-noshow:yes;	mso-style-priority:99;	mso-style-qformat:yes;	mso-style-parent:"";	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;	mso-para-margin:0in;	mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;	font-size:11.0pt;	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";	mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;	mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt;">Foreign Private Investment (Promo­tion and Protection) Act, 1980</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">Rule 21 of licensing Rules, 1986 and as such it is apparent that the order sus­pending the license and show cause no­tice impugned in the above writ petition were issued in accordance with law and with full lawful authority with a view to ensure compliance of the law of land; that having investigated the process of issuing the said license and having been satisfied as to the issuance of the license in violation of licensing rule and the long standing standard practice of not issuing license to 100% foreigners owned company, National Board of Revenue directed the licensing Author­ity of Chittagong Customs House to re­vise their decision by way of suspending the license issued to peti­tioner. The learned Counsel further sub­mitted that the interim order is harmful to public interest and ought not to have been passed and that the licence was granted at the instance of an outsider and as such, the High Court Division ought not to have passed the interim order. <em>Bangladesh, represented vs. CMA CGM Bangladesh Shipping Limited (Mohammad Fazlul Karim J) (Civil) 7 ADC 673</em></span></p></div></div>
53	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Hats and Bazars Ordinance,! 959.</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  7 ADC 906</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Hats and Bazars </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-11-07</p><!DOCTYPE html><p><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> <o:OfficeDocumentSettings>  <o:RelyOnVML/>  <o:AllowPNG/> </o:OfficeDocumentSettings></xml><![endif]--><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> <w:WordDocument>  <w:View>Normal</w:View> <w:UseAsianBreakRules/>   <w:DontGrowAutofit/>   <w:SplitPgBreakAndParaMark/>   <w:DontVertAlignCellWithSp/>   <w:DontBreakConstrainedForcedTables/>   <w:DontVertAlignInTxbx/> table.MsoNormalTable	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;	mso-style-noshow:yes;	mso-style-priority:99;	mso-style-qformat:yes;	mso-style-parent:"";	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;	mso-para-margin:0in;	mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;	font-size:11.0pt;	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";	mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;	mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast;	mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;	mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;}</style><![endif]--></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt;">Hats and Bazars Ordinance,! 959.</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">Under the provisions of Hats and Bazars Ordinance, 1959<span style="mso-tab-count: 1;">         </span>(2)</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">The main question before the High Court Division is to determine whether the authorities concerned made proper inquiry to ascertain whether a Bazar was established by the owner of the suit land or it was established by any other persons without obtaining consent of the owner of the suit land and no evi­dence was called either from local peo­ple or shop keepers to ascertain who established the Bazar on the suit land and rather the letter, Ext.5A, proved that Rustom Ali on 03.08.1976, in black and white, requested Deputy Commissioner, Dhaka to evict unauthorized shopkeep­ers from the suit land and thus Ext.5A manifestly proves that the Bazar is question was established by some other persons on the suit land without obtain­ing consent of the original owners and thus the defendant petitioner No.l, without taking Ext.5A into considera­tion, most illegally passed the impugned order of forfeiture dated 23.10.1976 without serving notice upon the owners of the suit land which is a clear high handness and it has been proved that Rustom Ali did not establish the said Bazar on the suit land at the relevant time and further, a plain reading of Sec-</span> <span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">tion 2(3) of the East Pakistan Hats and Bazars (Establishment and Acquisition) Amendment Act, 1966 (Act No.XII of 1967) shows that the suit land was not liable to be forfeited since the said Bazar was neither establishment by the owners themselves nor with their con­sent and moreover, no notice of forfei­ture was served upon the owners of the land before passing the order of forfei­ture." <em>Government of Bangladesh vs. Mariam Begum (A.B.M. Khairul Haque J)(Civil) 7 ADC 906</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p></div></div>
54	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Islamic Foundation Act, 1975</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  7 ADC 903   </p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Islamic Foundation</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-11-08</p><!DOCTYPE html><p><!-- [if 56	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Narcotics Control Act, 1990,</h2>

<w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="21" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Intense Emphasis"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="31" SemiHidden="false" <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="39" QFormat="true" Name="TOC Heading"/> </w:LatentStyles></xml><![endif]--><!-- [if gte mso 10]><style> /* Style Definitions */ table.MsoNormalTable	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;	mso-style-noshow:yes;	mso-style-priority:99;	mso-style-qformat:yes;	mso-style-parent:"";	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;	mso-para-margin-top:0in;	mso-para-margin-right:0in;	mso-para-margin-bottom:10.0pt;	mso-para-margin-left:0in;	line-height:115%;	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;	font-size:11.0pt;	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";	mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;	mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast;	mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;	mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;}</style><![endif]--></p><p class="MsoNormal"><strong>Narcotics Control Act, 1990, Sec­tion 19(1) Table l(Kha)</strong></p><p class="MsoNormal">Found the appellant Ashraful Islam and one Shahidul Islam in possession of 700 grams of heroine in a rexene bag and on query they told that the owner of the heroine was one Atiar Rahman and that aforesaid P.W.I then prepared a seizure list and took them to custody and the case was started against them along with aforesaid Atiar Rahman under Section 19(1) of the Table l(kha) of the Narcotics Control Act, 1990. <em>Md. Ashraful Islam vs. The State (Mohammad Fazlul Karim J) (Criminal) 8 ADC 354</em></p><p class="MsoNormal"><strong>Narcotics Control Act, 1990</strong></p><p class="MsoNormal">The very language of section 39 of the Act, 1990 shows that the power of the Director General of the Directorate of Narcotics to investigate into an offence committed thereunder is not in deroga-<br/>tion of the power of an officer-in-<br/>charge of the concerned police station given under the provisions of the Code to investigate into an offence commit- ted under the Act. The language of the section which is clear and unambigu- ous does not show that it is only the Di- rector General of the Directorate oi Narcotics or any other officer subordi- nate to him specially empowered by the Government by a gazette notification who shall have the exclusive and ab- solute power to investigate into an of-fence committed under the Act, 1990.<br/><span style="mso-spacerun: yes;"> </span>n this regard, it is very pertinent to state that section 31 of the Act, 1990 has made the offences committed under the Act cognizable and, therefore, the<br/>power of the officer-in-charge of the concerned police station or any other police officer of the police station to<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>whom endorsement may be made by the officer-in-charge to investigate the case under the Code cannot be curtailed or taken away. <em>The State vs. Amin<br/>l/uda (Md. Abdul Wahhab Miah J) (Criminal) 10 ADC<span style="mso-tab-count: 1;">  </span>52 7</em></p><p class="MsoNormal"><strong>Section 19</strong></p><p class="MsoNormal">Police after investigation submitted charge-sheets in both the cases against the appellant and another on 27.11.2007 under item Nos.5 and 9(kha) of the Table to section 19(1) and item Nos.5 and 9 (kha) of the Table to section 19 (1) /20 /22(ga) of the Act, 1990 respectively. After submission of charge-sheets, the case records were transmitted to the Druta Bichar Tribu­nal No.4, Dhaka where the cases were registered as Druta Bichar Tribunal Case Nos.4 of 2008 and 13 of 2008. The Tribunal by its order dated 31.01.2008 framed charges in both the cases against the accused-respondent and the co-accused under table 5 and 9(kha) of section 19(1) of the Act, 1990. <em>The State vs. Amin Huda (Md. Abdul Wahhab Miah J) (Criminal) 8 ADC 890</em></p></div></div>
57	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Nari o Shisu Nirjatan Daman Ain 2000,</h2>

Name="Medium Grid 1 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="68" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 2 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="69" <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="71" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Colorful Shading Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="72" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Colorful List Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="73" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Colorful Grid Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="19" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Subtle Emphasis"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="21" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Intense Emphasis"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="31" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Subtle Reference"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="32" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Intense Reference"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="33" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Book Title"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="37" Name="Bibliography"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="39" QFormat="true" Name="TOC Heading"/> </w:LatentStyles></xml><![endif]--><!-- [if gte mso 10]><style> /* Style Definitions */ table.MsoNormalTable	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;	mso-style-noshow:yes;	mso-style-priority:99;	mso-style-qformat:yes;	mso-style-parent:"";	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;	mso-para-margin-top:0in;	mso-para-margin-right:0in;	mso-para-margin-bottom:10.0pt;	mso-para-margin-left:0in;	line-height:115%;	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;	font-size:11.0pt;	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";	mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;	mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast;	mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;	mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;}</style><![endif]--></p><p class="MsoNormal"><strong>Nari o Shisu Nirjatan Daman Ain 2000, Section 11KA</strong></p><p class="MsoNormal">Since, the trial of the case could not be concluded within reasonable time after it was sent back for fresh trial under proper law the accused-petitioner prayed for bail before the High Court Division and by the impugned judg­ment and order the High Court Divi­sion rejected the said prayer making observation that since there was defi­nite direction from the High Court Di­vision that the accused shall remain in custody till conclusion of the trial, the court had no jurisdiction to entertain his prayer for bail. <em>Lokman Sarder vs. The State (Nazmun Ara Sultana J) (Criminal) 9 ADC 719</em></p><p class="MsoNormal">The prosecution examined several wit­nesses before the tribunal to prove the charge against the accused persons. The accused persons were also exam­ined under section 342 of the Code of Criminal Procedure and both of them pleaded not guilty. The tribunal, on consideration of the evidence and other facts and circumstances, found the present accused-respondent guilty under section 9(1) of the Nari-O-Shishu Nirjatan Daman Ain, 2000 and convicted him thereunder and sen­tenced him to suffer imprisonment for life along with fine. The tribunal ac­quitted the other accused of the charge levelled against him. <em>The State vs. Md. Kamal Hossain (Nazmun Ara Sultana J) (Criminal) 9 ADC 709</em></p><p class="MsoNormal"><strong>Section 7</strong></p><p class="MsoNormal">Accused Chaklet, Mostak, Masud ob­structed them and forcibly kidnapped Jannatul Ferdous @ Sagorika by a red coloured microbus. Informant tried to resist them when accused Mostak in­flicted dagger blow causing injury to the left hand of informant and accused Moniruzzaman @ Chaklet pointed a pistol and thereafter, the accused per­sons hurriedly left the place of occur­rence with victim Sagorika by microbus. <em>Md. Moniruzzaman alias Chaklet vs. The State (Mohammad Ea-zlul Karim J) (Criminal) 8 ADC 711</em></p></div></div>
