mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: .7pt 0in .0001pt 71.5pt;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">The Code of Civil Procedure, Order 21, Rule 42</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Petitioners filed the aforesaid writ peti­tion and obtained rule Nisi calling upon the respondents to show cause why the order dated 6.7.2008 attaching the prop­erty of the petitioners by the Artha Rin Adalat and the proceeding of the execu­tion proceeding in Artha Rin Execution Case No. 471 of 2008 should not be de-</span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> <span style="letter-spacing: .5pt;">S. Co. Power Plant<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">    </span>Ltd<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">    </span>vs.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">     </span>Government of Bangladesh (Md. Jovnul Ahedin J) (Civil) 7 ADC 299</span></span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">The Code of Civil Procedure, Order 23, Rule 1(2)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Seeking declaration of title in the suit property, withdrawal of the suit with a permission to sue afresh . <em>Grameen Telecom vs. Dr. Rowshan Alam(S.K. Sinha J) (Civil) 8 ADC 43</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Order 39, Rule 1</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">It appears that the plaintiff claimed this possession which is supported by the RW.2 and RW.3 on the contrary the de­fendant claimed possession in the suit land having placed Ext-'Kha'; the recent Khatian has been prepared in the name of the defendant. <em>Md. Lai Mi ah vs. Md. Anwar Hossain (Mohammad Fazlul Karim J) (Civil)6 ADC 409</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">The Code of Civil Procedure, Order 47 Rule 1</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Seeking decree for permanent injunc­tion and for declaration that the property in suit is not enemy property i.e. vested property. <em>Matiar Rahman vs. Assistant Custodian of Enemy Property Lands (Md. RuhulAmin CJ) (Civil) 6 ADC 20</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Order 5 Rule 20</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">By practicing fraud upon the Court by showing false report as to service of summons and on the basis of a forged karfa created in the name of a dead per­son. The plaintiff claimed the suit land by inheritance and possession thereon. <em>Riaz Uddin Ahmed vs. Khondakar KhorshedAli (S. K. Sinha J) (Civil) 7 ADC 392</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 4.8pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Order 7 Rule 11</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">First Appeal rejecting the plaint on an application filed under Order 7 Rule 11 read with Section 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure. </span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Sonali Bank repre­sented vs. Meghna Vegetable Oil (Md. Abdul Matin J)(Civil) 7 ADC 644</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: .7pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Order 9 Rule 13</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: .7pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></strong></p><p class="Style6" style="text-align: justify; mso-pagination: widow-orphan;"><span class="FontStyle14"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">Order 7 Rule 11</span></strong></span></p><p class="Style4" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-pagination: widow-orphan;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="Style4" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; tab-stops: dotted 95.5pt;"><span class="FontStyle12"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">Specific performance of contract by way of re-conveying by the defendants the suit land in his favour on the aver-ments that he was owner of the suit landby way of jote right and while in pos-session and enjoyment of the suit land he proposed to sell the same and the de- fendant No. 1(2)</span></span><span class="FontStyle13"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">Kohinoor Chowdhury vs. Sree Kamada Ranjan Bhattacharja (Md. Tafazzul Islam J) (Civil) 6 ADC 488.</span></span></p><p class="Style4" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; tab-stops: dotted 95.5pt;"><span class="FontStyle13"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;"> </span></span></p><p class="Style4" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; tab-stops: dotted 95.5pt;"><span class="FontStyle13"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: .5pt; font-weight: normal;"> </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Order 7 Rule 11, Section 151</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Praying for declaration of title to the suit land and also for further declaration that the ex-parte judgment and decree dated 13.11.1995 passed in Other Class Suit No. 99 of 1994 is not binding upon them contending. <em>Saleh Ahmed and oth­ers vs. Amena Bewa and others (Md. Abdul Matin J) (Civil) 6 ADC 695</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Learned Joint District Judge upon hear­ing the parties and considering the ma­terials on record allowed the petition by order dated 31.10.2002 awarding com­pensation of Tk.5,000/- in favour of the plaintiff. <em>Chairman, Chittagong Port Authority vs. Safiuddin (Shah Abu Nay-eem Mominur Rahman J)(Civil) 7 ADC.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 3.1pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Order 9 Rule 4</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Defendant-petitioner seeks review of this Court's judgment dated 19.06.2008 passed in Civil Appeal No. 181 of 2005 dismissing the appeal with cost of Tk. 10,000/- </span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">M.A. Aziz vs. Bangladesh represented bv the Secretarv (Md. JoynulAbedin J)(Civil) 6 ADC 547</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p></div></div>
89	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">The Code of Civil Procedure 1908-2</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  7 ADC   3 77, 7 ADC 633, 6 ADC 144</p><p><b>Subject:</b>   Civil Procedure</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b> Roman";	mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;}</style><![endif]--></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 4.55pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">The Code of Civil Procedure 1908, Order IX rule 13</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 4.55pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Praying for a decree for eviction of the defendant as licensee. The suit was de­creed ex-parte. <em>Waliullah being dead his heirs vs. Hasina Begum (A.B.M. Khairul Haque J) (Civil) 7 ADC<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">   </span>3 77</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 4.8pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Order IX Rule 13</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">The suit was decreed on compromise with defendant No. 1 and 2 and ex-parte against the rest by judgment and decree dated 02.09.2002. Then, the defendant Nos.4 to 6 made an application under order IX Rule 13 of the Code of Civil Procedure being Miscellaneous Case No.23 of 2006 for restoration of the suit to its original file and number after set­ting aside the ex-perte decree. <em>Puron Gonju vs. Abdul Haque and others (B.K.Das <span style="letter-spacing: 1.5pt;">J)</span> (Civil) 7 ADC 633</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 3.1pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Order VII, Rule 11</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">The facts of the case, in short, are that the Waqf Administrator, Dhaka by order dated 30.09.2002 appointed Tofazzal Ahmed, Mutawalli Secretary of Waqf Estate and constituted and approved 13 member committee for 5 years. <em>M. <span style="letter-spacing: -.5pt;">To­</span>fazzal Ahmed vs. Jashim uddin Haydar Faruque</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Order XLI</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">The High Court Division held that it is a settled principle of law that the appel­late Court below being final Court of fact will have to discuss and reassess the evidence of record independently while cither reversing of affirming the finding of the trial Court. <em>Chitta Ranjan Roy vs. Dhirendra Nath Roy (Mohammad Fa­zlul Karim J)(Civil) 6 ADC</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 5.05pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Order XLI rule 27</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Filed the instant suit for partition claim­ing a saham for 4.03 acres out of the suit-land. The suit was contested by the defendant Nos. 1,4, 5 and 2, 10 to 13 by filing separate set of written statements. <em>Abdur Razzak vs. Md. Habejuddin ■(A.B.M. Khairul Haque J)(Civil) 7 ADC</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Order XXI rule 99</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Allowing the appeal granting temporary injunction reversing those dated 08.03.1990 passed by the Senior Assis­tant Judge, Sadar, Sylhet in Title Suit No.241 of 1989 refusing plaintiffs prayer for temporary injunction. <em>Joirun-nessa vs. Abdul Matalib (Mohammad Fazlul Karim J)(Civil) 8 ADC 302.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Order XXVI</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Praying for a decree for declaration oftitle and recovery of khas possession in the suit land alleging his prior posses­sion and subsequent dispossession by the contesting defendants. <em>Md. Nurul Alain Miah vs. Md. Idris All (Moham­mad Fazlul Karim J)(Civil) 6 ADC 605</em> th</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Code of Civil Procedure, Rule 31, Order XXXXI</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-right: 1.2pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.4pt 1.2pt .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">In the Court of Subordinate Judge, Artha Rin Adalat No. 4, Dhaka alleging, inter alia, that the plaintiff is a public limited banking company incorporated. </span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">K.K.K. Garments Limited vs. Islami Bank (Mohammad Fazlul Karim J) (Civil) 6 ADC 181.</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.4pt 1.2pt .0001pt 0in;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Rule 5 and 6 Order XXXVIII</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Passed%w the High Court Division in Civil Revision No.3067 of 2000 dispos-<br/>ing of the Rule giving direction upon the appellant to take immediate steps to<br/>release two double Decker buses on payment of all duties and taxes and to<br/>sell and to keep out of the sale proceeds of TK.43,00,000.00 in fixed deposit to<br/>the credit of the trial Court till final de- cision of the suit. <em>Dhaka Bank Limited<br/>vs. Monir Hossain (Mohammad FazlulKarim J) (Civil)<span style="mso-tab-count: 1;">           </span>6 ADC 402</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 4.8pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Section 10, 11</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 3.1pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">The suit was filed seeking eviction of</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.9pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Section 115(1)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">licensee/permissive possessor and for khas possession, of the land de­scribed in the schedule attached to the plaint. <em>Sreematipriti Rani Chakraborlv vs. J.M. Sen Institute, through Head Master (Md. Ruhul Amin J) (Civil) 6 ADC 945.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Praying for declaration of title to the suit land and for recovery of khas pos­session therein and for a further declara­tion that the registered deed of gift in favour of Minoti Bala by the donar Gagon Chandra Saha Roy as well as as the registered sale deed dated 5.1.2000 executed by Minoti Bala Saha in favour of defendant Nos. 1-5 are forged, fraud­ulent and not binding upon the plaintiff. <em>Sree Ashish Kumar Shaha Roy vs. Al­ii'aj Md. Wasidul Islam (B.K. Das J) (Civil) 7 ADC 148</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 5.05pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Section 115</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">For declaration of title and recovery of khas possession of 0.04 acres of viti land with a tin shed alleging, inter alia, that the defendant sold 0.04 acres of viti land along with a tin shed thereon at a consideration of Tk.99,000/- to the plaintiff by a registered sale deed dated 29.3.1990 with an agreement of recon­veyance executed and registered on the same day. </span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Abul Hasem Chowdhury vs. Md.Shamsur<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">     </span>Rahman<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">     </span>(B.K. Das</span></em> <em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">J)(Civil) 7 ADC 327</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Section 115</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Where there is an error apparent on the face of the record, whether error oc­curred by reason of the counsel's mis­take or it crept in by reason of an oversight on the part of the Court, is not a circumstance which can affect the ex­ercise of jurisdiction of the Court to re­view its decision. <em>Md. Abdur Rashid Akand vs. Md. Raisuddin (S.K. Sinha J)(Civil) 8 ADC 39</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Section 115(1)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">"...Both the parties adduced evidence. The learned Assistant Judge upon con­sideration of the evidence on record found the plaintiffs homestead upon the suit land and found that the Government had received rent vide Ext.3 series from the plaintiff. In view of the above the said Court decreed the suit by the judg­ment and decree dated 1.10.1997. The Government preferred Title Appeal No. 142 of 1997 and that was dismissed by the Additional District Judge by the im­pugned judgment and decree dated 12.04.1999 against which the present application by the Government. I have gone though the judgment of both the Courts below and as well as the revi-sional application. Admittedly the homestead of the plaintiff are standing on the suit land. Admittedly the Govern­ment received rent from plaintiff. <em>Gov­ernment vs. Abdul Kader Munshi (Shah Abu Nayeem Mominur Rahman J) (Civil) 9 ADC 659</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 4.8pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Section 115(1)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Plaintiff was suffering from paralysis and was confined to bed. The defendant No. 1 taking advantage of her illness, managed to create a deed in collusion with the scribe and the plaintiff was not acquainted with the fact of the existence of the deed and the defendant created the deed on taking left thumb impres­sion on the plea of treatment. <em>Md. Ashraful Alam vs. Md Nazrul Islam (Md. Hassan Ameen J) (Civil)6 ADC 305</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 4.55pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Section 115(1)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">As regards the submissions of the learned counsel this will suffice to men­tion that the assumption of jurisdiction to hear a matter by a Division Bench in respect of a Single Court matter suffers from no infirmity and depends upon the absolute discretion of the Court con­cerned. <em>A.M.M. Ali Ashraf vs. Nurun Rashid Chowdhury (Mohammad Fazlul Karim J) (Civil)6 ADC 307</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; mso-bidi-font-style: italic;">Section 151, Order 39, Rule 1, 2</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Allowed the prayer of mandatory injunction relying on the Advocate Com­missioner's report. Being aggrieved thereby, defendant No. 1 and 6 filed Miscellaneous Appeal. <em>Md. Yunus vs. Abul Kalam (Md. Abdul Aziz J)(Civil) 6 ADC 584.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 4.3pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Section 152</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">As it appears the High Court Division rejected the revisional application sum­marily holding that the prayer as made in the application dated 2.11.2004 for setting aside the section 152 CPC, the Court cannot allow such relief and fur­ther the Court became functus officio after passing of the judgment and decree and the learned Joint District Judge hav­ing passed its judgment and decree dated 25.7.2004 on the basis of the sanction letter, <em>Dr. S.M. Yunus AH vs. Joint District Judge (Md. Tafazzul Islam J) (Civil) 6 ADC 144</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p></div></div>
90	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">The Code of Civil Procedure, 1908-3</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  6 ADC 666, Section 115, 8 ADC 673, 8 ADC     721, 8 ADC 744, 9 ADC 210.</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Civil Procedure</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-10-31</p><!DOCTYPE html><p><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> <o:OfficeDocumentSettings>  <o:RelyOnVML/>  <o:AllowPNG/> Heading"/> </w:LatentStyles></xml><![endif]--><!-- [if gte mso 10]><style> /* Style Definitions */ table.MsoNormalTable	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;	mso-style-noshow:yes;	mso-style-priority:99;	mso-style-qformat:yes;	mso-style-parent:"";	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;	mso-para-margin:0in;	mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;	font-size:11.0pt;	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";	mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;	mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast;	mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;	mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;}</style><![endif]--></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">The Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 Section 20</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Writ petition challenging the ex-parte decree passed in Money Suit No. 19 of 2002 and the proceedings of Money Ex­ecution Case No.l of 2006 correspon­ding to Money Execution Case No.85 of 2003 arising out of the said Money Suit No. 19 of 2002 filed by the respon­dent No.l against the petitioner in the 1st Court of Joint District Judge, Chit-tagong. The said writ petition was filed on the ground that the court at Chit-tagong which entertained and passed the ex-parte decree had no jurisdiction inas­much as the alleged cause of action arose in Dhaka and not in Chittagong and both the defendants were residents of places beyond the territorial jurisdic­tion of the Chittagong District Court. Another ground for such challenge was that the said court passed the exparte de­cree without caring that the service re­turn of summons of the suit was not received. <em>Sun Cult Business vs. M/s. Elite Iron &amp; Steel (Md. Joynul Abedin J) (Civil) 6 ADC 666.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 4.3pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Section 115</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">The Trial Court, on consideration of the evidence adduced by both the parties, dismissed the plaintiffs' suit on making observation and findings to the effect that the defendant No.l, admittedly, being in possession of the land in ques­tion for more than 20 years on the basis of a unregistered sale deed dated 25.5.1974 acquired a good title in that land by virtue of adverse possession and that the right title and interest of the plaintiffs in that land extinguished . <em>Md: Shamsul Hoque vs. Md. Jabbar (Naz-mun Ara Sultana J)(Civil) 8 ADC 673</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 6.95pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Section 151</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 3.35pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">From the facts stated hereinbefore, it is clear that the present-petitioner who was the original judgment-debtor in the execution case in question sold the mortgaged property to respondent No.2 during the pendency of the execution case. <em>Md. Hossain Ahmed vs. Bangladesh House Building (Md. Abdul Wahhab Miah J) (Civil) 8 ADC<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">     </span>721</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 3.35pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Section 151</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Both the Courts below on consideration of the evidence on record oral and doc­umentary having concurrently found that the plaintiffs failed to establish their right, title, interest in the C<strong>.S. </strong>plot No. 1548, the learned Judge of the High Court Division committed error of law in sending the suit back on remand to the trial Court with a direction to dis­pose of the same after "investigation of the suit land by appointing another Ad­vocate Commissioner" to ascertain the suit land invoking the inherent power under section 151 of the Code of Civi Procedure. <em>Md. Anwar Hossain <strong>m </strong>Mosammat Hoshneara Begum ( Ma. Abdul Wahhab Miah J) (Civil) 8 ADC 744</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Section 115</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">It is stated in the application for condo­nation that for filing a civil revision, the plaintiffs-petitioners collected a certi­fied copy of the judgment of the appel­late Court on 21.3.1994, and delivered the same to Mr. Md. Lutfor Rahman, a practising Advocate of Magura District Bar for taking necessary step in this re­gard. Thereafter in the middle of the year 2004, the said Advocate died, and hearing the news, petitioner No.l went to the house and the chamber of the said Advocate. He tried to collect informa­tion from the law clerk and the junior of the deceased Advocate Mr. Lutfor Rah­man. But they expressed their inability to return the certified copy of the im­pugned judgment. Then the plaintiffs-petitioners collected a fresh certified copy of the judgment and decree of the Appellate Court on 23.7.2009 and filed the present application for condonation along with a revisional application. <em>Abu Bakkar Lashkar vs. Rostam AH Mondal (Syed Mahmud Hossain J) (Civil) 9 ADC 210.</em></span></p></div></div>
91	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">The Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  2, MLR (1997) (AD) 212, 1, MLR (1996) (HC) 59, 3, MLR (1998) (AD) 258, 5, MLR (2000) (HC) 170, 5, MLR (2000) (HC) 395, 4, MLR (1999) (HC) 191, 1, MLR (1996) (HC) 201, 2, MLR (1997).(HC) 372, 3, MLR (1998) (HC) 99, 1. MLR (1996) (AD) 410, 1, MLR (1996) (H</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1898</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  The Code of Criminal Procedure</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-03-21</p><!DOCTYPE html><p><!-- [if gte mso <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="39" QFormat="true" Name="TOC Heading"/> </w:LatentStyles></xml><![endif]--><!-- [if gte mso 10]><style> /* Style Definitions */ table.MsoNormalTable	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;	mso-style-noshow:yes;	mso-style-priority:99;	mso-style-qformat:yes;	mso-style-parent:"";	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;	mso-para-margin-top:0in;	mso-para-margin-right:0in;	mso-para-margin-bottom:10.0pt;	mso-para-margin-left:0in;	line-height:115%;	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;	font-size:11.0pt;	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";	mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;	mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;	mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;}</style><![endif]--></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: center; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 14pt; color: black;">The Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 </span></strong></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: center; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12pt; color: black;">(Act No. V of 1898)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12pt; color: black;"> </span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 9(2)—</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">Place of sitting of the Court of Sessions</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—To be directed and notified—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">Government have the power under section 9(2) of the Code of Criminal Procedure to direct at what place or places the Court of Sessions shall hold its sitting to try any particular case by special order published in the official Gazettee. There is nothing wrong in the order giving such direction.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Syeed Farrok Rahman Vs. Sessions Judge Dhaka and others- </span></em><span style="color: black;">2, MLR (1997) (AD) 212.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Awarding of sentence—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">Sentence to be awarded should be proportionate to the gravity of the offence. It should not be too harsh or too lenient.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Md. Yahia &amp; others Vs. State- </span></em><span style="color: black;">1, MLR (1996) (HC) 59.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 99 A(l)</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— Forfeiture of Publications</span></strong> <strong><span style="color: black;">containing</span></strong> <strong><span style="color: black;">objectionable matters</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">When in its opinion any publication contains objectionable matters, the Government by order published in the official gazette- may forfeit such publication under section 99A(i) of the Code of Criminal Procedure. Objectionable matters need not the mentioned verbatim in the order. Order of forfeiture may be set aside upon application by the Special Bench of the High Court Division on the contrary shown under section 99B of the Code.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Sadaruddin Ahmed Chisty Vs. Bangladesh and others- </span></em><span style="color: black;">3, MLR (1998) (AD) 258.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;"> </span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 103</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— Search and seizure— Consequence of non-compliance</span></strong> <strong><span style="color: black;">of</span></strong> <strong><span style="color: black;">essential requirements—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">It is mandatory that whenever search and seizure of articles are made this shall be made in presence of some respectable persons of the locality otherwise the seizure and recovery will be doubtful. Non-examination of seizure list witness and independent and impartial witness together with material contradictions and omissions in the evidence on record render the prosecution case not proved beyond doubt leading to acquittal of the accused.</span><span style="color: black;">   </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Jewel and another Vs. the </span></em><span style="color: black;">State-5, MLR (2000) (HC) 170.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 103</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— Manner of search and seizure—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">Police while making search and seizure is mandatorily required to comply with certain formalities. Non-compliance with such formalities makes the seizure illegal consequently rendering the prosecution doubtful.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Haran Bepari (Md). Vs. The SLate-</span></em><span style="color: black;">5, MLR (2000) (HC) 395.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 145</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">Magistrate has no jurisdiction to draw up proceedings when the possession of the disputed property is already regulated by civil court's-order</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— </span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong> </strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Proceedings when liable to be quashed imder Section 561 A</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">Magistrate has no jurisdiction to draw proceeding under section 145 of</span> <span style="color: black;">the Code of Criminal Procedure when the  Civil  Court is  in seisin of the matter in dispute and already had passed   order  regulating possession thereof. Such proceedings drawn by magistrate are liable to be quashed.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;">Abdul Majid <em>Mondol Vs. The State and another- </em>4, MLR (1999) (HC) 191.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 144, 145— Apprehension</span></strong><strong> <span style="color: black;">of   breach of peace</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—Magistrate cannot decide ownership—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">A Magistrate has to see whether. there is any apprehension of the breach of peace over the possession of any immovable property and he is not required to decide ownership but the possetion of either party in the disputed property. The existence of apprehension of breach of peace is the</span> <span style="color: black;">essential ingredient which vests the jurisdiction in the Magistrate under section 144 and 145 Cr. PC.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Jotish Chandra Bhattacharya Vs. Babul Chandra Chattarjee-</span></em><span style="color: black;">1, MLR (1996) (HC) 201.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 145—</span></strong> <strong><span style="color: black;">Apprehension of breach of peace</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— Pre-requisite of a Magistrate's assuming jurisdiction—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;">Unless there exists apprehension of breach of peace arising out of the dispute over possession of immovable property Magistrate cannot assume jurisdiction under section 145 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. Proceedings drawn without the satisfaction of the Magistrate in this regard cannot be sustained in law.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Taizuddin Mia (Md) and others Vs. Md. Abdul Kader and another</span></em><span style="color: black;">— 2, MLR (1997).(HC) 372.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 145—</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">Proceedings not tenable</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— When civil court procedings are there—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">Where the subject-matter is under proceedings of the civil court with the order regulating the possession thereof from long before, the proceedings under section 145 of the Cr. P.C in relation to such property is not competent and being abuse of the process of law is liable to be quashed.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Abul Bashar (Haji) Vs. Hasanuddin Ahmed and others- </span></em><span style="color: black;">3, MLR (1998) (AD) 162.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 145—</span></strong> <strong><span style="color: black;">Jurisdiction of Magistrate not ousted by reason of a civil suit-</span></strong><span style="color: black;">So long decree is not passed or injunction regulating possession of the suit land is not granted the jurisdiction of the Magistrate under sections 145 Cr.P.C in the face of apprehension of breach of peace is not ousted merely by reason that a civil suit is filed.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Mozaffar Ahmed Vs. The State and others</span></em><em><span style="color: black;">— 3, </span></em><span style="color: black;">MLR (1998) (HC) 99.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 439 and 561 A</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></strong> <strong><span style="color: black;">Maintainability</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—After disposal of application u/s 439— application u/s 561A not permissible— Section 145— Proceedings thereunder—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">Finding of possession in the disputed property within the statutory period by the Magistrate on proper appreciation of evidence can not be interfered with. Application under section 561A does not lie in the self same matter after disposal of revisional application.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Ajman Alt Mia Vs. Md. Alauddin Chowdhunj</span></em><em><span style="color: black;">— </span></em><span style="color: black;">1.
