However if the same is complied before hearing under section 265B of the Code of Criminal Procedure, the defect is cured.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Bazlul Hada (Major Retd.) and another Vs. The State</span></em><em><span style="color: black;">— </span></em><span style="color: black;">5, MLR (2000) (AD) 276.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 195-</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">Taking cognizance of offence under section 188 of Penal Code</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">Magistrate empowered under section 190(1)(a) is competent to take cognizance of the offence under section 188 of the Penal Code upon enquiry report submitted by police of violation of order passed by the same Magistrate under section 144 Cr.P.C. without sending any written complaint to himself as required under section 195(1) Cr.P.C.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Anwar Hossain Vs. Jamal Hossain</span></em><span style="color: black;">— 1, MLR (1996) (HC) 93.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 476 and 195— Complaint by Court—when permissible- Private complaint when can be lodged—­The </span></strong><span style="color: black;">court can make a complaint only when a fraudulent document is produced before it in a proceedings. When not produced before the Court in any proceeding private complaint is not barred in law.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Shamsuddin</span></em><span style="color: black;"> <em>Ahmed Chowdhury Vs. The State &amp;. another- </em>2, MLR(1997) (AD) 119.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 195(1)(C)—</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">When a direct criminal case is barred</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">Section 195(1)(C) of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 is not attracted when the accused is charged for the offence under sections 467, 409 and 420 of the Penal Code, 1860 read with section 5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Sadat Ali Talukder Md</span></em><span style="color: black;"> Vs. <em>the State and another- </em>4, MLR (1999) (AD) 223.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 195- Complaint against forged document-</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 561A- Quashment of proceedings-When no bar</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">Section 195 bars taking of cognizance in respect of forged document filed in a Civil, Criminal or Revenue court except upon a complaint lodged by the court concerned. But when the forged document is not filed in any court, section 195 is not bar against taking of cognizance. Therefore the proceedings being competent in law cannot be quashed.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Ali </span></em><em><span style="color: black;">Aman and another</span></em><span style="color: black;"> <em>Vs</em>. <em>The State and another</em></span><em><span style="color: black;">— </span></em><span style="color: black;">5, MLR (2000)(AD) 343.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 195 and 476 (1)—</span></strong> <strong><span style="color: black;">Procedure of complaint for giving false evidence</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">It is not the requirement of law that the court should wait till conclusion of trial of the case where false evidence is given. Section 476(1) prescribes the procedure of making complaint against offence mentioned in section 195. It is also not mandatory that the court shall hold preliminary enquiry before sending complaint. Complaint can well be sent without holding preliminary inquiry.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Mosudur Rahman Mollah (MdJ and another Vs. the State- 5, MLR (2000) (HC) 390.</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 200, 156(3), 561A- Complaint and police investigation</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—Once cognizance is taken complaint can not be sent for </span></strong><span style="color: black;">police <strong>investigation—</strong></span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">The Magistrate may without talcing cognizance send a petition of complaint to the police for holding investigation treating the same as F.I.R. in a cognizable case under section 156(3). But once he takes cognizance under section 200 he can not direct the Police to treat the petition of complaint as an F I. R. and hold investigation on the basis thereof.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Yakub Ali Vs. The State Section 339c</span></em><em><span style="color: black;">— </span></em><span style="color: black;">1, MLR (1996) (AD) 58.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 537- Defects curable—</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 200</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— Examination of complaint— Non-examination-Defect curable</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">Nori-examination of the complainant under section 200 Cr. P.C. before transfer of a case for judicial enquiry is an irregularity which can be cured under section 537 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Kazi</span></em><span style="color: black;"> <em>Ershadur Rahman @ Ershad Hossain Vs. Md. Gyasuddin  &amp; another</em></span><em><span style="color: black;">—1, </span></em><span style="color: black;">MLR (1996) (HC) 277.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Sections 203, 205(1) and 436</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— Magistrate can not be directed to take cognizance—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">When a complaint has been dismissed under section 203 neither the Sessions Judge nor the High Court Division can direct the Magistrate to take cognizance of the offence and issue process under section 205(1). They can only direct further enquiry under section 436, the matter of taking cognizance absolutely resting with the Magistrate on the result of further inquiry.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Yusuf Hasan Vs. KM. Rezaul Ferdous</span></em><em><span style="color: black;">— </span></em><span style="color: black;">1, MLR (1996) (AD) 102.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 205D—</span></strong> <strong><span style="color: black;">Trial of cases instituted on complaint and on police report on the same matter</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">Both the cases, one instituted on complaint and the other on police report on same matter shall be tried together as if instituted on a police report.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Mokhlesur Rahman Vs. Rabeya Parvin Chowdhury and others- </span></em><span style="color: black;">4, MLR (1999) (AD) 260.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 205C—</span></strong> <strong><span style="color: black;">Transmission of record to court of Sessions with decuments</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— Omission to do so— Consequence of—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">Statements recorded under sections 161 and 164 of the Code of Criminal Procedure fall within the category of documents as mentioned in section 205C. Copies of such documents should be supplied to the accused for their defence. Omission to do so causes prejudice to the accused. The purpose of the law will be served if copies of those documents are supplied to the accused before hearing the framing of the charge.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Naral Islam Manzur Vs. The State</span></em><span style="color: black;">— 5, MLR (2000) (HC) 243.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 222- Joinder of charges-Defence not to be prejudiced</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">Not more than one charge should be brought under the single head against the accused because such joinder not only causes prejudice to the accused in his defence but also violates the provision of section 222 Cr.P.C.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Jyoti Prakash Datta Vs. the State.</span></em><em><span style="color: black;">— </span></em><span style="color: black;">4, MLR (1999) (HC) 81.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 241 A—Discharge of accuseds— When improper—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">Discharge of accused under section 241A of the Code of Criminal Procedure is not proper when there are primafacie materials on record for framing charge. Magistrate is bound to proceed with the trial of the case when the discharge order is setaside by Additional Sessions Judge in exercise of his revisional jurisdiction. The learned Additional District Magistrate discharging the accused again ignoring the order of the learned Additional Sessions Judge can well be subjected to proceedings calling upon him to explain his conduct.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Swendra nath Goswami Vs. </span></em><span style="color: black;">Helena <em>Herlovi and others</em></span><em><span style="color: black;">— </span></em><span style="color: black;">2, MLR(1997) (AD) 249.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 241A—</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">Discharge of accused on plea of alibi</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—based on police report— Not permissible—-</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">In a case triable by the court of Sessions, Magistrate can not discharge the accused on plea of alibi merely on the police report. Alibi can only be proved by evidence which stage comes during trial. Naraji petition is a complaint which can not be rejected without enquiry.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Jalaluddin Bhuiyan Vs. Abdur Rouf and others</span></em><em><span style="color: black;">—3, </span></em><span style="color: black;">MLR(1998) (HC) 101.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 241A- Discharge of accused when the charge is groundless</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">The trial court enjoys wide prower to frame charge on the basis of materials on record. The previous statements of the witnesses recorded under section 164 Cr.PC can only be used at the time of trial for the purpose of contradiction under section 145 of the Evidence Act, 1872. When charges are framed by the trial court on the basis of statements of the witnesses recorded under section 1.61 Cr.Pc this can not be interfered with lightly on the basis of statements recorded under section 164 Cr.Pc which can not be used before trial. However law does not permit to keep the victims in judicial custody for indefinite period.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Forhad Hossain (Md.) and </span></em><span style="color: black;">another Vs. <em>The </em>State</span><span style="color: black;">— '3, MLR (1998) (HC) 213.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 561A—</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 241A and 265C</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— Distinction between—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">Section 241A operates in respect of court of Magistrate and section 265C operates in respect of court of Sessions. When the civil court is in seisin of the matter, the parties cannot be directed to lodge complaint before the Magistrate in respect of offence relating to civil court proceedings. High Court Division can quash such proceedings under section 561A Cr.P.C.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Latifa</span></em><span style="color: black;"> <em>Akhter and others Vs. the State and another</em></span><em><span style="color: black;">— </span></em><span style="color: black;">4, MLR (199.9) (AD) 187.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 241A and 265C</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— Discharge of accused— </span></strong><span style="color: black;">When <strong>charge groundless—</strong></span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">Accuseds may be discharged when the allegations are found groundless on the basis of materials on record. Special Judge cannot discharge the accused on extraneous matters beyond the record, be that under section 241A or 265C of the Cr. P.C.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Abid Hossain Babu Vs. Gaji Hai/ibuf Hoque &amp; others-</span></em> <em><span style="color: black;">4, MLR (1999)</span></em> <span style="color: black;">(HC) 55.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 247-Non-appearance of complainant- consequence of</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">Implication of section 247 is altogether different from that of section 431 Cr.P.C. Failure of complainant to appear on the date of appearance of the accused or on any subsequent date of hearing does not confer any absolute right of the accused for acquittal.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Ruhul AmLn</span></em> <em><span style="color: black;">another Vs. Rezia</span></em> <em><span style="color: black;">Begum &amp; another-   </span></em><span style="color: black;">1, MLR (1996) (HC) 279.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 241A / 265-C-Discharge of accused—</span></strong><span style="color: black;">­Accused cannot be discharged under section 241A / 265-C of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 when there are primafacie ingredients of the offence alleged to stifle the prosecution before trial. The nature of offence can well be thrashed out in the trial.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Mozibul Plaque (Gazij and others Vs. Ahid Hossain Babu.-</span></em><em><span style="color: black;">— </span></em><span style="color: black;">5 MLR (2000) (AD) 63.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 245(1) and 171</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></strong><span style="color: black;"> Responsibility of police to produce</span> <span style="color: black;">witness-Under Section 171 Cr.P.C. it is responsibility of the police to produce witness before the court on the date of hearing of the case. When witness is not produced, the Magistrate has rightly acquitted the accused under section 245(1).</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Mobarak All and others Vs. Mobaswir Alt and. others</span></em><em><span style="color: black;">— </span></em><span style="color: black;">1, MLR (1996) (AD) 406,</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 242 and 256D—</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">Commencement of trial</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></strong><span style="color: black;">When</span> <span style="color: black;">starts-Section 242 and</span> <span style="color: black;">D- Trial of a</span> <span style="color: black;">Criminal  case commences with the</span> <span style="color: black;">framing of charge S.M.   </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Akbor All   Vs.   The -State</span></em><em><span style="color: black;">—</span></em> <span style="color: black;">1. MLR (1996) (HC)   355,</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 247—</span></strong><span style="color: black;">Acquittal on ground</span> <span style="color: black;">of non-appearance of complainant-Section 247, provides for issue of</span> <span style="color: black;">summons to the accused for</span> <span style="color: black;">appearance for hearing the case.</span> <span style="color: black;">Acquittal of the accused on ground of</span> <span style="color: black;">non-appearance  of the complainant</span> <span style="color: black;">on such date is illegal. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Shajib (Md) and others Vs. Md. Abdul Khaleque Akand and others</span></em><em><span style="color: black;">— </span></em><span style="color: black;">4, MLR (1999) (AD) 145.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;"> </span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 247— Acquittal-Section 403— Bar to second Complaint—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 561A</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— Quashment of proceedings— No criminal proceedings lie on contractual dispute of civil nature—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">When the accused was acquitted under section 247 Cr. P.C. second complaint on the self same allegations is not entertainable in view of the bar under section 403 Cr.P.C. Moreover no criminal proceedings lie in respect of civil dispute arising out of business contractual</span> <span style="color: black;">obligations. Such</span> <span style="color: black;">proceedings are liable to be quashed under section 561A Cr.P.C. being abuse of the process of law.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Dwan Obaidur Rahman VS. The State </span></em><em><span style="color: black;">— </span></em><span style="color: black;">4, MLR (1999) (AD) 257.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 256C and 256D— Discharge of the accused when there is no sufficient materials on record to frame charge—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">The provisions of section 265C and 265D are not the mere formalities.</span> <span style="color: black;">These are in fact the substitute in abridged form of Chapter XVIII of the Code of Criminal Procedure. These provisions cast important duty upon the Sessions Judge to scrutinise the materials on record inorder to satisfy himself as to whether those materials justify the framing of charge against the accused. When the Sessions Judge fails to discharge his duty as above the High Court Division can rightly interfere in order to prevent vexatious trial and abuse of the process of law in exercise of its revisional jurisdiction.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Jobaida Rashid Vs. The State</span></em><em><span style="color: black;">— </span></em><span style="color: black;">2, MLR(1997) (HC) 230.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 265-C-Supply of copies of documents to accused</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">Advocates of the accused are entitled to go through the papers and documents relied upon by the prosecution for framing charge.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Hussain Muhammad Ershad Vs. The State</span></em><em><span style="color: black;">— 1, </span></em><span style="color: black;">MLR (1996) (HC) 4.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;"> </span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 339B- Publication in the news paper for trial of accused </span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">in </span></strong><span style="color: black;">absentia</span><span style="color: black;">—­The requirement of law is that before trial, publications must be made in two national dailies having wide circulation. Whether a daily news paper published from Bogra is of wide circulation is a matter of fact. When no objection was raised before the trial court in this regard, no such objection can be raised subsequently. The publication in two daily news papers is a sufficient compliance with the requirement of law.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;"> </span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">FazerPK, (Md.) alias FazerAli Vs. the </span></em><span style="color: black;">State</span><span style="color: black;">— 5 MLR(2000)(HC) 351.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 339C- Application of Amending Act No XLII of 1992 to Pending Cases</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— Stoppage and revival of proceedings—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">The purpose of section 339C(4) was not to give the accused a right not to be tried any more on the same charge or a clean bill of acquittal. Stoppage of trial did not mean an absolute vested right of release of the accused because such right was equally attended with the right of the prosecution to revive the proceedings. With the repeal of sub-section (4) of section 339 C both the rights of release and revival are </span><span style="color: black;">gone. Section 6 of Act XLII of 1992 is only applicable to proceedings which were stopped before 1-11-1992. The newly amended procedural law will be applicable to pending cases although instituted when the old provision was in force.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Abdul Wadud Vs. The State</span></em><em><span style="color: black;">— </span></em><span style="color: black;">1, MLR (1996) (AD) 66.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;"> </span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 339D- Revival of proceedings</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></strong><strong> <span style="color: black;">On application of Public Prosecutor</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">Public Prosecutor is not the Government. He represents the State in a case of which he Is in charge during enquiry, trial or appeal. Application filed by Public Prosecutor for revival of the proceedings stopped due to expiry of the time-limit is the sufficient compliance of section 339D and such an action is an action deemed to be on behalf the Government so long not disowned.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Alimuddin &amp; others Vs. The State</span></em><em><span style="color: black;">— </span></em><span style="color: black;">1. MLR (1996) (AD) 364.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Section 439— Section 561A-</strong>Quashment of judgment— Not permissible— When ao legal infirmity—</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">The order of the Sessions Judge setting aside the order of discharge under section 241A Cr.Pc. passed in exercise of his power under section 439 of the Code upon consideration of the materials on record, is not liable to be interfered with because such order suffers neither from any illegality nor from any legal infirmity. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em>Morshed Ali and others Vs. The Stale</em><em>— </em>2, MLR (1997) (AD) 87.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Section 342- Examination of accused - Opportunity to explain conduct in defence</strong><strong>—</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">Examination of accused under section 342 Cr.P.C. is not an idle formality or a mere routine. A duty is cast upon the court by this section to bring to the notice of the accused every incriminating piece of evidence for affording him an opportunity to offer his explanation in his defence.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> <em>Jyoli </em><em>Prokash</em> <em>Dutta Vs. the State--</em> 4, MLR (1999).(HC) 81.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Section   342</strong><strong>—   Examination   of</strong><strong> accused - Statement of accused-Mot to be used against accused</strong><strong>—</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">The purpose of examination of an accused under section 342 of the Code of Criminal Procedure is to provide an opportunity to an accused to explain his conduct and circumstance in relation to the evidence adduced by the prosecution which is only for the benefit of the accused. Such statement cannot be used against the accused by the court nor this can be used by the prosecution to fill up any gap in its case.  </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em>Shah Alam Vs. State 42 DLR (AD) 31.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Section 342</strong><strong>— Omission, to examine an accused under section 342 Cr.P.C.— Legal effect of—</strong>­Examination of accused by Court under section 432 of the Code of Criminal Procedure is a mandatory requirement of law. Omission to examine an accused u/s 342 is a fatal defect which is not curable under section 537 Cr.P.C. Therefore the conviction and sentence passed in such trial is not sustainable in law. The appropriate course is to set aside the conviction and sentence and send the case for examination of the accused with direction to proceed on to dispose of the case by writing a fresh judgment in accordance with law.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> <em>Abdul Gqfur Vs. Jogesh Chandra Roy, 43 DLR (AD) 62.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Section 410</strong><strong>— Appeal against conviction and sentence passed by Sessons</strong> <strong>Judge—Scope</strong> <strong>of</strong><strong> interference </strong><strong>—</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">The appellate Court has to discuss the evidence on record while deciding an appeal. When the appellate court without discussing the evidence in details affirmed the findings of the trial court, the Appellate Division upon scrutiny of evidence on record found nothing wrong in the judgment of the appellate court and as such the same is not interfered with. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em>Altaf Hossain Vs. The State</em><em>— </em>5, MLR (2000)(AD) 205.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: SutonnyMJ; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">1998 mv‡ji †dŠR`vwi Kvh©wewa</span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">—</span></em></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: SutonnyMJ; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">aviv 342</span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">— </span></em></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: SutonnyMJ; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">Av`vjZ KZ©…K Awfhy‡³i cix¶v Kib</span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">—</span></em></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: SutonnyMJ; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">wePviKv‡j M„nxZ I wjwce×K…Z ¯^v¯’¨ I Awfhy‡³i mswk­óZv e¨vL¨v c~e©K Awfhy‡³i e³e¨ wjwce× Kib †dŠR`vwi Kvh©wewai 342 avivi weavbvbyhvqx wePvi‡Ki Aek¨ cvjbxq KZ©e¨| Awfhy³ wg_¨v e³e¨ cÖ`vb Kwi‡Z cv‡ib A_ev †Kvb cÖKvi e³e¨ cÖ`vb nB‡Z weiZ _vwK‡Z cv‡ib, †mB Kvi‡b Awfhy‡³i wei“‡× Av`vjZ KZ©…K †Kvb weiƒc avibv †cvlY Kiv hvB‡ebv| †Kvb Aciva m¤c‡K© Awfhy‡³i wei“‡× †Kvb Awf‡hvM cÖYqb Kiv nq bvB GBiƒc †Kvb Aciv‡ai Rb¨ Kvnv‡KI kvw¯’ cÖ`vb Kiv hvq bv| <em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">Avãyi iv¾vK ZvjyK`vi ebvg ivóª </em></span><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">—</span></strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">3, MLR (1998) (HC) 137.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';"> </span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Section 349A—</strong><strong> Sessions judge court is not a successor court of Special Martial Law  court </strong><strong>— </strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">Conviction may be passed on the evidence partly recorded by one Sessions Judge and partly by another Sessions Judge. A Sessions Judge is not a successor court of Special Martial Law Court and as such the Sessions Judge cannot pass conviction on the basis of evidence recorded by Special Martial Law Court. After getting back Hie case record from the Special Martial Law Court, the Sessions Judge ought to have resummoned the witnesses for exmination after framing charge. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em>The State Vs.</em> <em>Colam Mostaja and others</em><em>— 1, </em>MLR (1996) (AD) 320.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';"> </span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 352-</span></strong><strong> <span style="color: black;">No limit to appointment of defence lawyers</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">Section 352 does not authorise the Sessions Judge to limit the appointment of lawyers by each accused. Order limiting the appointment of lawyers by the accused is absolutely without jurisdiction.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Hussain Muhammad Ershad Vs. the State</span></em><em><span style="color: black;">—1, </span></em><span style="color: black;">MLR (1996) (HC) 3.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section </span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">417</span></strong><span style="color: black;"> <strong>and 439— Appeal or revision against</strong></span> <strong><span style="color: black;">acquittal</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— Revision lies on filing of</span></strong> <strong><span style="color: black;">an appeal</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">In a state prosecution case appeal lies at the instance of the state to the Court of Session under section 417(1)03) against acquittal passed by Magistrate. When the state fails to prefer appeal, the informant stake­holder of interest in the result of the case may prefer revision before the Court of Session under section 439A Cr.P.C within 60 days. When both appeal and revision are filed against the same order of acquittal, the revision dies a natural death on filing</span> <span style="color: black;">the appeal.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;"> <em>Abu Taher and others Vs. Hasina Begum and another</em></span><em><span style="color: black;">— </span></em><span style="color: black;">3, MLR (1998) (HC) 69.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;"> </span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 439</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— Revisional application </span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">does</span></strong><span style="color: black;"> <strong>not lie </strong>at <strong>a belated stage—</strong></span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">When the trial has already began and some of the witnesses are already examined, the matter as to whether the charges are established or not the determination of which rests with the trial court. The propriety of framing charge is now the matter of the past. At this belated stage the Revisional application does not lie.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Nazrul Islam and others Vs.
