Abdur Rahman &amp; 4 others</span></em><em><span style="color: black;">— 2, </span></em><span style="color: black;">MLR(1997) (AD) 125.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 561 A—Quashment of proceedings—Allegations being preposterous and abuse of the process of court—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">When the allegations are preposterous, the proceedings are abuse of the process of the court, and are opposed to law, and the allegations do not constitute an offence or there is no proof or evidence </span><span style="color: #272b11;">in </span><span style="color: black;">support of the charge, such proceedings can </span><span style="color: #272b11;">well </span><span style="color: black;">be quashed under section 561A and not otherwise.</span> <em><span style="color: black;">Ali Akkas Vs.</span></em><span style="color: black;"> <em>Enayet Hossain and others</em></span><em><span style="color: black;">—2, </span></em><span style="color: black;">MLR(1997) (AD) 166.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 561A—</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">Quashment of proceedings</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— Preventing abuse of the process of court—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;"> </span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Nari-o-Shishu Nirjatan (Bishes Babsta) Ain 1995</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— Proceedings—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">In order to bring the offence punishable under section 366 of the Penal Code or within the mischief of the Nari-O-Shishu Nirjatan (Beshesh Babstha) Ain 1995 the ingredients constituting such offence must be present. When a girl above 18 years of age in her own accord went out of the custody of her father and married the accused without any inticement such an act does not come within the mischief of the Nari-o-Shishu Nirjatan (Bishes Babstha) Ain 1995. The case so started being abuse of the process of law can well be quashed by exercise of the inherent jurisdiction of the High Court Division under section 561A Cr. P.C.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Md Manik </span></em><em><span style="color: black;">@ Akkash Khan Vs. The State— 2, </span></em><span style="color: black;">MLR(1997) (HC) 98.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;"> </span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 561A</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— Quashment of dismissal of appeal made on own seeking of the appellant— Not permissible—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">Order of dismissal of appeal on the own seeking of the appellant is not liable to be quashed as the same does not amount to abuse of the process of the court. The convict-petitioner can get the benefit of the decision in the other appeal brought by the co-convict.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Shamsar Rahman  alias Shamsu</span></em> <em><span style="color: black;">Moral and another Vs.  The State</span></em><span style="color: black;">— 3, MLR (1998) (HC) 96.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 561A- Inherent power of the High Court Division</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— to grant division to under trial prisoner— <em>The Jail Code-Paragraph </em>910- Grant of Division-1   status to under   trial prisoners—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">To allow Division-I status to under trial prisoner is within the authority of the trial court subject to the approval of the District Magistrate. When by reason of superior mode of living and high social status the under trial prisoner deserves the Division I, there can be no reason to deny him such status on flimsy grounds. In such a situation the High Court Division can interfere in exercise of its inherent power.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Khairozaman (Major Reid.) vs. The Stale</span></em><em><span style="color: black;">— 3, </span></em><span style="color: black;">MLR (1998) (HC) 210.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 561A- Quashment of proceeding— Where not tenable—</span></strong> <strong><span style="color: black;">Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— Section 5(2)— Offence of </span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">Criminal   misconduct   triable   </span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">by</span></strong><strong> <span style="color: black;">Special Judge</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong> </strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Penal Code I860</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— Section 21</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— Public servant— Bank Companies</span></strong><strong> <span style="color: black;">Act, 1991</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— Section    11O—    Managers    and</span></strong><strong> <span style="color: black;">officers of Bank where the Government have share holding interest are public servants</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">Manager of the IFIC Bank Ltd. in which the Government have 40% share is a public servant within the meaning of section 21 of the Penal Code, 1860 as amended by Act No. 10 of 1982 read with section 110 of the Bank Companies Act, 1991 and as such the offence committed by him under section 5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 and section 409, 477A and 462(a) of the Perial Code are triable by the Special Judge and the proceedings thereof cannot be quashed under section 561A of the Code of. Criminal Procedure, 1898.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">International Finance Investment and </span></em><span style="color: black;">Commerce BanJc Ltd Vs. <em>Abdul </em>Quayum &amp; another</span><span style="color: black;">— 4, MLR (1999) (AD) <em>340.</em></span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 561A— Section 409/109—</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">Quashment</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—When no offence is</span></strong> <strong><span style="color: black;">disclosed- proceeding liable to be quashed</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—­Prevention   of   Corruption   Act<sub>B </sub>1947— Section 5(2)—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">Unless there are ingredients of misappropriation and criminal misconduct, no offence under section 409 of the Penal Code 1860 and section 5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 are committed. Consultant charging additional amount for additional work cannot be liable for criminal prosecution. Proceedings being illegal and abuse of the process of law are quashed.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Lailun</span></em><span style="color: black;"> <em>Nahar Ekram Vs. The State</em></span><em><span style="color: black;">— </span></em><span style="color: black;">4, MLR (1999) (HC) 179.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section </span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">561A— Quashment of proceedings— Insufficiency of evidence is no ground for quashment—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;">Inherent power of the High Court Division under section 561A Cr.P.C. is extra-ordinary power which should be exercised very sparingly with caution for preventing abuse of the process of the court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Question of insufficiency of evidence does not fall within the purview of scrutiny under section 561A Cr.P.C. When the tribunal did not lack in jurisdiction and the case was not one of no evidence, conviction and sentence awarded by the tribunal therein cannot be quashed.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;"> <em>Nazrul Islam alias Amirul Islam Vs. The State</em></span><em><span style="color: black;">— 4, </span></em><span style="color: black;">MLR (1999) (HC) 327.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">561A— Quashment of proceedings under section 406, 420 and 109 of the Penal Code against Bank guarantor—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">A reque: is not false representation or inducement on the part of the guarantor with the Bank. Missing of certain quantity of imported goods during the process of delivery does not constitute offence under section 406, 420 and 109 of the Penal Code against the accused guarantor with the Bank. When the proceedings tantamount to abuse of the process of the Court, the High Court Division in exercise of its inherent power under section 561A Cr.P.C. can quash the proceedings without compelling the accused to wait till hearing under section 241A Cr. P.C. for the remedy.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Mohammad Habib and another Vs. The State</span></em><em><span style="color: black;">— </span></em><span style="color: black;">4, MLR (1999) (HC) 334.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;"> </span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 561A</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— Quashment of proceedings under section 406 of the Penal Code—Inrespect of loan—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">A truck purchased with loan money taken from Bank against agreement and subsequently it was sold in violation of agreement and by errasing registration number and Chesis number. These allegations primafacie constitute offence under section 406 of the Penal Code and as such the proceedings can not be quashed.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Ruhul Amin Vs. Md. Nazrul Islam and another.</span></em><em><span style="color: black;">— </span></em><span style="color: black;">5, MLR(2000) (AD) 320.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 561A- Quashment of proceedings or sentence-Explosive Substance Act, 1908</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— Possession of explosive substance must be exclusive and not c onstructive—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">In order to sustain a conviction of possession of explosive substance, the possession must be exclusive. No conviction can be based on constructive possession of explosive substance.</span> <span style="color: black;">Proceedings in a criminal case or a sentence may be quashed when the offence alleged does not constitute any offence or on ground of coramnon-judice or otherwise for securing the ends of justice.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;"> </span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Shahidul Vs. The State- </span></em><span style="color: black;">5, MLR (2000) (HC) 107.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 561A</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— Quashment of proceeding— </span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">Sessions</span></strong><span style="color: black;"> <strong>Judge can not direct Magistrate to take cognizance—</strong></span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">The law is well settled that a Sessions Judge can not in exercise of his revisional power, direct a Magistrate to take cognizance of any offence. In appropriate case he can direct further enquiry by the Magistrate. Direction of the Sessions Judge to the Magistrate to take cognizance being illegal is setaside.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;"> </span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">A.Rouf and others Vs. The State &amp; another</span></em><em><span style="color: black;">—5, </span></em><span style="color: black;">MLR(2000) (HC) 131.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 561 A—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Special Powers Act, 1974</strong><strong>— Section 27—</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Quashment of proceedings</strong><strong>— Not permissible— No wrong in sending complaint after examination of complainant under section 200 Cr.P.C. to police for investigation under section 27 of the Special</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Powers Act, 1974</strong><strong>—</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">There is nothing wrong in sending the complaint to the Police for investigation after examination of the complainant under section 200 of the Code of Criminal Procedure where cognizance can not be taken except upon a police report as required by section 27 of the Special Powers Act, 1974. It is not correct that only the Magistrate competent to take cognizance can send such complaint to the police for investigation. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em>Golam Rahman Vs. The State and another</em><em>— </em>5 MLR (2000) (HC) 239.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Seection 561A</strong><strong>— Quashment of proceedings—Non-payment</strong> <strong>of</strong> <strong>Customs duty does not constitute criminal offence</strong><strong>—</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">The non-payment of customs duties for purchase of used car in Bangladesh does not constitute offence under section 420, 406 of the Penal Code read with section 156(8) of the Customs Act, 1969 and as such the proceedings being abuse of the process of the Court are quashed. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">Golam <em>Sarwar Vs. The State</em><em>— </em>5, MLR (2000)(HC) 287. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">non-judice or otherwise for securing the ends of justice. <em>Shahidul Vs. The State- </em>5, MLR (2000) (HC) 107.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Section 561A</strong><strong>— Quashment of proceeding— </strong><strong>Sessions Judge can not direct Magistrate to take cognizance—</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">The law is well settled that a Sessions Judge can not in exercise of his revisional power, direct a Magistrate to take cognizance of any offence. In appropriate case he can direct further enquiry by the Magistrate. Direction of the Sessions Judge to the Magistrate to take cognizance being illegal is setaside. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em>A.Rouf and others Vs. The State &amp; another</em><em>—5, </em>MLR(2000) (HC) 131.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Section 561 A—</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Special Powers Act, 1974</strong><strong>— Section 27—</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Quashment of proceedings</strong><strong>— Not permissible— No wrong in sending complaint after examination of complainant under section 200 Cr.P.C. to police for investigation under section 27 of the Special</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Powers Act, 1974</strong><strong>—</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">There is nothing wrong in sending the complaint to the Police for investigation after examination of the complainant under section 200 of the Code of Criminal Procedure where cognizance can not be taken except upon a police report as required by section 27 of the Special Powers Act, 1974. It is not correct that only the Magistrate competent to take cognizance can send such complaint to the police for investigation. <em>Golam Rahman Vs. The State and another</em><em>— </em>5 MLR (2000) (HC) 239.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong> </strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Seection 561A</strong><strong>— Quashment of proceedings—Non-payment</strong> <strong>of</strong> <strong>Customs duty does not constitute criminal offence</strong><strong>—</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">The non-payment of customs duties for purchase of used car in Bangladesh does not constitute offence under section 420, 406 of the Penal Code read with section 156(8) of the Customs Act, 1969 and as such the proceedings being abuse of the process of the Court are quashed. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em>Golam</em> <em>Sarwar Vs. The State</em><em>— </em>5, MLR (2000)(HC) 287.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Section 561A—</strong><strong>Quashment of proceedings under section 406, 420 and 109 of the Penal Code against Bank guarantor</strong><strong>—</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">A request is not false representation or inducement on the part of the guarantor with the Bank. Missing of certain quantity of imported goods during the process of delivery does not constitute offence under section 406, 420 and 109 of the Penal Code against the accused guarantor with the Bank, When the proceedings tantamount to abuse of the process of the Court, the High Court Division in exercise of its inherent power under section 561A Cr.P.C. can quash the proceedings without compelling the accused to wait till hearing under section 241A Cr. P.C. for the remedy. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em>Mohammad Habib and another Vs. The State</em><em>— </em>4, MLR (1999) (HC) 334.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong> </strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Penal Code 1860</strong><strong>— Section 406— Section    581A-    Quashment    of</strong><strong> proceedings</strong><strong>— </strong>In certain cases breach of contract may   constitute   criminal   liability. Where there are primafacie criminal ingredients in connection with the breach of contract, the proceedings in a criminal case cannot be quashed under section 561A Cr.P.C. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong> </strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em>Rastom Ali Matubbar (Md.) @ Alam Vs. Mohammad Salahuddin and another</em><em>— </em>5 MLR (2000) (HC) 50.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong> </strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Section 410—</strong><strong> Appeal against conviction-Limitation</strong><strong>— Condonation of delay—</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">Dispute was settled in a salish and the complainant agreed to withdraw the case. On this belief the accused thereafter did not appear and was convicted and sentenced in absentia. 4 years and 9 months after the conviction appellant on coming to know about the order of conviction and sentence preferred appeal with a prayer for condonation of delay which was rejected on ground of inordinate delay. The High Court Division took liberal view and allowed the petition for condonation of delay in admitting the appeal for giving a chance for reviewing the order of conviction and sentence. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em>Abdul Mannan Vs. the State</em>— 5, MLR (2000) (HC) 280.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Section 9(3) 29C, 31(4), 409</strong><strong>— Assistant Sessions Judge deemed to be Additional Sessions Judge — not to be so deemed for all purposes—</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">An Assistant Sessions Judge specially empowered and deemed to be an Additional Sessions Judge shall have limited power to try Sessions cases and pass higher sentence except a sentence of death. An Assistant Sessions Judge deemed to be appointed as Additional Sessions Judge can not hear appeals, revisions, reference and reviews and as such those are to be heard by the Sessions Judge or Additional Sessions Judge as the case may be under section 409 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em>Abul Kashem Vs. The State 43 DLR (AD) 77.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong> </strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Section 417 and 423</strong><strong>— Conversion of finding of acquittal into one of conviction- when permissible—</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">The correct position of law is that the finding of acquittal can be converted into conviction only in an</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">appeal under section 417 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em>Mofizuddin Vs. State-</em> <em>40 DLR</em> <em>(AD) 286.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Section 241-A</strong><strong>— Alibi- When can be taken—</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">Alibi as a defence can only be taken at the time of trial. Magistrate is not competent to discharge an accused merely on the filing of some papers supporting alibi. Such an order of discharge passed by Magistrate at pretrial stage is grossly illegal and is not sustainable in law. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em>Nannu Gazi Vs. Awlad Hossain-43 DLR (AD) 63.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 439</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— Fresh bail petition not necessary while filing Revisional application—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">When the petitioners were already on bail granted by the appellate court it is not necessary that while moving revisional application they should file separate application for bail. Direction given by High Court Division for filing separate application for bail upon rejectio i of the prayer for bail is not proper and is not in keeping with the normal practice and procedure traditionally followed by the High Court Division in revision. The Appellate Division in such a case directed the appellants' to be on bail since granted by the appellate court below till disposal of the revision case.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Baneazuddin Ahmed Vs. The State-43 DLR (AD) 120.</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 439A and 561 A</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— Inherent power of the Court not circumscribed by the revisional </span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">power—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">Inherent power of the High Court Division under section 561A Cr.P.C. is extra-ordinary power which should be very sparingly exercised for securing the ends of justice in appropriate case covered by the provisions of the section itself. Inherent jurisdiction of High Court Division can well be invoked by a party who had lost in revision before the Sessions Judge in a fit case.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Amiml Islam Vs. Mujibar Rahman-45 DLR (AD) 9.</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 344 and 561A</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— </span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">Stay of proceedings in view of pending civil suit-</span></strong><span style="color: black;">Where a suit with respect to certain disputed documents has been instituted before lodging of FIR on the allegations of forgery of the same where the civil court has yet to examine the original documents, the proceedings of the subsequent criminal case may be stayed till the disposal of the suit.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Zakir Hos sain and others Vs. The State - 43 DLR (AD) 102.</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 561A</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— </span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">Quashment of proceedings— not to be </span></strong><span style="color: black;">allowed <strong>except in a clear </strong>case <strong>of no </strong>offence <strong>and abuse of the process of court—</strong></span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;">Unless there is a clear case of no offence constituted or disclosed from the materials contained in the FIR or complaint and the continuation of the proceedings will be an abuse of the process of the court, the High Court Division will be loath to stifle a prosecution at the initial stage.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> <em><span style="color: black;">Alhaj Md. Sirajuddowla Vs. The State- 43 DLR (AD) 198.</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;"> </span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Section 561A- Section 406, 409 of Penal Code read with section 5 (2) of Act II of of 1947- Loan taken does not constitute offence</strong><strong>—</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">The exemption of loan granted by Board does not constitute offence under section 406/409 of Penal Code read with section 5(2) of Act II of 1947 against the Managing Director. The proceedings being illegal are quashed under section 561A Cr.P.C. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em>SekanderAli Vs. The State</em><em>— </em>1, MLR (1996) (HC) 29.</span></p><p> </p></div></div>
92	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE CODE OF CRIMINAL PROCEDURE, 1898</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p align="center"><b>THE CODE OF CRIMINAL PROCEDURE, 1898</b></p><p align="center">(ACT NO. V OF 1898)</p><p align="right">[22nd March, 1898]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 An Act to consolidate and amend the law relating to the Criminal Procedure.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to consolidate and amend the law relating to Criminal Procedure; It is hereby enacted as follows:</p><p align="center">PART I</p><p align="center">PRELIMINARY</p><p align="center">CHAPTER I</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Short title Commencement</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1.(1) This Act may be called the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898; and it shall come into force on the first day of July, 1898.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Extent</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It extends to the whole of Bangladesh; but, in the absence of any specific provision to the contrary, nothing herein contained shall affect any special 2[ * * *] law now in force, or any special jurisdiction or power conferred, or any special form of procedure prescribed, by any other law for the time being in force.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Repealed</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. [Repealed by the Repealing and Amending Act, 1914 (Act No. X of 1914).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(1) Omitted</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3.(1) [Omitted by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Expressions in former Acts</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) In every enactment passed before this Code comes into force the expressions "Officer exercising (or 'having') the powers (or 'the full powers') of a Magistrate," "Subordinate Magistrate, first class," and "Subordinate Magistrate, second class," shall respectively be deemed to mean "Magistrate of the first class," "Magistrate of the second class" and "Magistrate of the third class," 3[ ***] the expression "Magistrate of the district" shall be deemed to mean "District Magistrate," 4[ ***].</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Definitions</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4.(1) In this Code the following words and expressions have the following meanings, unless a different intention appears from the subject or context:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5[ (a) "advocate", used with reference to any proceeding in any Court, means an advocate or a mukhtar authorised under any law for the time being in force to practise in any such Court and includes any other person appointed with the permission of the Court to act in such proceeding;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(aa) "Attorney-General" means the Attorney-General for Bangladesh, and includes also the Additional Attorney-General, the Deputy Attorney-General or the Assistant Attorney-General for Bangladesh, or, a Government advocate or such officer as the Government may, from time to time, appoint in this behalf:]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) "bailable offence" means an offence shown as bailable in the second schedule, or which is made bailable by any other law for the time being in force; and "non-bailable offence" means any other offence:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) "charge" includes any head of charge when the charge contains more heads than one:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) [Repealed by section 3 and Schedule II of the Repealing and Amending Act, 1923 (Act No. XI of 1923).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) Clerk of the State includes any officer specially appointed by the Chief Justice to discharge the functions given by this Code to the Clerk of the State:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) "cognizable offence" means an offence for, and "cognizable case" means a case in, which a Police-officer, may, in accordance with the second schedule or under any law for the time being in force, arrest without warrant:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g) [Omitted by the Schedule of the Adaptation of Central Acts and Ordinances Order, 1949.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h) "complaint" means the allegation made orally or in writing to a Magistrate, with a view to his taking action under this Code, that some person whether known or unknown, has committed an offence, but it does not include the report of a police-officer:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6[ (hh) "Court of Session" includes a Metropolitan Court of Session;]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) [Omitted by the Schedule of the Criminal Law (Extinction of Discriminatory Privileges) Act, 1949 (Act No. II of 1950).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">7[ (j) "High Court Division" means the High Court Division for criminal appeal or revision: ]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(k) "inquiry" includes every inquiry other than a trial conducted under this Code by a Magistrate or Court:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(l) "investigation" includes all the proceedings under this Code for the Collection of evidence conducted by a police-officer or by any person (other than a Magistrate) who is authorised by Magistrate in this behalf:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(m) "judicial proceeding" includes any proceeding in the course of which evidence is or may be legally taken on oath:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(n) "non-cognizable offence" means an offence for, and "non-cognizable case" means a case in, which a police-officer, may not arrest without warrant:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(o) "offence" means any act or omission made punishable by any law for the time being in force;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">it also includes any act in respect of which a complaint may be made under section 20 of the Cattle-trespass Act, 1871:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(p) "officer in charge of a police-station" includes, when the officer in charge of the police-station is absent from the station-house or unable from illness or other cause to perform his duties, the police-officer present at the station house who is next in rank to such officer and is above the rank of constable or, when the Government so directs, any other police-officer so present:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(q) "place" includes also a house, building, tent and vessel:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(r) [Omitted by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)]:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(s) "police-station" means any post or place declared, generally or specially, by the Government to be a police-station, and includes any local area specified by the Government in this behalf:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(t) "Public Prosecutor" means any person appointed under section 492, and includes any person acting under the directions of a Public Prosecutor 8[ * * *]:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">9[ (u) "Upazila" means a Upazila as defined in the Upazila Parisad Act, 1998 (Act. No. 24 of 1998)]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(v) and (w) [Omitted by section 2 of the Code of Criminal Procedure (Second Amendment) Ordinance, 1982 (Ordinance No. XXIV of 1982).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Words referring to acts</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Words which refer to acts done, extend also to illegal omissions; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Words to have same meaning as in Penal Code</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">all words and expressions used herein and defined in the Penal Code, and not hereinbefore defined, shall be deemed to have the meanings respectively attributed to them by that Code.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Construction of references</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">10[ 4A. -(1) In this Code, unless the context otherwise requires, any reference-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) without any qualifying word, to a Magistrate, shall be construed as a construed reference to a Judicial Magistrate;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) with a qualifying word not being a word clearly indicating a Judicial Magistrate shall be construed as a reference to a Magistrate as indicated in sub-section (2) (b);</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) to a Sub-divisional Magistrate shall be construed as a reference to-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) the District Magistrate if the functions exercisable are of the nature specified in clause (b) of sub-section (2); or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii) the Chief Judicial Magistrate or as the case may be, the Chief Metropolitan Magistrate, if the functions exercisable are of the nature specified in clause (a) of sub-section (2);</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) to an Assistant Sessions Judge, shall be construed as a reference to a joint Sessions Judge;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) to any area which is included in a Metropolitan area, shall be construed as a reference to such Metropolitan area;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) to any reference to a Magistrate of the first, second or third class in relation to an area which is included in a Metropolitan area, shall be construed as a reference to the Metropolitan Magistrate exercising jurisdiction in that area;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g) to a Magistrate of the first, second or third class in relation to an area outside a Metropolitan Area, shall be construed as a reference to a Judicial Magistrate of the first, second or third class exercising jurisdiction in that area.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Where, under any law for the time being in force other than this Code, the functions exercisable by a Magistrate relate to matters-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) which involve the appreciation or sifting of evidence or the formulation of any decision which exposes any person to any punishment or penalty or detention in custody pending investigation, inquiry or trial or other proceeding or would have the effect of sending him for trial before any Court, they shall subject to the provision of the Code, be exercisable by a judicial Magistrate; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) which are administrative or executive in nature, such as the granting of a licence, the suspension or cancellation of a licence, sanctioning a prosecution or withdrawing from a prosecution, they shall, subject as aforesaid, be exercisable by an Executive Magistrate.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Trial of offences under Penal Code</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5.(1) All offences under the Penal Code shall be investigated, inquired into, tried, and otherwise dealt with according to the provisions hereinafter contained.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Trial of offences against other laws</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) All offences under any other law shall be investigated, inquired into, tried, and otherwise dealt with according to the same provisions, but subject to any enactment for the time being in force regulating the manner or place of investigating, inquiring into, trying or otherwise dealing with such offences.</p><p align="center">PART II</p><p align="center">CONSTITUTION AND POWERS OF CRIMINAL COURTS AND OFFICES</p><p align="center">CHAPTER II</p><p align="center">OF THE CONSTITUTION OF CRIMINAL COURTS AND OFFICES</p><p align="center">A.—Classes of Criminal Courts</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Classes of Criminal Courts</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">11[ 6.(1) Besides the Supreme Court and the Courts constituted under any law for the time being in force, other than this Code, there shall be two classes of Criminal Courts in Bangladesh, namely:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) Courts of Sessions ; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) Courts of Magistrates.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) There shall be two classes of Magistrate, namely: -</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) Judicial Magistrate; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) Executive Magistrate.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) There shall be four classes of judicial Magistrate, namely: -</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) Chief Metropolitan Magistrate in Metropolitan Area and Chief judicial Magistrate to other areas;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) Magistrate of the first class, who shall in Metropolitan area, be known as Metropolitan Magistrate;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) Magistrate of the second class; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) Magistrate of the third class.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Explanation:</b> For the purpose of this sub-section, the word "Chief Metropolitan Magistrate" and "Chief judicial Magistrate" shall include "Additional Chief Metropolitan Magistrate" and "Additional Chief judicial Magistrate" respectively.]</p><p align="center">B. —Territorial Divisions</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Sessions divisions and districts</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">7.(1) Bangladesh shall consist of sessions divisions: and every sessions division shall, for the purposes of this Code, be a district or consist of districts.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power to alter divisions and districts</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Government may alter the limits or the number of such divisions and districts.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Existing divisions and districts maintained till altered</p><p style="text-align: justify;">. (3) The sessions divisions and districts existing when this Code comes into force shall be sessions divisions and districts respectively, unless and until they are so altered.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">12[ (4) 13[ A] Metropolitan Area shall, for the purposes of this Code, be deemed to be a sessions division.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power to divide districts into Upazilas etc</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">14[ 8. The Government may divide a district into Upazilas and, by notification in the official Gazette, fix or alter the limits of a Upazila or merge the areas of more than one Upazila into one Upazila and in so fixing, altering or merging, the Government shall ensure that the area of a Upazila is identical with the local area included in a Police Station.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Existing sub-divisions maintained</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) All existing sub-divisions which are now usually put under the charge of a Magistrate shall be deemed to have been made under this Code.</p><p align="center">C.—Courts and Offices</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Court of Sessions</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">9.(1) The Government shall establish a Court of Session for every sessions division, and appoint a judge of such Court 15[ ; and the Court of Session for 16[ a] Metropolitan Area shall be called the Metropolitan Court of Session.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Government may, by general or special order in the official Gazette, direct at what place or places the Court of Session shall hold its sitting; but, until such order is made, the Courts of Session shall hold their sittings as heretofore.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The Government may also appoint Additional Sessions Judges and Assistant Sessions Judges to exercise jurisdiction in one or more such Courts.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">17[ ***]]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">18[ (3A) The members of the Bangladesh Judicial Service shall be appointed as Sessions Judge, Additional Sessions Judge and Joint Sessions Judge in accordance with the rules framed by the President under the proviso to Article 133 of the constitution to exercise jurisdiction in one or more of such areas.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) A Sessions Judge of one sessions division may be appointed by the Government to be also an Additional Sessions Judge of another division, and in such case he may sit for the disposal of cases at such place or places in either division as the Government may direct.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) All Courts of Session existing when this Code comes into force shall be deemed to have been established under this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Executive Magistrates</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">19[ 10.(1) In every district and in every Metropolitan Area, the Government shall appoint as many persons as it thinks fit to be Executive Magistrates and shall appoint one of them to be the District Magistrate.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Government may also appoint any Executive Magistrate to be an Additional District Magistrate, and such Additional District Magistrate shall have all or any of the powers of a District Magistrate under this Code or under any other law for the time being in force, as the Government may direct.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Whenever in consequence of the office of a District Magistrate becoming vacant, any officer succeeds temporarily to the chief executive in the administration of the district, such officer shall, pending the orders of the Government, exercise all the powers and perform all the duties respectively conferred and imposed by this Code on the District Magistrate.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) The Government may, or subject to the control of the Government, the District Magistrate may, from time to time, by order define local areas within which the Executive Magistrate may exercise all or any
