text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">The Constitution of Bangladesh Article 47</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">The High Court Division is of the view that the respondents are under trial pris­oners in connection with different cases and on consideration of their social and political status, they can not be denied and/or deprived of their right or entitle­ment of benefits and status as per Jail Code. In arriving at such conclusion the High Court Division has taken into con­sideration Rule 910 of the Bengal Jail Code. <em>Government of the People's vs.Abdul Quader Mollah (S.K. Sinha J) (Civil) 8 ADC 972.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Article 102</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">It appears that the writ-petitioner is an elected donor member of the Governing body of Jhargram Fazil Madrasa, Bag-mara, Rajshahi. This committee was duly approved by the Bangladesh Madrasa Education Board on 14.08.2006. On an allegation of misap­propriation, the principal of the madrasa, the added writ-respondent No.6, was suspended by the Governing body by its resolution dated 04.01.2005. This decision was challenged in Other Class Suit No.59 of 2005, filed by the writ-respondent No.6, in the Court of Assistant Judge, Bagmara. In the mean­time, the Upa-Zilla Nirbahi Officer, the respondent No.4 who is the ex-officio Chairman of the Governing body, by his office order dated 19.04.2007, withdrew all allegations against the suspended principal and directed his reinstatement as the principal of the madrasa (Annex-ure-E to the writ petition). The legality of this Order has been challenged in the writ-petition, on the grounds inter-alia that the respondent No.4, passed the im­pugned order not in his capacity as the Chairman of the Governing body but as the Upa-Zilla Nirbahi Officer, an exec­utive of the Government. <em>Md. Abdus Samad vs. Md. Ismail Hos-sain Shakhider (A.B.M. Khairul Haque CJ) (Civil) 8 ADC 1000.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Article 102</span></strong></p><p class="Style3" style="margin-top: 1.7pt; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-pagination: widow-orphan;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">The petitioner No.4 contested the peti-</span><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> that the respon-dents were appointed purely on tempo-rary basis against a project with clear stipulation that the duration of their em-ployment will remain valid till the com- pletion of the project. In view of the above, the respondents have accrued no right to claim regularization of their service and thus, the writ petition is not<br/>maintainable.<span style="mso-tab-count: 1;">   </span><em>Government of Bangladesh vs. Mini Begum (S.K. Sinha J)(Civil) 8 ADC 1008.</em></span></p><p class="Style3" style="margin-top: 1.7pt; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-pagination: widow-orphan;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></em></p><p class="Style3" style="margin-top: 1.7pt; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly;"><strong><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Article 39, 108</span></em></strong></p><p class="Style3" style="margin-top: 1.7pt; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></em></p><p class="Style3" style="margin-top: 1.7pt;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">It has been held in the main judgment that the disclosure of true facts cannot be taken as a defence against the act of contempt. If presentation of facts is made in such a manner, so as to lead or provoke some one to disrespect or shake confidence on any Court of law, not to speak of the highest Court of the Country, such presentation is an act of contempt and the same has been ap­proved not only by all Superior Courts of the sub-continent but all Courts of law of the civilized world. This is the case in the instant proceeding. Md. Riaz Uddin Khan vs. Mahmudur Rahman (MohammadFazlul Karim CJ)(Civil) 9 ADC 104</span></em></p><p class="Style3" style="margin-top: 1.7pt; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-pagination: widow-orphan;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">The Constitution of Bangladesh Article 108</span></strong></p><p class="Style3" style="margin-top: .95pt; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-pagination: widow-orphan;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Undoubtly the press has freedom but</span><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> <span class="FontStyle13"><span style="mso-ansi-font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 11.0pt;">this freedom is controlled by the basic concepts of the written Constitution it­self and can be exercised within the lim­its allowed to its independence. If the press steps beyond the limits allowed it, or acting within its boundary, trespass on the administration of justice in a manner not justified by the law, its in­dependence is liable to be struck down by the Courts. Therefore, it is necessary to remember that though our press has independence they perform function within the limits prescribed by law and the relevant provisions of the Constitu­tion. In a democratic country governed by a written Constitution, it is the Con-stitution which is Supreme and Sover­eign. The Constitution has entrusted to the judiciary the task of construing the provisions of the Constitution. When a citizen challenged an article or com­mentary of a journalist on the ground that the journalist has written which is obscene or has scandalized the judiciary or has interfered with the administration of justice or has unconstitutionally tres­passed beyond his limits, it is for the Courts to determine the dispute and de­cide whether the writings are within the limits of independence. Adjudication of such a dispute is entrusted solely and exclusively to the judiciary of the coun­try and not on the journalists or colum­nists or academicians.A/t/. </span></span><span class="FontStyle14"><span style="mso-ansi-font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Riaz Uddin Khan vs. Mahmudur Rahman (S.K.</span></span></span></strong></p><p class="Style4" style="text-align: justify; mso-pagination: widow-orphan;"><span class="FontStyle14"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">SinhaJ)(Civil) 9 ADC</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Article 102</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Challenging the above decision of the authority, the petitioner obtained the Rule Nisi from the High Court Division which made the Rule absolute and de­clared Anncxure-'H' to the Writ Petition to have</span><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> <span style="letter-spacing: .5pt;">been issued without lawful au­thority. The salient findings of the High Court Division are as follows: The prayer of the petitioner for correc­tion was refused on the ground of delay of 30 years and no other reason was as­signed in the impugned order rejecting the prayer of the petitioner. The author­ity made a correction in respect of the name of one Md. K.M. Sayed after about 30 years and the date of birth of respondent No.5 was corrected as per Secondary School Certificate after 32 years. The reason assigned in the im­pugned order refusing his prayer was capricious, arbitrary and without any application of mind. The petitioner ob­tained a duplicate Secondary School Certificate as the original was lost and in this process he had to spend enough time collecting the same. The word "Fakir" in his name as well as in his fa­ther's name had rather complicated the case of the petitioner and in such a po­sition, the word 'Fakir' should not have been used after both the names to avoid such complication in the certificate, had it been a fake one. The existence of the word 'Fakir' in the name of the peti­tioner and also in the name of his father in the certificate proved its genuineness. <em>The Chairman BFIDC vs. Md. Hatem</em></span></span> <em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">AH (Syed Mahmud Hossain J) (Civil) 9 ADC 169</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">The Constitution of Bangladesh Arti­cle 102</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Mr. M. K. Rahman, learned Advocate along with Mr. Khurshid Alam Sarker, learned Advocate, appearing for the writ petitioners, submits that the High Court Division has failed to hold that the em­ployees previously absorbed as benefi­ciaries of the judgment of the High Court Division in writ petition No. 1522 of 2004 heard along with 99 other writ petitions do not belong to the same class and are not similarly situated or on an equal footing with the writ petitioners and as such, the impugned judgments and orders passed by the High Court Di­vision should be set aside. He further submits that the High Court Division ig­nored the fact that no express promise/undertaking/representation was ever made by the writ-respondents and as such, the writ-petitioners are not en­titled to be absorbed in LGED. <em>Chief Engineer LGED vs. Sanjoy Kumar Haider (Syed</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Article <strong>102</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Mr. Syed Amir-ul Islam, the learned Senior Counsel appearing for the appel­lant has advanced his argument in two</span> <em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Mahmud Hossain J) (Civil) 9 ADC 174</span></em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> lines. His first line of argument is that the petitioner was never a government employee even while he was serving under IRDP, that the 1RDP was not a government owned organization; rather it was an autonomous organization and the petitioner was appointed as Thana Project Officer by the authority of that non-government organization. <em>Bangladesh Rural Development Board vs. Mohammad Shahjahan (Nazmun Ara Sultana J) (Civil) 9 ADC<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">        </span>195</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Article 102</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">The facts necessary for disposal of this Civil Petition for Leave to Appeal, in short, are that one Md. Hossain Ali was allotted the plot in question by the Gov­ernment by a registered deed of lease dated 06.04.1962 for a period of 99 years. The said lessee constructed a res­idential house in the said plot and had been possessing the same. <em>Bangladesh represented by the Secretary vs. Nazirul Hoq (Nazmun Ara Sultana J)(Civil) 9 ADC 206</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Article 102</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">The High Court Division, on hearing both the sides, made the rule absolute holding that the impugned circular No. 10, so far it relates to its retrospec­tive effect, has not been made under any lawful authority and as such void and</span><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> <span style="letter-spacing: .5pt;">not applicable to the petitioner's case. In this impugned judgment the High Court Division also observed that the peti­tioner was eligible for promotion since 2001 and as such he is entitled to sen­iority over his juniors and to all finan­cial benefits from the date he was first superseded by his juniors. <em>Bangladesh Bank vs. Sukamal Sinha Choudhury (Nazmun Ara Sultana J)(Civil) 9 ADC 218</em></span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 6.25pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Article 31 and 40</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">The petitioner was a licensed currency dealer operating his business as a cur­rency money changer under license is­sued by the Bangladesh Bank. The terms and conditions of the license stip­ulated that he would follow the direc­tions given from time to time by way of circulars issued by Bangladesh Bank. The petitioner was issued with the li­cense dated 15.06.97 as proprietor of "James Money Changer" granted by Bangladesh Bank. By Memo dated 13.03.2001 he was informed about in­spection of his business by a visiting team of the Bank. Inspection took place on 13.03.2001, 28.03.2001 and 06.08.2001. <em>Mosharref Hossain vs. Governor, Bangladesh Bank (Muham­mad Imman AH J)(Civil) 9 ADC 263</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Article 102</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Whether the learned Judges of the High Court Division erred in law in having failed to take notice of the fact that the writ-petitioner had no locus standi to file the present writ petition for enforce­ment of an incomplete and inconclusive contract of lease and the writ petition was not maintainable, and whether the case bristles</span><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> <span style="letter-spacing: .5pt;">with disputed and compli­cated question of fact, which cannot be decided in writ jurisdiction. <em>Engineer A. B. Siddique vs. Kazi Akramuddin (Syed Mahmud Hossain J)(Civil) 9 ADC 279.</em></span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 6.7pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Article 102</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">In all the petitions the writ petitioners stated that they prayed for absorbing in the revenue set up but their prayers were unheeded to despite assurances given by the authority. The High Court Divi­sion noticed the Rules framed by the Government for regularizing the service in the revenue budget in respect of those officers and employees who are work­ing in the development projects and to determine their seniority by Gazette No­tification dated 28th June, 2005 and the decision of the ECNEC dated 10th June, 2008, and observed that the rules and the decision of ECNEC are sheet anchor for resolving the issues involved in the petitions. <em>Chief Engineer LGED vs. Sayeda Shahana Aktari (S.K. Sinha J) (Civil) 9 ADC 287</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Article 102</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">The High Court Division, on hearing the learned Advocates of both the sides and considering the facts and circum­stances and relevant Service Rules and also the reports of Medical Boards found that the petitioner was capable of working as Berthing Master and as such his release from service without offer­ing him the post of Berthing Master and without giving him any opportunity of being heard has been malafide, arbitrary and illegal. The High Court Division, accordingly decided also that the peti­tioner was entitled to remain in service till completion of 57 years of his age i.e. till 28.10.2004 and as such the peti­tioner is entitled to pension/gratuity and other benefits along with LPR and un­paid arrear of pay from August, 2000 till</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; tab-stops: dotted 170.4pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">the date of his retirement<span style="mso-tab-count: 1 dotted;">................. </span>(5)</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Chittagong Port Authority represented vs. Md. Azizul Islam Chowdhury (Naz-mun Ara Sultana J) (Civil) 9 ADC 351</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></em></p></div></div>
95	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">The Constitution of Bangladesh Arti­cle 102   </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  8 ADC 725, 8 ADC 752, 8 ADC 767, 8 ADC 782, 8 ADC 788, 8 ADC' 798, 8 ADC 811, 8 ADC 824,8 ADC 831, 8 ADC 834, 8 ADC 879,  8 ADC 941, 8 ADC. 956,  8 ADC960</p><p><b>Subject:</b>   Constitution of Bangladesh</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-10-31</p><!DOCTYPE html><p><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> <o:OfficeDocumentSettings> <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="19" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Subtle Emphasis"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="21" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Intense Emphasis"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="31" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Subtle Reference"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="32" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Intense Reference"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="33" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Book Title"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="37" Name="Bibliography"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="39" QFormat="true" Name="TOC Heading"/> </w:LatentStyles></xml><![endif]--><!-- [if gte mso 10]><style> /* Style Definitions */ table.MsoNormalTable	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;	mso-style-noshow:yes;	mso-style-priority:99;	mso-style-qformat:yes;	mso-style-parent:"";	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;	mso-para-margin:0in;	mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;	font-size:11.0pt;	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";	mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;	mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast;	mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;	mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;}</style><![endif]--></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">The Constitution of Bangladesh Arti­cle 102</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Writ petition in the High Court Division seeking a direction for regularizing their service against the posts advertised on the doctrine of legitimate expectation. Their case in short is that they entered in the service of Bangladesh Technical Ed­ucation Board as Master Roll workers. <em>Bangladesh Technical Education Board vs. Md. Anamul Haque (S.K. Sinha J) (Civil) 8 ADC 725</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">The Constitution of Bangladesh Ar­ticle 102</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">The High Court Division upon hearing the parties by the impugned judgment made the rule absolute on the reason­ings that the writ petitioners are stand­ing on the same footing with Block Supervisors and that the writ petitioners were discriminated in not giving them higher scale which they were entitled to. <em>Bangladesh Water Development Board vs. Md. Shafiqul Islam (S.K. Sinha J) (Civil) 8 ADC 752.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 4.8pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Article 102</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-right: .7pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.65pt .7pt .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">It is contended on behalf of the petition­ers that the High Court Division erred in law in directing to reinstate the writ petitioner in the service of the Corpora­tion in failing to consider that he was terminated from the service for miscon­duct under the provisions of the Service Regulation of the corporation. <em>Chair­man, Bangladesh Parjatan Corporation vs. Md. Shafiqul Islam (S.K. Sinha J)(Civil) 8 ADC 767.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.65pt .7pt .0001pt 0in;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: .7pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Article 27 and 102</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Rule 55(2) of the Chattagram Bandar Katripakka Karmachari Chakuri Pro-<strong><br/></strong>bidhanmala of 1991 provides that notwithstanding anything contained in<strong><br/></strong>this Probidhanmala, the competent authority may terminate the service of any <strong><br/></strong>employee without assigning any reason subject to giving notice of ninety days <strong><br/></strong>or in lieu thereof, salary of ninety days, that as per the provision of Rule 55(2) <strong><br/></strong>of Probidhanmala. </span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Arun Chandra Das vs Chittagong Port Authority (S.K. </span></em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">j<br/><em>Sinha J) (Civil) 8 ADC.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 6.25pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Article 102</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">That the Promotion Rules of 2002 con­taining marking system for academic qualification cannot be applied in case of promotion of the petitioners who had been serving as Deputy Secretaries at the time of framing of this Promotion Rules.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: .25pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Molla Md. Anwarul Hauqe vs. Govern­ment <span style="letter-spacing: 1.5pt;">of</span> the People's (Nazmun Ara Sul­tana J) (Civil) 8 ADC 782</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 5.75pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Article 102</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.9pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Mr. Murad Reza, learned Additional At­torney General appearing on behalf of | the respondent-petitioners, submits that the government scaled the main en­trance of the factory premises including : the godown as part of its lawful obliga- |</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">tion to obey the order of status-quo passed by the High Court Division in public interest and that the High Court Division failed to consider the same in passing the impugned order directing the respondent-petitioners to release im­ported wheat alleged to have been stored by respondent No.6 and as such the impugned order should be set aside. <em>Government of Bangladesh vs. Dhaka Match Industries (Syed Mahmud Hos-sain J)(Civil) 8 ADC 788.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 6.0pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Article 102</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">The High Court Division noticed that the petitioner claimed that his date of birth is 8.4.1946 as per annual confiden­tial report prepared and maintained by the respondents (appointing authority) and the annual confidential report shows that the date of birth of the peti­tioner is 8.4.1946. </span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">The Managing Direc­tor vs. Md. Ahsanullah (Sved Mahmud Ilossain <span style="letter-spacing: 1.5pt;">J)</span> (Civil) 8 ADC' 798.</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Article 102</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Peace Accord was signed and executed to facilitate the public interest in gen­eral, specially the people living in the Chittagong Hill Tracts in order to bring peace and harmony in the said region of Bangladesh so that the tribal and non-tribal people of Bangladesh living in the said area could co-exist there. It was also done to give effect to the constitu</span><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> <span style="letter-spacing: .5pt;">tional mandates for advancement of backward sections of the population and establishment of efficient local govern­ment institutions. The writ petition in­volved political and disputed question of facts and, as such, the same could not be reviewed by the High Court Division as it purported to challenge the execu­tion, signing and implementation of the Chittagong Hill Tracts Accord, 1997 dated 02.12.1997 (hereinafter referred to as the Peace Accord). Peace Accord was enacted taking into account the then political situation which existed in the Chittagong Hill Tracts and, as such, that cannot be the subject matter of judicial review of this Court. <em>Bangladesh vs. Md. Badiuzzaman (Md. Abdul Wahhab Miah J)(Civil) 8 ADC 811</em></span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 6.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Article 102</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">The voter list of Jhalokathi Pourashava | was prepared and published for each <span style="letter-spacing: -.5pt;">Ward,</span> and in June, 2010 it was detected <strong><span style="mso-font-width: 10%;">I </span></strong>that about 400 families of "Abason | Project Nos.l and 2" established by the then Government on the land of Uttar Kistakathi under Ward No.7 of Pona-balia Union Parishad have been enjoy­ing the facilities of Jhalokathi Pourashava though the 'Abason Project Nos.l and 2' had not been included in the Pourashava by the Gazette Notifica­tion published on 2nd July, 1998. The Councilor of Ward No.7, Jhalokathi Pourashava found that Kistakathi area, on which Abason Project Nos.l and 2' had been established, is part of Ward No.7 Ponabalita Union Parishad, but in­habitants of said Abason Project Nos.l and 2 had been included as voters of Ward No.7 of the Pourashava. The said issue was brought to the attention of Pourashava and a resolution was taken on 15th July, 2010 authorizing the writ petitioner for taking steps in that regard and subsequently the writ petitioner for­warded the resolution to the writ re­spondent No.2 requesting it to correct the voter list. However, the writ respon­dent Nos.2-5 without excluding the vot­ers of Uttar Kistikathi area declared the election schedule on 2nd December, 2010 for holding election of the Pourashava, and 672 voters have been added in Ward No.7 of Jhalokathi Pourashava illegally. <em>Afzal Miah vs. Abdul Halim Gazi (S.K. Sinha J)(Civil) 8 ADC 824</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 6.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Article 102</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: -.5pt;">We</span><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> find merit in the submissions of the learned advocate for the petitioners and are inclined to grant leave in both the petitions on the following grounds:</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; tab-stops: 15.1pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">I.<span style="mso-tab-count: 1;">   </span>Whether the High Court Division il-<br/>legally declared Rule 6 of the <span style="letter-spacing: -.5pt;">«sn#?J<br/></span></span><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: -.5pt;">f^fwMn </span><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Carfax wrsf/f*w fitfMn ^<span style="font-variant: small-caps;">t^j</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: .25pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 29.05pt; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: -.5pt;">&lt;rfe)</span><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> <span style="letter-spacing: -.5pt;">*rcj"IT*H </span>^ftft ifc&amp;v to be ultra-vires since no Rule was issued to exam­ine the vires of the said Rule 6.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; tab-stops: 23.5pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">II.<span style="mso-tab-count: 1;">    </span>Whether the Rule 6 of the </span><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: -.5pt;">WT€fa</span><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> <span style="letter-spacing: -.5pt;">the principle of natural justice by giving the National University which nomi­nates the President of the Governing Body, unfettered power to withdraw the said nomination at any time. <em>Mirza Ash-faque Hossain vs. Md. Ashraful Alam (Muhammad Imman Ali J) (Civil) 8 ADC 831</em></span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; tab-stops: 23.5pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: -.5pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 5.75pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Article 102</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">The petitioner has come in Court for ju­dicial review of the orders/decisions of the Bangladesh Bank intimating the Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Bank that as Prof. Yunus has been continuing as Managing Director even after surpassing the retirement age of 60 years violating the service Regulations, his continuation as per decision of the Board for indefinite period without ap­proval of the Bangladesh Bank is not legal and that he has not been legally working as Managing Director of the Bank. <em>Professor Muhammad Yunus vs. Bangladesh (S.K. Sinha J) (Civil) 8 ADC 834</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 3.35pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Article 102</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; tab-stops: 23.5pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">The points involved in these appeals are whether the Rajdhani Unnayan Katri-pakha (RAJUK) can remove unautho­rized constructions under the Building Constructions Act, 1952, the rules framed thereunder, the Town Improve­ment Act, 1953 and the Government and Local Authority Lands and Build­ings (Recovery of Possession) Ordi­nance, 1970 without demarcating the lands by metes and bounds by a prop­erly constituted partition suit and whether the High Court Division is jus­tified in restraining the Government and the RAJUK from removing the unau-' thorized constructions till the disputed property is partitioned by the civil Court. <em>Government of Bangladesh vs. Md. Gias Uddin Chowdhurv (S.K. Sinha J) (Civil) 8 ADC 879</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; tab-stops: 23.5pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: -.5pt;"> </span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-right: .25pt; text-align: right; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 5.75pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Article 102</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-right: 3.35pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.65pt 3.35pt .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">The respondent No. 1, (writ petitioner) a teacher of Fulbaria College, My-mensingh instituted Writ Petition No.3746 of 2003 in the High Court Di­vision seeking a declaration to the effect that the decision for demotion of the writ petitioner by the writ respondents to the post of lecturer from the post of Assistant Professor of Fulbaria College, Mymensingh and degrading his monthly pay scale from Tk.7,200/- to Tk.6,150/- to be declared without lawful authority. <em>Principal, Fulbaria College vs. Md. Helaluddin (S.K. Sinha J)(Civil) 8 ADC 941</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.65pt 3.35pt .0001pt 0in;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Article 102</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">The moot question involved in this pe­tition is whether, the High Court Divi­sion was correct in making the rule absolute in determining the terms and conditions of service of the employees of Bangaldesh Krishi Bank; which is in­cluded in the schedule of the Adminis­trative Tribunal Act, 1980, and secondly, whether the High Court Divi­sion was correct directing the petition-'ers to prepare a joint gradation list on the basis of the gradation list dated 19th November, 1998 by maintaining the seniority of respondents according to the recommendation of the Managing Director of the Bank and to issue viva voce card upon the respondents jointly for the purpose of their promotion along with the Senior Officers of Bangladesh Krishi Bank? <em>Bangladesh Krishi Bank vs. A run Chandra Banik (S.K. Sin ha J)(Civil) 8 ADC 952</em> to cancel the writ petitioner's</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">The moot points involve in this petition are whether the respondents are entitled<br/>to absorb in the revenue set up who were appointed purely on temporary<br/>basis and whether after the completion of ISSA project and discharging the em-<br/>ployees, they can be reemployed on regular basis by giving continuity of their<br/><em>service.Bangladesh represented by the Secretary vs.Md. Harunur Rashid (S.K.<br/>Sinha J) (Civil) 8 ADC. 956.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 4.55pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Article 102</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-right: .25pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.9pt .25pt .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">The Bangladesh Petroleum Corporation communicated a letter to the petitioner for setting up filling station in pur­suance of concerned Ministry's letter under memo dated 14th July, 2008. In the impugned letter the Bangladesh Pe­troleum Corporation has assigned no reason other than the reference of the concerned Ministry's letter. The writ-pe­titioner annexed the said letter, which revealed that the Ministry requested the Petroleum Corporation to cancel the ap­proval letter on basis of a complaint made by one 'Titas Filling Station' alleg­ing that the writ petitioner's filling sta­tion was set up towards 400 meters north of 'Titas Filling Station' <em>Padma Oil Compaftv Limited vs. Md. Abdus Samad (S.K. Sinha Jf(Civil) 8 ADC960</em></span></p></div></div>
96	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">The Constitution of Bangladesh Arti­cle 102 and 117</h2>
