text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt;">The General Clauses Act, 1897 Section 6</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">Prayed for a direction for fixing up their seniority, promotion, pay and status, time scale in accordance with the pro­visions of Rules, 1981 but the authority on a misconception of law fixed their seniority, promotion, pay and status as per Rules of 2000. <em>Government of Bangladesh vs. Kamrun Nahar (S.K. Sinha J)(Civil) 8 ADC 95</em></span></p></div></div>
110	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">   THE GOVERNMENT AND LOCAL AUTHORITY LANDS AND BUILDINGS (RECOVERY OF POSSESSION) ORDINANCE, 1970 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>THE GOVERNMENT AND </strong><strong>LOCAL</strong><strong> </strong><strong>AUTHORITY</strong><strong> </strong><strong>LANDS</strong><strong> AND BUILDINGS (RECOVERY OF POSSESSION) ORDINANCE, 1970 </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(EAST PAKISTAN ORDINANCE XXIV OF 1970).[18th September, 1970]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Ordinance to repeal and with certain amendments, re-enact the East Bengal Government Lands and Buildings (Recovery of Possession) Act, 1952, and the East Pakistan Government Land (Unauthorised Occupation) Ordinance, 1960, and to consolidate the law relating to recovery of possession and assessment and recovery of compensation and arrear rent from unauthorised occupants of Government and Local Authority lands and buildings.             1</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to repeal, and with certain amendments, re-enact the East Bengal Government Lands and Buildings (Recovery of Possession) Act, 1952, and the East Pakistan Government Land (Unauthorised Occupation) Ordinance, 1960, and to consolidate the law relating to recovery of possession and assessment and recovery of compensation and arrear rent from unauthorised occupants of Government and Local Authority lands and buildings;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in pursuance of the Proclamation of the 25th day of March, 1969, read with the Provisional Constitution Order, and in exercise of all powers enabling him in that behalf, the Governor is pleased to make and promulgate the following Ordinance:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong> Short title, extent and commencement </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. (1) This Ordinance may be called the 2[ * * *] Government and Local Authority  Lands and Buildings (Recovery of Possession) Ordinance, 1970.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It extends to the whole of Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) This Ordinance, in so far as it relates to Government lands and buildings, shall come into force at once; and the Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, extend it to such Local Authority and from such date as may be specified in the notification.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong> Definitions </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Ordinance, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) “building” means a building which vests in, or is owned by, or is in possession or under the management and control of, the Government or a Local Authority, and includes the land appurtenant thereto;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        “Deputy Commissioner” means the Deputy Commissioner of a District and includes an Additional Deputy Commissioner or a Joint Deputy Commissioner and such other persons as may be appointed by the Government to perform all or any of the functions of a Deputy Commissioner under this Ordinance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        “land” means any land which vests in, or is owned by, or is in the possession or under the management and control of, the Government or Local Authority and includes any water;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        “Local Authority” means a local authority as defined in 3[ clause (28) of section 3 of the General Clauses Act, 1897 (X of 1897)];</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        “prescribed” means prescribed by rules made by the Government under this Ordinance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f)         “unauthorised occupant” means a person who is in occupation of any land or building or part thereof without having obtained the express permission or authority of the Government or the Local Authority</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">concerned, as the case may be, and without executing, where necessary, a legal document, and includes-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) a person unlawfully inducted into any land or building or part thereof by the lessee; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii) a lessee who continues in possession of the land or building or part thereof after expiry of term or determination of lease; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g) the words “lease” and “lessee” have the same meanings as in the Transfer of Property Act, 1882, and the word “lessee” includes his heirs, assigns, legal representatives, members of his family and all persons inducted by him into the demised land.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Eviction of outgoing lessee from land or building</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. If on the expiry, whether before or after the commencement of this Ordinance, of the period of a lease in respect of any land or building of which the Government or a Local Authority is the lessor or on the determination of such lease on the ground of breach of any covenant or on the determination of such lease according to the terms and conditions of the lease or otherwise, the lessee refused or failed, or refuses or fails, to vacate that land or building and put the lessor into possession of the same, then, notwithstanding anything contained in any other law for the time being in force or in any contract, it shall be lawful for the Deputy Commissioner, on his own motion or on the complaint of or upon information received from anybody or a Local Authority, at any time after the expiry or determination of lease, to re-enter upon the demised land or building and recover khas possession thereof by evicting the lessee and by demolishing and removing structures, if any, erected or built thereon by the lessee:</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the Deputy Commissioner shall, before demolishing and removing any structures under this section, issue, in the prescribed manner, a notice on the lessee calling upon him to remove such structures within a period of thirty days from the date of service of the notice.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Determination of lease and recovery of building in certain cases</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. (1) Notwithstanding anything contained in any other law for the time being in force or any contract, where the lessee of a building or part of a building 4[ is a person in the service of the Republic] or of a Local Authority, the lease in respect of such</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">building or part shall, in addition to the modes mentioned in section 111 of the Transfer of Property Act, 1882, terminate-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        on the suspension, discharge, removal, dismissal, resignation, retirement or death of such servant or on his transfer from the station in which he is employed to any other station; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        on the transfer of the lessee's interest by assignment, mortgage, sub-lease or in any other manner.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) On the determination of a lease in respect of a building or part of a building in the manner stated in sub-section (1) or in any of the modes mentioned in section 111 of the Transfer of Property Act, 1882, the lessee or the person claiming through him shall, notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in the said Act or in any other law for the time being in force or in any contract, forthwith put the lessor into possession of such building or part, failing which it shall be lawful for the Deputy Commissioner to re-enter and recover khas possession of the same by evicting the lessee or the person claiming through him:</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the Deputy Commissioner shall, before re-entering such building or part of a building, issue, in the prescribed manner, a notice on such lessee or person calling upon him to vacate the same within a period of thirty days from the date of service of the notice.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Eviction of unauthorised occupant</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. (1) If the Deputy Commissioner, on his own motion or on the complaint of or upon information received from anybody or a Local Authority, is satisfied after making such inquiry as he thinks fit, that a person is an unauthorised occupant, he may issue, in the prescribed manner, a notice directing such person to vacate the land, building or part thereof in his occupation within a period of thirty days from the date of service of the notice 5[ :</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the Deputy Commissioner may, where he is satisfied that thirty days' notice will not be in public interest, reduce the period of such notice to not less than seven days.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) If the person, against whom an order under sub-section (1) has been made, refuses or fails to vacate the land, building or part thereof in his occupation within the time fixed, then, notwithstanding anything contained in any other law for the time being in force, it shall be lawful for the Deputy Commissioner to enter upon such land, building or part thereof and recover khas possession of the same by evicting such person and by demolishing and removing structures, if any, erected or built by that person.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Mode of recovery of possession</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. For the purpose of recovering khas possession of any land, building or part thereof under the provisions of section 3 or section 4 or section 5, the Deputy Commissioner may use or cause to be used such force as may be necessary.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Penalties</p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. (1) Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Ordinance or in any other law for the time being in force, if a Deputy Commissioner, an Additional Deputy Commissioner, a Joint Deputy Commissioner or a 6[ Upazilla Nirbahi Officer], on his own motion or on the complaint of or upon an information received from anybody, is satisfied after making such inquiry as he may think fit, that a person is an unauthorised occupant of any land or building or part thereof, he may give or cause to be given an information to that effect to the Police Station having jurisdiction and thereupon it would be an offence which shall be punishable with imprisonment of either description for a term not exceeding two years or with fine which may extend to rupees one thousand or with both.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) An offence punishable under sub-section (1) shall be a cognizable and non-bailable offence to be tried in accordance with the warrant procedure as laid down in the Code of Criminal Procedure.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Forfeiture</p><p style="text-align: justify;">8. All structures and other properties remaining on the land, building or part thereof, after expiry of the period specified in the notice under section 3 or section 4 or section 5, shall be forfeited to the Government or the Local Authority, as the case may be.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Compensation for unauthorised occupation</p><p style="text-align: justify;">9. (1) For unauthorised occupation of any land, building or part thereof or for any damage caused thereto, the unauthorised occupant shall be liable to pay to the Government or to the Local Authority, as the case may be, such compensation as may be assessed by the Deputy Commissioner in accordance with the rules to be made in this behalf by the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) As soon as an assessment has been made under sub-section (1), the Deputy Commissioner shall serve on the assessee, in the prescribed manner, a notice of such assessment, directing him to pay the amount so assessed within the period of thirty days from the date of service of the notice.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Any amount due under sub-section (2) or if the rent payable for lease in respect of any land, building or part of any building has been in arrear, such amount or rent shall be recoverable as public demand under the provisions of 7[ * * *] Public Demands Recovery Act, 1913.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Appeal</p><p style="text-align: justify;">10. Any person aggrieved by an order made under section 3 or section 4 or section 5 or section 9 may prefer an appeal to the 8[ Commissioner of the Division] within thirty days of the service of notice and the decision of the 9[ Commissioner] on such an appeal shall be final.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Bar to jurisdiction of civil Court</p><p style="text-align: justify;">11. No civil Court shall pass an order in any suit or proceeding granting a temporary or ad interim injunction restraining the Deputy Commissioner from taking possession of any land, building or part thereof under this Ordinance nor shall call in question any assessment of compensation made under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Public servant</p><p style="text-align: justify;">12. Any person authorised to exercise any power or discharge any duty under this Ordinance shall be deemed to be a public servant under section 21 of the 10[ * * *] Penal Code.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Indemnity</p><p style="text-align: justify;">13. (1) No suit or legal proceeding shall lie against the Government or a Local Authority in respect of anything which is, in good faith, done or intended to be done under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) No suit, prosecution or legal proceeding shall lie against any person in respect of anything which is, in good faith, done or intended to be done under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Power to make rules</p><p style="text-align: justify;">14. The Government may make rules for carrying out the purposes of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">[]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">15. [Repeal and savings.- Omitted by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 Throughout this Ordinance, the words “Bangladesh” and “Government” were substituted for the words “East Pakistan” and “Provincial Government” by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2 The words “East Pakistan” were omitted by Article 6 of the Bangladesh (Adaptation of Existing Laws) Order, 1972 (President's Order No. 48 of 1972)</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3 The words, brackets, figures and comma “clause (28) of section 3 of the General Clauses Act, 1897 (X of 1897)” were substituted for the words, brackets, figures and comma “clause (23) of section 3 of the Bengal General Clauses Act, 1899 (Bengal Act I of 1899)” by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4 The words “is a person in the service of the Republic” were substituted for the words “is a servant of Government in Pakistan” by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5 The colon (:) was substituted for the full-stop (.) and the proviso was added thereafter by Article 2 of the Bangladesh Government and Local Authority Lands and Buildings (Recovery of Possession) Order, 1972 (President's Order No. 85 of 1972)</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">6 The words “Upazilla Nirbahi Officer” were substituted for the words “Sub-divisional Officer” by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">7 The word “Bengal” was omitted by Article 6 of the Bangladesh (Adaptation of Existing Laws) Order, 1972 (President's Order No. 48 of 1972)</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">8 The words “Commissioner of the Division” were substituted for the word “Government” by the Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Amending) Ordinance, 1976 (Ordinance No. IX of 1976)</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">9 The word “Commissioner” was substituted for the word “Government” by the Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Amending) Ordinance, 1976 (Ordinance No. IX of 1976)</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">10 The word “Pakistan” was omitted by Article 6 of the Bangladesh (Adaptation of Existing Laws) Order, 1972 (President's Order No. 48 of 1972)</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p> </div></div>
111	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">The Government Servant (Dis-cepline and Appeal) Rules, 1985</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  9 ADC 407</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Government Servant</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-11-07</p><!DOCTYPE html><p><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> <o:OfficeDocumentSettings>  <o:RelyOnVML/>  <o:AllowPNG/> </o:OfficeDocumentSettings></xml><![endif]--><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> <w:WordDocument>  <w:View>Normal</w:View> <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="68" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 2"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="69" SemiHidden="false" Locked="false" Priority="73" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Colorful Grid"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="60" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light Shading Accent 1"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="61" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light List Accent 1"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="62" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light Grid Accent 1"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="63" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Shading 1 Accent 1"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="64" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Shading 2 Accent 1"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="65" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium List 1 Accent 1"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Revision"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="34" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="List Paragraph"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="29" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Quote"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="30" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Intense Quote"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="66" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium List 2 Accent 1"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="67" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 1 Accent 1"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="68" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 2 Accent 1"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="69" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 3 Accent 1"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="70" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Dark List Accent 1"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="71" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Colorful Shading Accent 1"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="72" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Colorful List Accent 1"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="73" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Colorful Grid Accent 1"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="60" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" table.MsoNormalTable	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;	mso-style-noshow:yes;	mso-style-priority:99;	mso-style-qformat:yes;	mso-style-parent:"";	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;	mso-para-margin:0in;	mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;	font-size:11.0pt;	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";	mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;	mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast;	mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;	mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;}</style><![endif]--></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">The Government Servant (Dis-cepline and Appeal) Rules, 1985 Rule, 7(2) (c),10(9)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">The present respondent Md. Khorshed AH Talukder filed the above mentioned Administrative Tribunal Case No.47 of 2002. His case, in short, was that he joined the service as Sub-divisional Agriculture Officer on 22.07.1970. That while he was serving as Principal of Gaibanda Training Institute from 09.09.1997 in current charge the author­ity framed a charge against him on 20.09.2001 on the allegations of corrup­tion under Rule 3(b) and 3(d) of the Government Servants (Discipline &amp; Appeal) Rules, 1985. <em>Government of the People's vs. Md. Khorshed Ali Talukder (Nazmun Ara Sultana J) (Civil) 9 ADC 407</em></span></p></div></div>
112	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE GOVERNMENT SERVANTS (SPECIAL PROVISIONS) ORDINANCE, 1979 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>THE GOVERNMENT SERVANTS (SPECIAL PROVISIONS) ORDINANCE, 1979 </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ORDINANCE NO. XI OF 1979).[22nd February, 1979]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Ordinance to make special provisions for maintaining discipline among Government servants.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to make special provisions for maintaining discipline among Government servants;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in pursuance of the Proclamations of the 20th August, 1975, and the 8th November, 1975, and in exercise of all powers enabling him in that behalf, the President is pleased to make and promulgate the following Ordinance:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Short title </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. This Ordinance may be called the Government Servants (Special Provisions) Ordinance, 1979.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Ordinance to override all other laws, etc</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. This Ordinance shall have effect notwithstanding anything contained in any law, rules and regulations relating to Government servants or in the conditions of service of any Government servant.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Offences</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. Where a Government servant-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) engages in any activity which causes disaffection among, or interferes with the discipline of, or obstructs the performance of duties by, any other Government servant; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) without leave of absence or any reasonable excuse, absents himself or otherwise abstains from, or fails to perform, his duties, whether or not in concert with others; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) incites or in any manner persuades any other Government servant to be absent or to abstain from, or not to perform, his duties; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) prevents any Government servant from attending to or performing his duties;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">he shall be liable to be punished with any of the penalties mentioned in Section 4.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Penalties</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. The following shall be the penalties which may be imposed under this Ordinance, namely:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) dismissal from service;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) discharge from service; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) reduction in rank or pay.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Inquiry and punishment</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. (1) When a Government servant is to be proceeded against for any of the offences mentioned in section 3, the appointing authority or any person authorised by him 1[ in this behalf by general or special order] shall frame a charge and, by notice accompanied by the charge, require the Government servant, hereinafter called the accused, to show cause, within a period which shall not be less than two days nor more than five days from the date of the service of the notice, why he should not be punished under this Ordinance and also to state whether he desires to be heard in person.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) If, after consideration of the cause, if any, shown by the accused, and hearing him in person, if the accused appears for the purpose, the appointing authority 2[ or the person who framed the charge] finds the accused guilty of the charge, or if no cause is shown within the required period, the appointing authority 3[ or the person who framed the charge] shall, by notice specifying the penalty proposed to be imposed, require the accused to show cause within three days of the service of the notice, why the penalty specified therein shall not be imposed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) After considering the cause, if any, shown under sub-section (2), or if no cause is shown within required period, the appointing authority may impose upon the accused the penalty specified in the notice under sub-section (2).</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) For the purpose of this section, a notice shall be deemed to have been validly served if it is served by delivery to the accused or by affixing it to a conspicuous place of his last known residence or by publication in not less than two daily newspapers.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4[ Appeal and review]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. (1) A Government servant on whom a penalty has been imposed under this Ordinance may, within seven days of the receipt of the order imposing the penalty, appeal against the order to an authority immediately superior to the appointing authority; and the appellate authority to whom the appeal has been made may pass such order on the appeal as it may deem fit.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5[ (2) Where the appointing authority is the President, the Government servant on whom a penalty has been imposed under this Ordinance may, within thirty working days of the receipt of the order imposing the penalty, apply to the President for review of the order and the President may pass such order on the application as he may deem fit.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) An order passed on appeal under sub-section (1) or on application under sub-section (2) shall be final.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Court’s jurisdiction barred</p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. No proceeding or order under any of the provisions of this Ordinance shall be called in question in any Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 The words “in this behalf by general or special order” were inserted by section 2 of the Government Servants (Special Provisions) (Amendment) Act, 1990 (Act No. VII of 1990)</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2 The words “or the person who framed the charge” were inserted by section 2 of the Government Servants (Special Provisions) (Amendment) Act, 1990 (Act No. VII of 1990)</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3 The words “or the person who framed the charge” were inserted by section 2 of the Government Servants (Special Provisions) (Amendment) Act, 1990 (Act No. VII of 1990)</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4 The words “in this behalf by general or special order” were inserted by section 2 of the Government Servants (Special Provisions) (Amendment) Act, 1990 (Act No. VII of 1990)</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5 Sub-sections (2) and (3) were substituted for sub-section (2) by section 3 of the Government Servants (Special Provisions) (Amendment) Act, 1990 (Act No. VII of 1990)</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p> </div></div>
113	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">The Jagannath University Ain, 2005</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Subject:</b>   Jagannath University </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-11-08</p><!DOCTYPE html><p><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> text-autospace: none; margin: 4.1pt 0in .0001pt 75.85pt;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">The Jagannath University Ain, 2005, Section 56</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">The moot question before us is whether the petitioners who are existing Lectur­ers / Teachers of the newly created Uni­versity and who were appointed by the Government and deputed to the Gov­ernment Jagannath College could claim to be entitled to automatic absorption as Lecturers/Teachers in the newly created Jagannath University. Upon scrutiny of the *r*t3W f^fwl^ra wf^, ^ooc (the Act of 2005), it appears that the statute has categorically dealt with the conse­quences of the Government Jagannath College being converted to the Jagan­nath University. Section 56(2)(L)-(Q) deals with the assets and liabilities of the erstwhile Government Jagannath College which is not relevant for our purposes. With regard to the Principal, Vice-Principal, Lecturers, Teachers, Of­ficers and Workers etc. of the College, section 56(2)(chha) provides as follows:</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-right: .5pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p></div></div>
114	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">The Junior Police Service Rules, 1969</h2>

Bangladesh Police Force on various date and are presently serving as Sub-Inspector at different locations within the country. The Writ Petition No.7942 of 2009 was filed impugning the Memo No. wra <em>4® </em>4*1 / to*-*oov/*°fr* dated 5.8.2009. The said memo gave detail of various conditions / bars which could have to be fulfilled before appointment serving in the rank of Sub-Inspector, would be considered for promotion to the rank of Inspector. <em>Government of Bangladesh vs. Md. Abdus Sattar (Muhammad Imman All J)(Civil) 9 ADC 662</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></em></p></div></div>

table.MsoNormalTable	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;	mso-style-noshow:yes;	mso-style-priority:99;	mso-style-qformat:yes;	mso-style-parent:"";	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;	mso-para-margin:0in;	mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;	font-size:11.0pt;	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";	mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;	mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast;	mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;	mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;}</style><![endif]--></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt;">The Land Appeal Board Rules, 1990, Rules 3(3), (5), 4(1)(3) and 5</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">A reading of the order of the Full Board further shows that in fact, they re­opened the matter and re-heard the same and has written out a fresh judgment on the same materials considering which the Chairman of the Land Appeal Board passed the order on 29.08.1995. It also appears to us that the Full Board pro­ceeded in a manner as if they were hear­ing an appeal from the order of the Chairman of the Land Appeal Board and corrected the mistake committed by him which was not within the scope and extent of the exercise of the power of re­view. The Full Board also failed to ap­preciate that the object of review is neither to enable the reviewing author­ity to re-hear the matter nor to write a</span> <span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">second judgment. And in the context, the High Court Division rightly held that the Full Board travelled beyond its jurisdiction in deciding matters not within its jurisdiction as contemplated under the Rules, 1990. <em>Md. Mintu Chowdhwy vs. Khurshid Naveem (Md. Abdul Wahhab Miah J)(Civil) 10 ADC 148.</em></span></p></div></div>

none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.4pt 0in .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">It was argued on behalf of the peti­tioner that the High Court Division erred in law in dismissing the appeal summarily which has resulted miscar­riage of justice. It was further urged</span> <span style="font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">that though it was alleged that 140 grams of heroin were recovered from the house of the petitioner, in fact, only 1.40 grams of heroin were recovered and in this connection learned advo-cate-on-record has drawn our attention to the seizure list, and on consideration of the trifling nature of offence, it is submitted, the sentence awarded to the petitioner be reduced to the period un­dergone. <em>Abul Hossen vs. The State (S.K. Sinha J)(Criminal) 9 ADC 807</em></span></p></div></div>

118	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">The Manual of Civil Suit Instruc­tions</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>   7 ADC 87</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Manual of Civil Suit </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-11-08</p><!DOCTYPE html><p><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> <o:OfficeDocumentSettings>  <o:RelyOnVML/>  <o:AllowPNG/> </o:OfficeDocumentSettings></xml><![endif]--><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> <w:WordDocument>  <w:View>Normal</w:View> 119	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">The meaning of Bank Companies Act, 1991</h2>

defaulter within the meaning of Bank Companies Act, 1991 and as such, the said decision of the High Court Di­vision merits interference by this Court. <em>Industrial Promotion vs. Mrs. Mohsina Rahman (S.K. Sinha J) (Civil) 9 ADC </em>865</span></p></div></div>
120	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">The Money Laundering Protirodh Ain, 2009</h2>

Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Writ Petition No.6286 of 2010 mainly on the ground that the proceed­ings under the provisions of the Ain of 2009 is barred under Articles 35(1) and 44 of the Constitution since the alleged offences were committed admittedly be­fore the enactment of the said Ain. <em>Tarique Rahman vs. Government of Bangladesh (Md. Muzammel Hossain J) (Civil) 8 ADC 217</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.9pt 3.35pt .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p></div></div>
121	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">The Muslim Family Law Ordinance, 1961</h2>

Locked="false" Priority="64" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Shading 2 Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="65" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium List 1 Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="66" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium List 2 Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="67" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 1 Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="68" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 2 Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="69" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 3 Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="70" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Dark List Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="71" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Colorful Shading Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="72" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Colorful List Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="73" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Colorful Grid Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="60" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light Shading Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="61" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light List Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="62" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light Grid Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="63" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Shading 1 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="64" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Shading 2 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="65" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium List 1 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="66" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium List 2 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="67" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 1 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="68" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 2 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="69" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 3 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="70" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Dark List Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="71" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Colorful Shading Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="72" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Colorful List Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="73" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Colorful Grid Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="19" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Subtle Emphasis"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="21" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Intense Emphasis"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="31" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Subtle Reference"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="32" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Intense Reference"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="33" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Book Title"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="37" Name="Bibliography"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="39" QFormat="true" Name="TOC Heading"/> </w:LatentStyles></xml><![endif]--><!-- [if gte mso 10]><style> /* Style Definitions */ table.MsoNormalTable	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;	mso-style-noshow:yes;	mso-style-priority:99;	mso-style-qformat:yes;	mso-style-parent:"";	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;	mso-para-margin:0in;	mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;	font-size:11.0pt;	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";	mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;	mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast;	mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;	mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;}</style><![endif]--></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.9pt 3.35pt .0001pt 0in;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">The Muslim Family Law Ordinance, 1961, Section 6(5)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.9pt 3.35pt .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.9pt 3.35pt .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">The High Court Division misdirected it­self in interpreting Section 7(1) of the Ordinance, 1961 in that the provision of notice to the Chairman of the Union Council as stipulated in the said section is applicable when any man who wishes to divorce his wife unilaterally does so and when divorce is effected by mutual understanding and bilateral action of the parties or at the instance of the wife, such requirement of notice to the Chair­man of the Union Council is dispensed with since the objection of a notice to the Chairman and to serve a copy to the wife as required by Section 7(1) of the Ordinance, 1961, is to bring to the no­tice of divorce to the wife as initiated by the husband and to 'prevent hasty disso­lution of marriage' and when the wife</span> <span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">herself is a party to the 'Talaqnama' there is no need to serve a notice to the Chairman of the Union Council since the wife is already aware of the divorce and is a consenting party to the divorce and as such, the judgment and order of the High Court Division is liable to be set aside. <em>Abul Hasnat Mohammad Mohsin vs. Dilruba Aktar (Mohammad Fazlul Karim J) (Civil) 8 ADC 314</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.9pt 3.35pt .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.9pt 3.35pt .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.9pt 3.35pt .0001pt 0in;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">The Muslim family law Ordinance, 1961, Rule 6(3)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.9pt 3.35pt .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.9pt 3.35pt .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Respondent was appointed as the Nikah Registrar for No.7 Edbarpur Union on temporary basis and the respondent having requisite qualification got the appointment as Nikah Registrar on 26.01.2003 by the authority concerned i.e. the Ministry of law and Parliamen­tary Affairs issued the License of Nikah Registrar in favour of the respondent No.l and before taking appointment the respondent No. 1 obtained some letter of recommendation from the then member of Parliament namely, Mr. Redwan Ahmed, besides the respondents by cre-ating some false papers and documents suppressing his own identity in order to have the license of a Nikah Registrar for the area of No. 7 Edbarpur Union which is under Chandina Police Station of Comilla District. <em>Md. Abdul Awal vs. Kazi Md. Abul Basar (Mohammad Fa­zlul Karim J)(Civil) 6 ADC 517</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.9pt 3.35pt .0001pt 0in;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Muslim Law of Inheritance</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.9pt 3.35pt .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="Style2" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; margin: 2.15pt 2.4pt .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">Both the parties adduced some wit­nesses in order to prove their respective cases. The trial court, on consideration of evidence</span><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> and facts and circum­stances, opined that since the deceased employee did not select any nominee for the provident fund and other service benefits these benefits will be distrib­uted among the heirs of the deceased as per Muslim Law of inheritance and or­dered for issuance of succession certifi­cate in favour of the petitioners and the opposite party No. 1 accordingly. <em>Sheikh Moqbul ahmed vs. Ms. Nurunnahar Begum (Nazmun Ara Sultana J) (Civil) 9 ADC 246</em></span></p></div></div>
122	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">The Muslim Marriages and Divorces (Registration) Rules, 1974</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  10 ADC 652,  6 ADC 799.</p><p><b>Subject:</b>   Muslim Marriages and Divorces </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-11-08</p><!DOCTYPE html><p><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> <o:OfficeDocumentSettings>  <o:RelyOnVML/>  <o:AllowPNG/> </o:OfficeDocumentSettings></xml><![endif]--><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light Grid Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="63" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Shading 1 Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Name="Medium List 1 Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="66" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium List 2 Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="67" <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="69" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 3 Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="70" SemiHidden="false" Name="Colorful Grid Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="60" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light Shading Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="61" <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="63" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Shading 1 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="64" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Shading 2 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="65" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium List 1 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Name="Medium Grid 1 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="68" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 2 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="69" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 3 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="70" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Dark List Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="71" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Colorful Shading Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="72" SemiHidden="false" UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Intense Emphasis"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="31" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Subtle Reference"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="32" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Intense Reference"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="33" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Book Title"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="37" Name="Bibliography"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="39" QFormat="true" Name="TOC Heading"/> </w:LatentStyles></xml><![endif]--><!-- [if gte mso 10]><style> /* Style Definitions */ table.MsoNormalTable	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;	mso-style-noshow:yes;	mso-style-priority:99;	mso-style-qformat:yes;	mso-style-parent:"";	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;	mso-para-margin:0in;	mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;	font-size:11.0pt;	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";	mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;	mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast;	mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;	mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;}</style><![endif]--></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 4.1pt 0in .0001pt 19.9pt;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">The Muslim Marriages and Divorces (Registration) Rules, 1974, Rule 5A(1)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">It appears that the respondent No. 1 was appointed as temporary Nikah Registrar on 18.01.1995 and he served more than six years as Nikah Registrar and there was no allegation against him and be­fore the cancellation of licence no show cause notice was served upon the re­spondent No. 1. It has been well estab­lished that no action should be taken against a person without giving him any opportunity of being heard. Section 11 of the Muslim Marriages and Divorces (Registration) Act, 1975 no order for cancellation and suspension of a licence shall be made unless the Nikah</span> <span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Registrar has been given a reasonable opportunity of showing cause why that order should not be made. It appears that the High Court Division rightly found that the writ petitioner was ini­tially given temporary licence on 18.01.1995 as per Rule 5A(1) of the Muslim Marriages and Divorces (Reg­istration) Rules, 1975. Under Section 11 read with Rule 8(2) of the Muslim Mar­riages and Divorces (Registration) Rules, 1975 notice is required to be served upon the Nikah Registrar before cancellation of licence and it is also a fundamental principle of natural justice that no action shall be taken against any person without giving him any opportu­nity of being heard. <em>Md. Abu Hanifa vs. Md. Shafiul Bashar (Md. Muzammel Hossain J) (Civil) 10 ADC 652</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">The Muslim Marriages and Di­vorces (Registration) Act, 1974 Section 4</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Section 4 of the Muslim Marriages and Divorces (Registration) Act 1974 and also Rule 10 of the Muslim Marriages and Divorces (Registration) Rules 1975 as amended by S. R. O. No. 273 Ain / 2002 dated 02.10.2000 being violative of the fundamental rights as guaranteed by the constitution. <em>Md. Bazlur Rashid vs. Bangladesh represented by the Sec­retary (Md. Tafazzul Islam J)(Civil) 6 ADC 799.</em></span></p></div></div>
123	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">The National University Act, 1992</h2>

mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">The National University Act, 1992</span></em></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Making the Rule absolute without any order as to costs declaring the order dated 17.03.2005 terminating the serv­ice of the respondent as Deputy Regis­trar of the National University, Gazipur</span></em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> <em>to be illegal and of no legal authority and further directing the National Uni­versity to reinstate the respondent in her service with all attending benefits ad­missible to her. National University vs. Begum Sultana Razia (Mohammad Fa-zlul Karim J)(Civil) 8 ADC 307</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Section </span></em></strong><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">24, 26</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Mr.A.K.Badrul Huq, learned Senior Counsel appearing for the petitioner, submits that the definition of "Teacher" under regulation 2(umma) of the Regu­lations, 1994 means Principal, Vice-Principal including permanent and temporary Teachers of college and thus the petitioner is eligible for the post of the Principal within the purview of no­tification of the Government dated 2.4.2003 and as such the impugned memo dated 18.1.2007 is illegal. He further submits that the notification dated 2.4.2003 confirmed by notifica­tion dated 15.11.2008 issued by the Ministry of Education, the controlling authority of all educational Institutions, and that though the National University is regulated by National University Act, 1994, still the Ministry of Education re­mains the controlling and regulating au­thority and that the National University authority is required to abide by notifi­cation dated 2.4.2003 and that the High Court Division committed error in hold­ing that the notification dated 2.4.2003 issued by the Ministry of Education has no manner of application for appoint­ment of a Principal of degree college. S.M.Zakir Hossain vs. The People's Re­public of Bangladesh (Syed Mahmud Hossain J)(Civil) 8 ADC 600</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></em></p></div></div>
124	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">The Negotiable Instrument Act, 1881</h2>

Normal";	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;	mso-style-noshow:yes;	mso-style-priority:99;	mso-style-qformat:yes;	mso-style-parent:"";	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;	mso-para-margin-top:0in;	mso-para-margin-right:0in;	mso-para-margin-bottom:10.0pt;	mso-para-margin-left:0in;	line-height:115%;	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;	font-size:11.0pt;	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";	mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;	mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast;	mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;	mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;}</style><![endif]--></p><p class="MsoNormal"><strong>The Negotiable Instrument Act, Section 138</strong></p><p class="MsoNormal">Application for review has been filed on discovery of new facts which was possibly not known to the Advocate of the petitioner when the revisional case was heard before the High Court Divi­sion nor this was known to the Advo-cate-on-Record when the leave petition was filed <em>Jamil Ahmed Khan vs. Md. Delwar Hossain (Md. Abdul Matin J)(Criminal) 6 ADC 429</em></p><p class="MsoNormal"><strong>The Negotiable Instrument Act, Section 138</strong></p><p class="MsoNormal">Accusing the accused-petitioner stat­ing, inter alia, that on 15.06.2003 the petitioner issued a cheque for Tk. 15,00,000/- in favour of him in his own account with the Pubali Bank Ltd. For­eign Exchange Brach, Dhaka. On the same day he presented the cheque for encashment but the same was dishon­oured due to "insufficient of fund'. On 29.06.2003 he served a legal notice upon the petitioner for payment. The petitioner received the same no 1.7.2003 but with no effect. <em>M.K. Ba-zlur Rahman vs. Md. Johurul Haque (MM. Ruhul Amin CJJ(Criminal) 6 ADC 809</em></p><p class="MsoNormal"><strong>Section 138</strong></p><p class="MsoNormal">We are of the view that the operation of section 138 of the Act, 1881 cannot be obstructed or, in any way, circum­vented by the mere fact of filing of a suit by the drawer of the dishonoured cheque in civil Court whatever allega­tions may be in the plaint about the same and the relief prayed for therein, because such a device shall totally make the section itself nugatory. How­ever, if a holder or the payee gets hold of a dishonoured cheque by fraudulent means or forgery, the drawer of the cheque shall have the liberty to take such defence during the trial <em>.Md. Arif-Uz-Zaman. vs. The State (Md. Abdul Wahhab Miah J) (Criminal) 8 ADC 975</em></p><p class="MsoNormal"><strong>Act,</strong></p><p class="MsoNormal"><strong>The Negotiable Instrument 1881, Section 138</strong></p><p class="MsoNormal">Facts relevant for disposal of this petition is that pursuant to a complaint made by the respondent No.2, the learned Chief Metropolitan Magistrate, Chittagong, issued process against the petitioner under section 138 of the Ne-gotiable Instruments Act, 1881. <em>Md.<br/>Mofizur Rahman vs. The State (S.K..Sinha J)(Criminal) 9 ADC 71</em></p><p class="MsoNormal"><strong>The Negotiable Instrument Act, 1881, Section 138(1)</strong></p><p class="MsoNormal">Points urged on behalf of the petitioner are that the High Court Division acted stifled before the trial specially when • there is a prima facie case for going for trial and further the trial of the case has already been concluded and the case is pending for argument so at this stage the application quashing is not entertainable as in the case of Golam Sarwar Hani vs. The State and another reported in 13 MLR (AD) 103 it has been held that quashment of proceed­ings, at the stage when trial already began and prosecution witnesses are being examined, is not permissible. <em>Mohammad Mosharraf Hossain vs. Golam Mohammad (Md. Tafazzul Islam J) (Criminal) 7 ADC 179</em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Section 138</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">The accused-petitioner filed an appli­cation along with a photostat copy of money receipt and prayed for obtain­ing opinion of the handwriting expert by comparing the disputed signature of the complainant appearing on the money receipt with his admitted signa­tures made on the petition of com­plaint, vokalatnama and deposition sheet. It was urged that handwriting expert's opinion was required as the complainant who was examined P.W. 1 denied the execution of money receipt in his cross-examination. <em>Md. Shamsul A lam vs. The State (Sved Mahmud Hossain J)(Criminal) 10 ADC 702</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Section 138</span></strong></p><p class="Style5" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; margin: 2.4pt .05in .0001pt 0in;"><span class="FontStyle13"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; letter-spacing: -.5pt;">We</span></span><span class="FontStyle13"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> have heard the learned Advocate-on-Record and perused the materials available on record and have reasons to believe that the submissions of the learned Advocate for the petitioner has got no merit and accordingly the same is dismissed. </span></span><span class="FontStyle12"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Md. Nasir Uddin vs. The State (Md. Hassan Ameen <span style="letter-spacing: 2.0pt;">J)</span> (Crimi­nal) 6 ADC 534</span></span></p><p class="Style1" style="margin-left: 43.45pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-pagination: widow-orphan;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="Style1" style="margin-left: 43.45pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-pagination: widow-orphan;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p></div></div>
125	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">The Non-Agricultural Tenancy Act, 1949</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>   6 ADC 783, 6 ADC 859, 7 ADC 568, 9 ADC 386, </p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Non-Agricultural  Tenancy</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>
