mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Without spending the money for the development of the Pourashava he misappropriated the amount. On the aforesaid allegation District Anti-Cor­ruption officer, Cox's Bazar lodged first Information Report with Cox's Bazar Police Station against the peti­tioner . <em><span style="letter-spacing: .5pt;">Md. Nurul Absar vs. The State (Md. Joynul Abedin J) (Criminal) 6 ADC 617</span></em></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: center; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: 'Cordia New','sans-serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman';"> </span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: center; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: 'Cordia New','sans-serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman';"> </span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center; line-height: 14.65pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 3.85pt 0in .0001pt 0in;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">The Prevention of Corruption Act, (Act <span style="letter-spacing: 1.5pt;">II</span> of 1947), Section 5(2)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: 'Cordia New','sans-serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 1.9pt 0in .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Dismissing the appeal and upholding the judgment and conviction under Section 409 of the penal Code and Sec­tion 5(2) of the Prevention of Corrup­tion Act, 1947 passed by the Court o</span> <span style="font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Divisional Special Judge. <em>Md. Nurul Absar vs. The State (Md. Hassan Ameen J)(Criminal) 6 ADC 984</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 1.9pt 0in .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: normal; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 3.1pt 0in .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.4pt 0in .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.4pt 0in .0001pt 0in;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Section 5(2)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.4pt 0in .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.4pt 0in .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">On the next date the accused remained absconding and on 17.05.2009 he was . shown arrested and an application for bail made on behalf of accused respon­dent No.l but the same was rejected. The case was transferred to the Court of Special Judge, Court No.2, Dhaka where date was fixed on 22.06.2009 for charge hearing. On the next two dates the ac­cused sought adjournment. When an­other date was fixed for 26.07.2009, the accused filed an application under sec­tion 241<strong>A </strong>of the Code of Criminal Pro­cedure. The next date fixed was 17.08.2009 for charge hearing. <em>The State vs. Dr. A.Z.M. Zahid Hossain (Muham­mad Imman Ali J)(Criminal) 9 ADC 985</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.4pt 0in .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.4pt 0in .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.4pt 0in .0001pt 0in;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Section 5(2)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.4pt 0in .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.4pt 0in .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Question is whether the confiscation of plot No.49, 49A, 49B and 49C situated at Kawran Bazar commercial Area under <strong>P.S. </strong>Tejgaon, District-Dhaka in­cluding the building structure thereon is authorised by law. <em>M. A. Salter vs. The State(Md. Abdul Matin J) (Crimi­nal) 6 ADC 157</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.4pt 0in .0001pt 0in;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">The said Act, Section ll(Ka), 4(l)/30</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.4pt 0in .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.4pt 0in .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">The defence case as it transpires from the trend of cross-examination is that they have been falsely implicated in the case out of enmity and the deceased succumbed to her burn injury which was accidental in nature</span> <em><span style="font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">Md. Mirzajul Sheikh vs. The State (Md. Joynul Abe-din J) (Criminal) 6 ADC 442</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.4pt 0in .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p></div></div>
131	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">The Process of State Acquisition and Tenancy Act.</h2>

text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt;">The Process of State Acquisition and Tenancy Act.</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">It appears from the record that the de­termination of the boundary of the Mu­nicipality or political unit is an administrative act of the writ respondent under Pourashava Ordinance, 1977 and it is obviously a policy matter, as such the writ-petitioner has no locus standi to file the writ petition. <em>Nekbar Ali vs. Government of Bangladesh (Moham­mad Fazlul Karim J) (Civil) 41 DLR 246.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt;"> </span></strong></p></div></div>
132	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">The provisions of Family Courts Ordinance, 1985</h2>

133	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">The Public Procurement Regula­tions, 2003</h2>

134	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">The public Servant Retirements Act, 1974</h2>

style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt;">The REB Service Regulations, 1990, Regulations 40(2)</span></em></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></em></p><p class="Style3" style="line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-pagination: widow-orphan;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">Rule 40 of the REB service Rules en­visages two categories of penalties, namely, minor penalties and major</span></em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">penalties. Under Rule 40 (1) (Kha) four types of major penalties can be inflicted upon a delinquent employee who has been found guilty of major offences, namely, misconduct, corruption, theft, misappropriation, cheating and prejudi­cial act against national security or any subversive act as per provisions of Rule</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-pagination: none; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 18.95pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 1.45pt .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">39<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">     </span></span></span><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">(kha), (uma), (cha) and (chha) re­spectively of the Service Rules. These four types of major penalties under Rule</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: 0in; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-pagination: none; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 18.95pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">40<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">     </span></span></span><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">(1) (Kha) can be inflicted upon a delinquent employee considering the gravity of the offence committed by him. Accordingly, Rule "40(1) (L) (A)" provides for demotion of an employee to a lower post or to a lower grade of service scale, Rule "40( 1) (L) (Av)" pro­vides for realization of the financial loss caused to the Rural Electrification Board from the salary or other entitle­ments of the employee and Rule "40(1) (L) (B)" provides for removal (WPTRH) from service but "40( 1) (L) (C)" pro­vides for dismissal (WM) from service. In the REB Service Rules, 1990 there is no definition of removal (w=<sup>,</sup>W3<sup>c</sup>f) and dismissal (^TRS). But according to the REB Service Rules, there is some dif­ference between dismissal and removal as to their consequences. From the de­cided cases in different jurisdiction of the sub-continent we get some light as to the meaning of these two expres­sions. <em>The Chairman, REB vs. Md. Awlad Hossain (Md. Muzammel Hos-sain J)(Civil) 9 ADC 153</em></span></p></div></div>

style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">The River Research Institute Act, 1990</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">The petitioner completed pensionable service under respondent No.2 and he is legally entitled to pension. The pension of the petitioner has illegally been stayed. <em>Md. Tozammel Hossain vs. River Research Institute (Mohammad Fazlul Karim J) (Civil) 6 ADC 326</em></span></p></div></div>
137	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">The Said Act, </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>   6 ADC 772</p><p><b>Subject:</b>   Said </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-11-11</p><!DOCTYPE html><p><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> <o:OfficeDocumentSettings>  <o:RelyOnVML/>  <o:AllowPNG/> </o:OfficeDocumentSettings></xml><![endif]--><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> <w:WordDocument>  <w:View>Normal</w:View>  <w:Zoom>0</w:Zoom>  <w:TrackMoves/>  <w:TrackFormatting/>  <w:PunctuationKerning/>  <w:ValidateAgainstSchemas/>  <w:SaveIfXMLInvalid>false</w:SaveIfXMLInvalid>  <w:IgnoreMixedContent>false</w:IgnoreMixedContent>  <w:AlwaysShowPlaceholderText>false</w:AlwaysShowPlaceholderText>  <w:DoNotPromoteQF/>  <w:LidThemeOther>EN-US</w:LidThemeOther>  <w:LidThemeAsian>X-NONE</w:LidThemeAsian>   <w:SplitPgBreakAndParaMark/>   <w:DontVertAlignCellWithSp/>   <w:DontBreakConstrainedForcedTables/>   <w:DontVertAlignInTxbx/>   <w:Word11KerningPairs/>   <w:CachedColBalance/>  </w:Compatibility> <w:LatentStyles DefLockedState="false" DefUnhideWhenUsed="true"  DefSemiHidden="true" DefQFormat="false" DefPriority="99"  LatentStyleCount="267">  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="0" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Normal"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="9" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="heading 1"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="9" QFormat="true" Name="heading 2"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="9" QFormat="true" Name="heading 3"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" 138	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">The Securities and Exchange Ordi­nance, 1996</h2>

text-autospace: none; margin: 2.4pt 0in .0001pt 0in;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">The Securities and Exchange Ordi­nance, 1996 ,Section 17</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.4pt 0in .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.4pt 0in .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; letter-spacing: .5pt;">The relevant facts of the case, in brief, are that a petition of complaint was filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission, represented by the Exec­utive Director in the Court of the Chief Metropolitan Magistrate, Dhaka stat­ing that the accused firm and other ac­cused acted as dealer / broker in the Dhaka Stock Exchange and in such ca­pacity of being dealer / broker was in­volved in fraudulent activities during the month of July to December, 1996 within the mischief of Section 17 of the Securities and Exchange Ordi­nance, 1996. The offence was detected by an inquiry committee formed by the Securities and Exchange Commis­sioner who inquired into the matter under section 21 of the Securities and Exchange Ordinance, 1969. <em>Securities and Exchange Commission vs. Dona Securities (Muhammad Imman Ali J) (Criminal) 9 ADC 802</em></span></p></div></div>
139	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">The Sonali Bank (Employees) Serv­ice Regulations, 1981</h2>

mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">The Sonali Bank (Employees) Serv­ice Regulations, 1981</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">The departmental proceeding of the Bank being held in violation of the pro­vision of the Service Regulations of the Sonali Bank cannot be treated as legal or valid inasmuch as the respondent em­ployee in the instant case has been de­nied his right to raise any objection against the appointment of the inquiry officer. <em>Sonali Bank Limited vs. Md. Abdul<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">   </span>Aziz<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">   </span>(Shah<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">   </span>Abu Nayeem Mominur Rahman J) (Civil) 6ADC541</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></em></p></div></div>
140	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">The Specific Relief Act,</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  6 ADC 996, 10 ADC 913,  6 ADC 1006, 8 ADC 26, 10 ADC  721, 6 ADC 661, 10 ADC 98,  7 ADC 168, 8 ADC 483, 8 ADC 486, 8 ADC 488, <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="39" QFormat="true" Name="TOC Heading"/> </w:LatentStyles></xml><![endif]--><!-- [if gte mso 10]><style> /* Style Definitions */ table.MsoNormalTable	{mso-style-name:"Table 5.4pt;	mso-para-margin:0in;	mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;	font-size:10.0pt;	font-family:"Times New Roman","serif";}</style><![endif]--></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">The Specific Relief Act, Section 42</span></em></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Plaintiff constructed houses thereon though her bharatias on the basis of the right of adverse possession acquiring title and possession thereof and during the last survey, the suit land was wrongly recorded in the name of the fa­ther of defendant. Rada Rani Nath vs. Niranajan Dutta (Mohammad Fazlul Karim J) (Civil) 6 ADC 996</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Section 42</span></em></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">A suit in which title of the plaintiff has been disputed by the defendant, a decla­ration of title and possession is neces­sary and in the absence of a prayer for such declaration such suit is not main­tainable in view of the proviso to sec­tion 42 of the Specific Relief Act and hence the decree as passed is illegal and not maintainable. Kadbanu Bibi vs. Wazed AH Sikder (Shah Abu Nayeem Mominur Rahman J)(Civil) 10 ADC 913</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Section 42</span></em></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">For declaration of title, recovery of pos­session of the suit land after demolish­ing the structures thereon and for mesne profit and permanent injunction. A. Hakim Gazi vs. Gazi Safiqul Islam (Md.</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Joy mil A bedin J) (Civil) 6 ADC 1006</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Section 42</span></em></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Seeking declarations that the Memo No.299 dated 11.4.1994 passed by the defendant No. 1 cancelling the license of the plaintiff as a nikah registrar, the Memo No.291/l(4) of the same date di­recting the plaintiff to hand over the records, seals and other documents to the defendant No.3 and the Memo No.534 dated 17.4.1994 issued by de­fendant petitioner No.3 directing the plaintiff to remain present in his office on 21.4.1994 with the register, seal and other documents being illegal, beyond jurisdiction and contrary to the relevant provisions of law are not binding upon him. <em>District Registrar vs. Md. Shariful Islam (Md. Tafazzul Islam J) (Civil) 8 ADC 26</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Section 39</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">The suit has been filed for declaration of title and confirmation of possession<br/>and also for khas possession if the plaintiff is found to be out of possession of<br/>the suit land during pendency of the suit<span style="mso-tab-count: 1;">         </span>(2)</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">The High Court noted that during the hearing of the Mutation Case, it was disclosed that defendant No.l pur­chased the suit land in 1961 and that the plaintiff filed an application to the Bu­reau of Anticorruption and at its in stance, the thumb impressions of Mo- <strong>I </strong>hammad Mia Chowdhury, the execu- \ tant, appearing on the deed of sale dated <strong>I </strong>14.11.1961 and the deed of exchange date 14.02.1985 were examined by a finger print expert who opined that the thumb impressions of Mohammad Mia Chowdhury, in fact, were on the deed of <strong>I </strong>sale dated 14.11.1961 and the deed of <strong>I </strong>exchange. The High Court Division <strong>j </strong>came to a finding that the suit land was ! transferred in favour of defendant No. 1 | on 14.11.1961 (Exhibit-Ga) which was | much earlier than the deed of exchange dated 14.02.1985 (Exhibit-4). The High Court Division further came to a finding ! that on the date of execution of the deed <strong>j </strong>of exchange dated 14.02.1985, pro- ! forma-defendant No. 13 did not have <strong>I </strong>any saleable interest in the suit land, <strong>j </strong>The High Court Division also came to <strong>I </strong>a finding on consideration of materials | on record that the plaintiff was not in | possession of the suit land.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">    </span><em>Haji \ Shafiqur Rahman vs. Abdul Malek \ Chowdhury (Syed Mahmud Hossain J) (Civil) 10 ADC<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">   </span>. 721</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Section 42</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">For declarations that the order dated 23.10.1976 of the Additional Deputy Commissioner (Rev), the defendant No.2, for forfeiture the suit land is ille­gal and has no binding force in law and their right title and interest in the suit land have not been affected thereby and that they entitled to get decree for khas possession of the suit land. <em>Bangladesh and represented vs. Mariam Begum (Md. Tafazzul Islam J)(Civil) 6 ADC 661</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">Section 42</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';">We have heard the learned Advocate-On-Record for the petitioners, perused the impugned judgment and order of the High Court Division and other con­nected papers on record. It appears that the High Court Division having consid­ered the materials on record made con­current findings of the facts with the learned Sub-Ordinate Judge to the effect that some portion of Bainama is over written and some other portion of the Bainama appears to have been erased and signature of the Munshi appears to be illegible and over written which gave rise to concoction as to its veracity. <em>An-warullah vs. Deputy Commissioner, Lakshmipur Court Building (Md. Muza-mmel Hossain J)(Civil) 10 ADC 98</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.4pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt;">Section 42</span></em></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">The trial court on consideration of the evidence on record came to the finding that the plaintiffs could not prove their title and possession in the suit land. The trial court further noticed that the plain­tiffs could not prove that summons was not served upon there predecessor, who was defendant no. 18 in other suit no. 05 of 1988 nor the plaintiffs could prove that the summons was suppressed in</span></em> <em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">collusion with the process server and the decree passed in suit being Other Suit No.5 of 1988 was a valid decree and the suit was hit by Section 42 of the Specific Relief Act since the plaintiff have no interest in the suit land. Anwar Munshi vs. Kulsum Begum (B.K.Das J)(Civil) 7 ADC 168</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt;">Section 12</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">For Specific Performance of contract stating, inter alia, that the plaintiff com­pany is a sister concern of Globe Phar­maceuticals Group of Companies. The defendant No.4 company obtained loan from the defendant No. 1 Bank and the defendant No.5 as the Managing Direc­tor of the defendant No.4 company and guarantor of the loan had mortgaged his property with the defendant No. 1 Bank as collateral security. <em>Globe Druges Ltd vs. Arab Bangladesh Bank Ltd (S.K. Sinha J) (Civil) 8 ADC 483</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt;">Section 42</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">Taking advantage of the plaintiffs mi­nority during the last settlement opera­tion, Jabed Ali, son of Rahman Ali in collusion with the settlement staff got the suit lands recorded in his name. <em>Md. Kabir Hossain vs. Abdur Razzak Mallik (S.K. Sinha J)(Civil) 8 ADC 486</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></em></p><p class="Style4" style="text-align: justify; mso-pagination: widow-orphan;"><span class="FontStyle13"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">Section 42</span></span></p><p class="Style4" style="text-align: justify; mso-pagination: widow-orphan;"><span class="FontStyle13"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;"> </span></span></p><p class="Style2" style="margin-top: 3.1pt; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-pagination: widow-orphan;"><span class="FontStyle14"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">Was collusive, void, ineffective, illegal and violative of the Rules of Madrasha Shikkah Board Regulations and the same is not binding upon the plaintiff. </span></span><span class="FontStyle12"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">Musrat Dhulia Dakhil Madrasha vs. Md. Rafiqul Islam (Shah Abu Naveem Mominur Rahman J)(Civil) </span></span><span class="FontStyle15"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">8 </span></span><span class="FontStyle12"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">ADC </span></span><span class="FontStyle15"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">488</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt;">Section 54: Exclasive possession</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">The learned Advocate appearing for the leave petitioners submitted that the High Court Division erred in arriving at its decision on misreading and non-con­sideration of the materials on record inasmuch as the High Court Division has found both the parties in possession and the suit land has not been divided or partitioned on metes and bounds and that the Appellate Court below erred in decreeing the suit without discussing and considering the depositions of the witnesses and evidences adduced and produced in the case by the respective parties and that the Appellate Court below though reversed the judgment of the trial Court but did not reverse the findings of the trial Court relating to the exclusive possession on the undivided suit plots. <em>Joynal Abedin vs. Shahidul Islam (Shah Abu Nayeem Mominur Rahman J) (Civil) 8 ADC 492</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></em></p><p class="Style4" style="text-align: justify; mso-pagination: widow-orphan;"><span class="FontStyle13"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">Section 42</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">The petitioner instituted the above suit</span> <span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">seeking two declarations, one, for decla­ration of title in respect of schedule one land, and the other, for declaration that the deed described in schedule two of the plaint is not binding upon him. <em>AH Amzad Khan vs. Md. Titam Khan (S.K. Sinha J) (Civil) 8 ADC 495</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt;">Section 12</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">The plaintiff-respondent filed the above mentioned Other Suit No. 136 of 2000 against this defendant-petitioner and others for specific performance of con­tract. The plaint case, in short, was that the suit land originally belonged to Umacharan who died leaving son Bijoy Sree Barua. That Bijoy Sree Barua while was in possession of the suit land along with other properties died leaving four sons in Prodip Barua @ Bappi (the defendant-petitioner), Dilip @ Badal Barua, Probal Barua @ Babul and Pro-bir Barua @ Monu Barua and wife Mukta Rani Barua @ Kishi. Mukta Rani Barua @ Kishi relinquished her share in favour of her four sons. On am­icable partition among the sons of Bijoy Sree Barua the suit land fell in the saham of Prodip Barua @ Bappi-the principal defendant. <em>Sree Prodip Barua alias Bappi vs. Faisal Madani (Nazmun Ara Sultana J) (Civil) 9 ADC 231</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">seeking two declarations, one, for decla­ration of title in respect of schedule one land, and the other, for declaration that the deed described in schedule two of the plaint is not binding upon him. <em>AH Amzad Khan vs. Md. Titam Khan (S.K. Sinha J) (Civil) 8 ADC 495</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt;">Section 12</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">The plaintiff-respondent filed the above mentioned Other Suit No. 136 of 2000 against this defendant-petitioner and others for specific performance of con­tract. The plaint case, in short, was that the suit land originally belonged to Umacharan who died leaving son Bijoy Sree Barua. That Bijoy Sree Barua while was in possession of the suit land along with other properties died leaving four sons in Prodip Barua @ Bappi (the defendant-petitioner), Dilip @ Badal Barua, Probal Barua @ Babul and Pro-bir Barua @ Monu Barua and wife Mukta Rani Barua @ Kishi. Mukta Rani Barua @ Kishi relinquished her share in favour of her four sons. On am­icable partition among the sons of Bijoy Sree Barua the suit land fell in the saham of Prodip Barua @ Bappi-the principal defendant. <em>Sree Prodip Barua alias Bappi vs. Faisal Madani (Nazmun Ara Sultana J) (Civil) 9 ADC 231</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt;">Section 42</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">Plaint has not been incorporated in the paper book, but from the judgment of the trial Court it appears that the suit was filed for declaration that the initia­tion of vested property Case No.9 of 1984 (KDA) and the notice issued in the said case on 27.09.1984 asking the plaintiffs to hand over possession of the suit property was illegal, without juris­diction and also for a mandatory injunc­tion to restore back possession of the suit property to the plaintiffs. <em>Govern­ment of Bangladesh vs. Monwarul A lam (Md. Abdul Wahhab Miah J) (Civil) 8 ADC 679</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Section 42</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.65pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">From the impugned judgment passed by the High Court Division, it appears that it did not at all consider the pertinent legal aspect involved in the case that after final publication of R.S. record a suit for declaration simpliciter that such record was wrong was not maintainable in law and further wrong recording of the suit land having created cloud over plaintiffs title he was not entitled to get saham in the suit land without establish­ing his title therein. </span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Jiban Chandra Sarkar vs. Md. Rafizuddin Beparv (Md. Abdul Wahhab Miah J)(Civil) 8 ADC 760</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 5.3pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Section 42</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-right: .5pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.65pt .5pt .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast; letter-spacing: .5pt;">The learned Assistant Judge dismissed the suit holding that the mother of the plaintiff could not get possession of the suit land on the basis of the deed of 1928. On appeal from the said judgment by the defendants, the Court of appeal below affirmed the judgment of the trial Court observing that the defendant No. 1 proved his possession in pursuance of the deed of gift dated 14th November, 1958, exhibit-Ka, that the plaintiff did not challenge the defendants deeds ex-hibits-A-Tha executed by Mohendra to Ashiaron Rahman . </span><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;">Sukendra Bikas Das vs. Anil Baran Das (S.K. Sinha J) (Civil) 8 ADC 764</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.65pt .5pt .0001pt 0in;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 2.65pt .5pt .0001pt 0in;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-theme-font: minor-fareast;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt;">Section 42</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">It further appears that the High Court Division also found that the trial Court misread the evidence and materials on record and illegally held that the plain­tiffs have not acquired title, interest and possession in the suit land. <em>Mohadashi Sutradhar vs. Monindra Chandra San-nvashi Md. Abdul Wahhab Miah J (Civil) 8 ADC 773</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt;">Section 42</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">The suit land was purchased by plaintiff No.l and one Sokiruddin by kabala dated 07.12.1955 from its owner and in the S.A.. Khatian their names were recorded to the extent of 22 decimals of land instead of 26 decimals. Sokiruddin transferred 13 decimals of land to plain­tiff Nos.2 and 3 by sale dated 05.12.1948. Plaintiff Nos.2 and 3 sold .0375 acre of land to plaintiff No.4 by a kabala dated 23.11.1996. <em>Md. Abdul Hakim vs. Government of Bangladesh (Md. Abdul Wahhab Miah J)(Civil) 8 ADC 801</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt;">Section 55</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">The learned Subordinate Judge upon hearing the parties by judgment and order dated 29th April, 1997 allowed the application for mandatory injunction</span> <span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">on the reasonings that a local inspection was held wherein the Advocate Com­missioner reported that the respondents no. 1 and 2 had started construction of a house towards 3 ft. west of the appel­lant's house, and thereafter the Second Advocate Commissioner reported that the respondents had already completed the house and they had started a con­struction of a new one and they also dug up a ditch towards the north-west­ern comer and thereby the they made the constructions in utter violation of the Court's order and accordingly, di­rected the respondents to remove the said constructions within 15 days at their own cost, failing which, it was di­rected that the plaintiff-appellant would be able to remove the constructions through the process of the Court. <em>Md.Azizur Rahman Chowdhury vs. Tauhiduddin Chowdhury (S. K. Sinha J) (Civil) 8 ADC 915</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt;">Section 42</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">Whether a domesticated son-in-law is entitled to the right of residence, posses­sion and maintenance from the estate of his father-in-law. <em>Roy Mohan Dey vs. Jogesh Chandra Dey (Nazmun Ara Sul­tana J) (Civil) 8 ADC 921</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt;">Section 53</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">The facts of the case, in brief, are that the petitioners instituted a suit being</span> <span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">Title Suit No.90 of 1978, before the Court of Munsif, Nawabganj, praying</span> <span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">for a decree for permanent injunction, on being threatened dispossession by the defendants. The defendant Nos. 1 to 4 contested the suit by filing a written statement, denying all material aver­ments made in the plaint. <em>Mosammal Rahima Khatun vs. Emran Ali (A.B.M. Khairul Haque J)(Civil) 8 ADC 991</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt;">Section 42 and 39</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">The facts, in short, are that the respon­dent No.l filed a suit being the Other Suit NO.116 of 1997, in the Court of Assistant Judge, Shibganj, Bogra, pray­ing for a decree for a declaration that the Waqf Deed No.6152, executed and registered on 03.06.1997, is collusive, void and not binding upon the plaintiff. <em>Satana Para Mosque vs.Amser Ali Swarnakar (A.B.M. Khairul Haque J)(Civil) 8 ADC 995</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt;">Section 42</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">The facts leading to the filing of this pe­tition are that these petitioners filed a suit being Title Suit No.313 of 1988 in the Court of Assistant Judge, Bagerhat, praying for decrees for establishment of their title, confirmation of possession and permanent injunction with a prayer for further declaration that the decree passed in Title Suit No.267 of 1967 is illegal, collusive and not binding upon</span> <span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">the plaintiffs. The plaintiffs claimed the suit-land by virtue of oral settlement from one Syed Tujammel Ali who got it by amicable partition with other original owners. The defendant No.34 and the defendant Nos.36-48 contested the suit by filing separate written statements, denying all material averments made in the plaint. It is contended on behalf of the defendant No.34 that the owners of the suit-land left this country before 1959 and the Government took it over as khas land and leased out to the defen­dant No.35. The defendant Nos.36 to 48 claimed title by purchase from the heirs of the C. S. recorded tenants. They also claim that they are in possession of the suit-land. <em>Abdul Hakim Howlader vs. Narayan Chandra Paul (A.B.M. Khairul Haque J) (Civil) 8 ADC 998</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt;">Section 42</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">The facts leading to the filing of this pe­tition are that the respondents herein filed a suit for declaration and recovery of khas possession of the suit-land. The petitioner Nos. 1 and 2 contested the suit by filing a written statement, denying all material averments made in the plaint. <em>Siddiqur Rahman vs. Abdul J alii Meah (A.B.M. Khairul Haque J) (Civil) 8 ADC 1002</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 4.55pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; mso-bidi-language: BN-BD;">Section 42</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 4.55pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; mso-bidi-language: BN-BD;"> </span></strong></p><p class="Style3" style="margin-top: 2.15pt; line-height: normal; mso-pagination: widow-orphan;"><span class="FontStyle13"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">The trial court, on consideration of evi</span></span><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-bidi-language: BN-BD;">dence adduced by the contesting parties and other facts and circumstances, dis­missed the suit by the judgment and order dated 17.04.2004 holding mainly that the plaintiffs could not prove the case that the impugned kabala deed was forged, collusive etc. The trial court also found that the contesting defendants have been possessing the suit land by recording the same in their names and on payment of rent since their purchase. <em>Md. Amzad Hossain Parag vs. Md. Sai-ful Islam (Nazmun Ara Sultana J) (Civil) 9 ADC 224</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; mso-bidi-language: BN-BD;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; mso-bidi-language: BN-BD;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 4.8pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; mso-bidi-language: BN-BD;">Section 42</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; mso-bidi-language: BN-BD;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; mso-bidi-language: BN-BD;">Mr. Mohammad Ali Akanda, the learned Advocate for the petitioners in both the civil petitions has assailed the impugned judgment and order of the High Court Division by making submis­sions to the effect that the appellate court below fell in error in reversing the judgment and decree of the trial court without examining the evidence on record properly and without assigning any reason for reversing the judgment of the trial court and the learned judge of the High Court Division also af­firmed this judgment of the appellate court below mechanically without ap­plying his judicial mind. <em>Rezia Khatun Chowdhurani vs. Sayeda Sirajunnessa Khatun (Nazmun Ara Sultana J)(Civil) 9 ADC 299.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; mso-bidi-language: BN-BD;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; mso-bidi-language: BN-BD;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 2.4pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 14.15pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Arial Unicode MS'; mso-bidi-language: BN-BD;"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt;">Section 42</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">The learned Counsel has argued that the High Court Division has committed error in not taking into consideration the sufficient materials on record which prove that Madhu Kha got back the suit land from Somir Mollah and Somir Gain as per agreement entered in be­tween them. The learned Counsel has argued also that the court of appeal below committed wrong in holding that the patta and kabuliyat executed and registered in between Madhu Kha and Somir Mollah and Somir Gain being in terms of uncertainty were not accept­able in the eye of law inspite of the suf­ficient evidence to prove that Madhu Kha got back the suit land from Somir Mollah and Somir Gain and possessed the same. <em>Md. Jashimuddin Kha vs. Md. Amir Uddin Gain (Nazmun Ara Sultana J) (Civil) 9 ADC 305</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt;">Section 42</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">Mr. Mohsin Rasid, learned Advocate, appearing for the petitioners submitted that a benami transaction of immovable property can not be made by way of gift and as such, the claim of the plaintiff that he transferred the suit property to his wife, the defendant No.l by execut­ing deed of Heba-bil-Ewaz dated 26.10.1979 and she was his benamder only in respect of the suit property is not tenable in law. <em>Most. Momtaj Begum vs. Md. Abdul Wahab Miah (Mohammad Fazlul Karim CJ)(Civil) 9 ADC 308</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 12.0pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.5pt; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"> </span></p></div></div>
141	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">The Trade Organization Ordi­nance, 1961</h2>

3"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="65" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium List 1 Accent 3"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="66" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium List 2 Accent 3"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="67" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 1 Accent 3"/>  <w:LsdException
